5032 CRICKET PAKISTAN 473-6 AT TEA ON FOURTH DAY THIRD TEST 
5033 LONDON 1996-08-25 
5034 Pakistan were 473-6 at tea on the fourth day of the third and final test at The Oval on Sunday in reply to England 's 326 
5035 Scores England 326 ; Pakistan 473-6 
5036 CRICKET RUN-OUT GIVES LEWIS AND ENGLAND SLIM SATISFACTION 
5037 LONDON 1996-08-25 
5038 Chris Lewis did his best to forget his controversial omission from the England one-day squad on Sunday but could not prevent Pakistan reasserting their dominance in the final test at The Oval 
5039 A super piece of fielding by Lewis dropped as a disciplinary measure after arriving only 35 minutes before the start on the fourth morning provided the only bright spot for England as the touring team batted on to reach 413 for five at the interval a lead of 87 
5040 The solitary wicket to fall was Asif Mujtaba run out for 13 attempting a second run to third man where Lewis was lurking with a point to prove 
5041 There seemed scant danger until the Surrey player swooped on to the ball and returned off balance to county team mate Alec Stewart who whipped off the bails 
5042 Lewis though could not make similar waves with the ball as Salim Malik and Wasim Akram batted through the rest of the session with few alarms 
5043 Wasim rattled along to 30 not out outscoring his partner who was unbeaten on 24 at the break although the weather was again threatening to play the dominant role 
5044 Rain arrived just as the players left the field for lunch forcing the ground-staff into action yet again 
5045 The weather delayed the resumption for over an hour the umpires finally announcing play would start again at 1445 local time 1345 GMT

5392 BASEBALL ORIOLES SNEAK PAST ANGELS 
5393 BALTIMORE 1996-08-25 
5394 Rafael Palmeiro 's two-out single in the sixth inning scored Roberto Alomar with the go-ahead run as the Baltimore Orioles rallied past the California Angels 5-4 and took over the American League 's wild-card berth on Saturday 
5395 The Orioles trailed 4-3 when pinch-hitter Mike Devereaux led off the sixth with a triple against reliever Kyle Abbott 0-1 and scored the tying run on Alomar 's single 
5396 After Brady Anderson sacrificed Palmeiro hit the first pitch into right field for a single scoring Alomar 
5397 In Boston former Mariner Darren Bragg 's first career grand slam in the sixth inning off reliever Randy Johnson lifted the Boston Red Sox to their fifth win in six games a 9-5 victory over Seattle 
5398 Just one of those things I was just trying to make contact said Bragg 
5399 The bases were loaded and I had two strikes 
5400 I was just trying to put the ball in play 
5401 I got the good part of the bat on it and it carried out 
5402 In Cleveland Kevin Seitzer 's two-out single in the top of the 10th brought home David Hulse with the winning run as the Milwaukee Brewers sent the Cleveland Indians to their third straight extra-inning defeat 4-3 
5403 Bob Wickman 5-1 acquired from the New York Yankees on Friday earned the win in his Milwaukee debut despite allowing the tying run in the eighth inning 
5404 At Minnesota Marty Cordova and Matt Lawton hit solo homers and Frankie Rodriguez allowed six hits over seven innings to earn his first win as a starter in a month as the Minnesota Twins held on to beat the Texas Rangers 6-5 
5405 Yeah you know it 's fun it 's always fun when you 've got a chance to go to the ballpark and win a game that 's important said Rodriguez 
5406 Every game should be important but it 's a little more important now 
5407 In New York Wally Whitehurst allowed two runs over seven innings for his first win in more than two years and Paul O'Neill 's three-run double snapped a sixth-inning tie as the New York Yankees held on for a 5-4 victory over the Oakland Athletics 
5408 Whitehurst promoted from Triple-A Columbus on Wednesday allowed seven hits and struck out one without a walk 
5409 It was his first win since defeating the St. Louis Cardinals on May 28th 1994 when he was with the San Diego Padres 
5410 In Kansas City Jose Rosado came within one out of his third complete game and Michael Tucker homered and drove in three runs as the Kansas City Royals broke a six-game losing streak with a 9-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers in a battle of cellar-dwellers 
5411 Rosado 5-3 allowed two runs one earned and seven hits over 8-2/3 innings with three walks and six strikeouts 
5412 In his last four starts the 21-year-old left-hander has given up only four earned runs in 29-2/3 innings 
5413 BASEBALL BRAVES RALLY TO BEAT CUBS 
5414 ATLANTA 1996-08-25 
5415 Fred McGriff went 5-for-5 and homered twice including a three-run blast with two out in the bottom of the ninth inning that lifted the Atlanta Braves to a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs on Saturday 
5416 I was just trying to hang in there and hit it up the middle said McGriff about his homer in the ninth 
5417 I was just looking for the ball trying to stay on it 
5418 Brad Clontz 6-2 picked up the win in relief for Atlanta which has won 11 of its last 13 games 
5419 In Colorado Mark Thompson threw an eight-hitter for his third complete game and Ellis Burks homered and drove in three runs as the Colorado Rockies beat the Pittsburgh Pirates 9-3 
5420 Vinny Castilla and Dante Bichette each added two RBI for Colorado which improved the major league 's best home mark to 44-20 
5421 At Florida Kevin Brown scattered seven hits over eight innings and Kurt Abbott snapped a sixth-inning tie with a two-run double as the Florida Marlins defeated the tired Cincinnati Reds 5-3 
5422 The Marlins won for just the third time in nine games taking advantage of a Reds team that has not had a day off since August 8th and was playing its fourth game in 43 hours 
5423 In Los Angeles Tom Candiotti allowed two runs in seven innings and singled home the go-ahead run and Mike Piazza and Todd Hollandsworth drove in two runs apiece as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the New York Mets 7-5 
5424 Candiotti 8-9 walked one allowed five hits and struck out a season-high eight batters for Los Angeles which has won 10 of its last 14 games 
5425 In San Diego Joey Hamilton allowed two hits over seven innings and Rickey Henderson hit his major league-record 69th leadoff homer as the San Diego Padres defeated the Philadelphia Phillies 7-1 for their fifth win in six games 
5426 Hamilton 12-7 won his second straight start allowing just a sixth-inning run and a pair of singles 
5427 In San Francisco Pedro Martinez allowed two hits in eight innings and David Segui drove in two runs as the Montreal Expos shut out the San Francisco Giants 3-0 for their third straight win 
5428 Martinez 11-7 who lasted just 1-1/3 innings in his last start against San Diego five days ago pitched eight-plus innings walking four and striking out 10 
5429 In Houston Orlando Miller 's two-run homer with one out in the bottom of the ninth off Todd Stottlemyre gave the Houston Astros a 3-1 win over the St. Louis Cardinals and left the teams in a virtual tie for the lead in the NL Central division 
5430 Shane Reynolds 16-6 fired a five-hitter walking one and striking out six

5451 SOCCER CHAMPIONS PORTO KICK OFF SEASON WITH A DRAW 
5452 LISBON 1996-08-25 
5453 Portuguese champions Porto kicked off the season with a disappointing 2-2 home draw against Setubal and were lucky to squeeze in an equaliser in extra time 
5454 Porto who are fighting to take their third consecutive title this season were 2-0 down until the 86th minute when a header by Mario Jardel found the net after a string of missed opportunities including a penalty taken by top league scorer Domingos Oliveira in the 60th minute 
5455 Domingos redeemed himself by netting the equaliser just into extra time 
5456 Setubal who put on a skilful counter-attack throughout the game opened the scoring 16 minutes into the match when an unmarked Chiquinho Conde shot around Porto 's new Polish keeper Andrejez Wozniak 
5457 Conde scored his second in the 70th minute 
5458 Benfica also playing their first game of the season at home were held to a 1-1 draw by northern side Braga despite the fact that the visitors were reduced to 10 men in the 54th minute after Rodrigo Carneiro was sent off for a second bookable offence 
5459 Benfica dominated the game but their lack of a first-class striker was apparent throughout and in the 30th minute they lost key Brazilian midfielder Valdo who suffered a light knee injury 
5460 He was substituted by Paulao 
5461 Benfica finally opened the scoring in the 81st minute with a penalty taken by Helder after Luis Baltasar tripped up captain Joao Pinto under the referee 's nose 
5462 Braga defender Idalecio gave his team their equaliser seven minutes from the final whistle with a header into the back of the net

5470 SOCCER FIORENTINA WIN WITH BATISTUTA DOUBLE 
5471 MILAN 1996-08-25 
5472 Argentine striker Gabriel Batistuta gave Fiorentina the perfect 70th birthday present on Sunday with two goals that gave the Italian Cup winners a 2-1 Supercup victory over serie A champions Milan 
5473 The victory coming on the eve of the founding of the Florence club in 1926 also marked the first time since the pre-season trophy between the Cup winners and league champions was started in 1988 that the Cup winners had won 
5474 Batistuta gave Fiorentina the lead in the 11th minute 
5475 Sweden 's Stefan Schwarz picked him out with a lob to the edge of the box and Batistuta did the rest chipping veteran defender Franco Baresi and scoring at the near post 
5476 Montenegrin midfielder Dejan Savicevic equalised for the home team weaving past a defender checking and firing in a left-footed shot in the 21st minute that gave young Fiorentina goalkeeper Francesco Toldo little chance 
5477 The scored stayed level to the final minutes but with a penalty shoot out looming Batistuta took charge 
5478 French international midfielder Marcel Desailly fouled the Argentine whose coach at Boca Juniors before he joined Fiorentina in 1991 was new Milan coach Oscar Tabarez and Batistuta rammed home the free kick from 30 metres out 
5479 The 83rd minute shot curling over the defence and dipping in under the bar from the striker dubbed Batigol by adoring Fiorentina fans was just reward for Fiorentina who looked a far more impressive team 
5480 Milan 's player of the year George Weah missed a good first half opportunity but otherwise looked a little rusty while Italian team mate Roberto Baggio did not play due to injury 
5481 New Dutch signing Edgar Davids came on late in the second half as a Milan substitute but made little impact 
5482 The league season starts on September 8 
5483 SOCCER FIORENTINA BEAT MILAN IN ITALIAN SUPERCUP 
5484 MILAN 1996-08-25 
5485 Italian Cup winners Fiorentina beat 
5486 league champions Milan 2-1 halftime 1-1 in the pre-season 
5487 Supercoppa SuperCup in Milan on Sunday 
5488 Scorers

5490 Milan Dejan Savicevic 21st

5625 CYCLING FERRIGATO SPRINTS TO SECOND STRAIGHT WORLD CUP WIN 
5626 ZURICH 1996-08-25 
5627 Andrea Ferrigato of Italy sprinted to his second cycling World Cup win in successive weekends with victory in the Swiss Grand Prix on Sunday 
5628 Ferrigato winner of the Leeds Classic last Sunday with a one second win over Britain 's Max Sciandri posted a similarly narrow margin of victory again 
5629 The 26-year-old Italian surged past compatriot Michele Bartoli and last year 's winner and defending World Cup champion Johan Museeuw of Belgium in the final few metres of the 237km race 
5630 All three clocked the same time of five hours 51 minutes 52 seconds 
5631 Former world champion Lance Armstrong of the United States was in front as the leading pack of seven riders turned into the Oerlikon velodrome for the final one lap sprint but quickly faded and settled for fourth 
5632 The back-to-back wins vault Ferrigato from sixth to second in the overall World Cup rankings with 112 points but Museeuw continues to hold a commanding lead with 162 points after eight of the 11 rounds

5657 SOCCER PSV BEAT GRONINGEN 4-1 TO PULL AWAY FROM AJAX 
5658 AMSTERDAM 1996-08-25 
5659 Belgian international Luc Nilis scored twice on Sunday as PSV Eindhoven came from behind to beat Groningen 4-1 in Eindhoven 
5660 PSV and Vitesse Arnhem are the only unbeaten teams after two rounds of the Dutch league 
5661 Defending champions Ajax Amsterdam were defeated 2-0 loss away to Heerenveen on Saturday 
5662 Groningen took the lead in the seventh minute when Dean Gorre intercepted a back pass from Ernest Faber to goalkeeper Ronald Waterreus and shot home 
5663 Faber made amends in the 32nd minute when he headed in a corner to score the equaliser 
5664 PSV took control in the second half but could not score until Groningen striker Romano Sion was sent off in the 58th minute 
5665 Five minutes after his dimissal Nilis gave PSV the lead and in the final 15 minutes he added another as did Zeljko Petrovic 
5666 Vitesse Arnhem upstaged Utrecht 1-0 despite ending the match with only nine men following the dismissal of defenders Raymond Atteveld and Erwin van der Looi 
5667 Gaston Taument scored twice and newly signed Argentine Pablo Sanchez once in Feyenoord Rotterdam 's 3-0 victory over Volendam

5772 DUTCH CAPTAIN BLIND ENDS INTERNATIONAL CAREER 
5773 AMSTERDAM 1996-08-25 
5774 Dutch soccer captain Danny Blind has decided to end his international career Ajax spokesman David Endt said on Sunday 
5775 Endt told Dutch news agency ANP that Blind 35 would no longer be available for selection for the national squad 
5776 The Ajax defender who led the Netherlands into the quarter-finals at June 's European championship finals in England had decided to devote his attention to playing for his Amsterdam club Endt said 
5777 Blind who played in the 1990 World Cup and the 1992 European championship was capped 42 times for the Netherlands 
5778 CRICKET INDIA BANS SIDHU FOR 50 DAYS 
5779 NEW DELHI 1996-08-25 
5780 Indian opener Navjot Singh Sidhu was on Sunday given a 50-day ban from international cricket for quitting this year 's tour of England the Press Trust of India said 
5781 The right-handed batsman will have to forfeit half the money he was due to earn from the tour the news agency said after a disciplinary committee set up by the Board of Control for Cricket in India met at Mohali near the northern city of Chandigarh 
5782 Sidhu abandoned the Indian team after the third one-day international against England at Old Trafford in Manchester on May 26 before India began a three-test series citing serious differences with captain Mohammed Azharuddin 
5783 Azharuddin was sacked after the tour and replaced by Sachin Tendulkar 
5784 Sidhu was not considered for the four-nation Singer Cup beginning in Sri Lanka this month and the Sahara Cup against Pakistan scheduled to be played in Canada next month 
5785 Sidhu whose ban ends on October 14 will be free to play domestic cricket 
5786 He will not be considered for a test match against Australia starting on October 10 in New Delhi the United News of India said

5810 Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800 
5811 RUGBY UNION All Blacks relive triumph 
5812 PRETORIA Aug 25 Captain Sean Fitzpatrick and his All Blacks revisited the test venue today to relive some of the magic moments of yesterday 's momentous rugby victory over South Africa NZPA reported 
5813 Most of the test 15 who beat the Springboks 33-26 to secure New Zealand 's first-ever rugby series in South Africa stood in the middle of the empty 50,000-seat Loftus Versfeld 
5814 Magnificent said Fitzpatrick New Zealand 's most capped player and the world 's most capped forward 
5815 The players relived the moves and tries the tackles and what might have been as the emotions of victory continued 
5816 Zinzan Brooke the only No 8 in test rugby to have scored a dropped goal when he kicked a three-pointer against England during last year 's World Cup added a second to his name yesterday 
5817 I was right here he said standing at the spot where he had received the ball for the kick 
5818 The maul was there and I was going to go in but I thought I should hold off because we had the ball 
5819 When halfback Justin Marshall got the ball he was going to go on the openside where Jon Preston was so I emptied my lung at him to get the ball this way 
5820 I just hit through and I was punching the air before the ball got there 
5821 It cost me a few bucks at the bar 
5822 The decision to attempt a dropped goal was a spontaneous one Brooke said 
5823 It was just like the World Cup the ball came and the chance was there 
5824 Centre Frank Bunce said he had never felt so exhausted during a match 
5825 We were gutted and there was nowhere to hide they just kept coming at you he said 
5826 I was gone in the first 20 minutes completely exhausted but you had no choice 
5827 There was just so much riding on it 
5828 It 's amazing just how big this ground was yesterday 
5829 Two-try winger Jeff Wilson said he was so tired that he kept asking Bunce where he should be while defending 
5830 He told me I 'm buggered too so just hang in there Wilson recalled 
5831 About 4000 New Zealander supporters were partying into the early hours of today in the South African capital 
5832 Messages of goodwill continued to roll into the team hotel 
5833 All Blacks coach John Hart said Prime Minister Jim Bolger rang him today to offer his congratulations 
5834 He thanked us on behalf of the country which is really nice for the team and I understand we had tremendous support at home

5886 Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800 
5887 South Africa yet to hear from apartheid enforcers 
5888 Anton Ferreira 
5889 CAPE TOWN 1996-08-25 
5890 South Africa 's truth commission begins issuing subpoenas this week in a bid to dig beneath the political rationales and find the sinister figures who have the blood of the country 's race war on their hands 
5891 Leaders of the major parties involved from right-wing whites to radical blacks appeared before Archbishop Desmond Tutu 's Truth and Reconciliation Commission last week to paint the broad picture of their actions for or against apartheid 
5892 Most including former president F.W. de Klerk and African National Congress Deputy President Thabo Mbeki offered apologies for any mistakes they had made and accepted broad responsibility for the actions of their foot soldiers 
5893 But none named those guilty of ordering or carrying out any of the gross violations of human rights which Tutu is investigating 
5894 Human rights lawyer Brian Currin said the hearings last week were not intended as a form of confessional and that those who personally committed crimes during apartheid would testify only before a separate arm of the commission the amnesty committee 
5895 I do n't think one should have expected more than what one got he said 
5896 That was not the amnesty committee where perpetrators are expected to open their hearts and souls and to tell it all 
5897 The commission which has the power to grant amnesty to those who confess to abuses has begun hearing the testimony from people already in jail for their deeds 
5898 But others such as self-confessed secret police hit-squad leader Dirk Coetzee have yet to testify 
5899 Tutu 's deputy chairman Alex Boraine told reporters the commission would begin issuing subpoenas to suspects who refused to appear voluntarily some time this week 
5900 He added that former hardline apartheid president P.W. Botha could be among those called 
5901 But Currin who is advising several people regarded as perpetrators said this was not the best way to achieve the commission 's aims 
5902 A person can be forced to appear but the only way one is going to get to the truth in its totality is if people feel it is a good idea to go to the amnesty committee 
5903 At the moment this is not the case 
5904 He cited Coetzee who was charged with murder after confessing in media interviews to dirty tricks 
5905 His trial is due to start in December but the truth commission intends to decide on his amnesty application before that 
5906 Currin said the law had to be changed so all judicial prosecutions were automatically suspended for those who approached the truth commission 
5907 Last week 's submissions to the commission by the ANC de Klerk 's National Party and the right-wing Freedom Front of General Constand Viljoen left many South Africans unsatisfied 
5908 Boraine said the picture was incomplete because officers of the apartheid-era security forces had yet to make their scheduled separate submission but one black caller to a radio talk show declared 
5909 This whole thing is utterly useless it does n't help us at all 
5910 What the people expect is to have houses to have jobs 
5911 Political scientist Jannie Gagiano said he doubted that the National Party which implemented apartheid in 1948 and began dismantling it in 1990 felt it carried a burden of guilt and needed to be exculpated through the commission 
5912 Therefore I have some doubts about achieving some form of reconciliation 
5913 One has to feel a bit guilty to feel the need for reconciling yourself to a historical adversary he said 
5914 Professor Tom Lodge of the University of the Witwatersrand demurred saying 
5915 In the irritation in the jokes in the anger that white South Africans express about the commission I think there 's a moral uneasiness and I think that 's healthy 
5916 Responsibility is percolating downwards 
5917 Moslem refugees seek to vote in Serb-held town 
5918 Samir Arnaut 
5919 MATUZICI Bosnia 1996-08-25 
5920 Thousands of Moslem refugees denounced Bosnia 's elections as a farce on Sunday because Serb incomers would be able to vote in their old home town cementing partition of the country 
5921 They said they were ready to force their way back across post-war ethnic lines to Serb-held Doboj one of several towns where NATO troops fear violence involving refugees determined to vote where they once lived 
5922 The refugees rallying in Matuzici on government territory two km from Doboj in northeast Bosnia waved banners calling the polls a farce staged by the United Nations and the European Union 
5923 We demand to vote in Doboj other banners said 
5924 Bosnia 's Moslem-led central government and many displaced Moslems are angered by a key provision of the Western-organised September 14 elections allowing people to vote in post-war new places of residence 
5925 As a result separatist Serb authorities have packed former Moslem majority towns with refugees of their own or registered other Serbs to vote there 
5926 Critics say that what was billed as an electoral process to reintegrate Bosnia as a single multi-ethnic state is shaping up as a referendum on partition de facto or de jure 
5927 Only our physical presence in Doboj will mean that the Dayton peace treaty has truly been implemented Edhem Efendija Camdzic Doboj 's Islamic imam-in-exile told the refugees 
5928 The main point of this rally is to highlight to the world powers what misfortune they brought upon us said Reuf Mehemdagic head of Doboj municipality-in-exile 
5929 Eleven thousand Serbs who came from elsewhere to Doboj will vote there 
5930 How can we then expect the reintegration of Bosnia ? 
5931 But no one will stop us from returning to our homes 
5932 Mirhunisa Komarica a government refugee official said We want to vote where we were thrown out from 
5933 This is a protest of warning and the next step is entering our town using all means possible so let them shoot 
5934 Bosnian Vice President Ejup Ganic a Moslem told the refugees We have a message for the Serbs who are now in our homes not to plan the future of their children there because there will be no good fortune in that 
5935 To loud applause he added We will enter Doboj untie the Doboj knot and ensure free movement for all 
5936 We have to enter Doboj to free the Serbs from their own separatist politics 
5937 The Dayton peace accords guaranteed refugees the right to return to their homes and ensured freedom of movement across ethnic lines 
5938 But local police controlled by nationalist parties in Moslem Serb and Croat sectors of Bosnia and civilian mobs have turned ceasefire lines into virtually impassable borders 
5939 The majority of refugees from Bosnia 's 1992-95 war are Moslems from the Serb-controlled north and east 
5940 NATO-led peace troops beefed up their presence in the Doboj area on Sunday to deter any sudden emotional attempt by the refugees to cross the Inter-Entity Boundary Line into Doboj 
5941 But the crowd dispersed without incident 
5942 Moslems and Serbs have scuffled several times along the line in the past when Moslem refugees tried to surge into the town 
5943 Eight killed in Moscow casino blaze 
5944 MOSCOW 1996-08-25 
5945 Eight people died on Sunday in a blaze at a Moscow casino which the fire service said might have been started deliberately Interfax news agency said 
5946 The number of casinos has soared in Moscow since the collapse of communism 
5947 The mayor has said he wants to cut their number to five as part of a war against organised crime 
5948 President Boris Yeltsin signed a decree on fighting crime in July and handed wide-ranging powers to security chief Alexander Lebed currently engaged in making peace in breakaway Chechnya 
5949 Russian troops start pullout but not in Grozny 
5950 SHATOI Russia 1996-08-25 
5951 Russian troops began to pull out from southern Chechnya on Sunday under a ceasefire agreement between Russian security chief Alexander Lebed and rebel leaders 
5952 But in the capital Grozny the commander of Russian Interior Ministry forces in Chechnya General Anatoly Shkirko told Interfax news agency he was delaying a pullout of troops there after a group of Chechens disarmed an armoured column 
5953 Reuters cameraman Liutauras Stremaitis said a column of around 40 vehicles including tanks armoured personnel carriers artillery cannons and lorries escorted by Chechen rebels pulled out of the village of Shatoi towards the border around 50 km 31 miles to the north 
5954 In Grozny Shkirko told Interfax he was suspending the pullout of troops from the capital until weapons seized by the Chechens were returned 
5955 Chechen rebel spokesman Movladi Udugov confirmed the weapons had been seized but that it was a maverick group of Chechens 
5956 He said later that the rebels had handed them over 
5957 The pullout of the Russian troops is a key element of the peace plan brokered by Lebed which aims to end the 20-month Chechnya conflict 
5958 Leftist Mexican armed group says troops in capital 
5959 MEXICO CITY 1996-08-25 
5960 The leftist Popular Revolutionary Army EPR in a published report on Sunday said it operated throughout Mexico including the capital and denied government assertions it was isolated to one state 
5961 Commanders Vicente and Oscar guarded by a dozen EPR gunmen said in an interview with La Jornada outside Mexico City that the armed group was committed to overthrowing the government 
5962 They government officials want to present us before public opinion as a local problem as just being from Guerrero and as irrational radicals Commander Oscar told La Jornada 
5963 They said the ERP whose fighters first appeared wearing military fatigues and brandishing assault rifles in the southwestern state of Guerrero on June 28 had a 23,000-strong membership but this could not be confirmed independently 
5964 La Jornada also reported on Sunday that the Mexican Army has discovered a 37-page EPR manual detailing guerrilla tactics and strategies 
5965 It quoted the manual as saying The objective of the Basic Course on War is to provide for combatants of the EPR basic military knowledge for the armed conflict against the police and military apparatus of the bourgeoisie 
5966 It was the second time armed commanders of the EPR have granted interviews outside Guerrero state an extremely poor and volatile region where leftist protesters often have clashed violently with authorities 
5967 Unlike the better known and unrelated Zapatista rebels in southeastern Chiapas state the EPR has never taken on the army in direct combat according to official reports 
5968 There have only been a few skirmishes in Guerrero in which a handful of police soldiers and civilians have been killed or injured 
5969 Ten people gunned down in northwest Colombia 
5970 BOGOTA Colombia 1996-08-25 
5971 Unidentified gunmen dragged 10 men out ot their homes in a rural area of Colombia 's northwest province of Antioquia and shot them to death authorities said on Sunday 
5972 Police said the killings occurred on Saturday morning in the municipality of Anza but news of the massacre only reached the provincial capital of Medellin early on Sunday 
5973 Anza is only 20 miles 30 km west of Medellin but there are no roads linking it directly to the city 
5974 Police initially said leftist Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia FARC rebels were prime suspects in the killings 
5975 But gunmen of the left and right have killed with impunity across Antioquia for years and there were unconfirmed reports that the latest bloodshed was the work of a right-wing paramilitary group

5981 Two Thai border police wounded by Burma gunmen 
5982 MAE SOT Thailand 1996-08-25 
5983 Two Thai border policemen were seriously wounded on Sunday when members of a Burmese rebel splinter faction ambushed their patrol in northwest Thailand security officers said 
5984 The two were wounded in the early hours of Sunday when some 30 members of the Democratic Karen Buddhist Army DKBA ambushed their patrol on the Thai side of the border with Burma to the north of the town of Mae Sot 
5985 The Thai army commander in the area Col Suvit Maenmuan told reporters the DKBA which is allied with the Rangoon military government and based in southeast Burma had recently stepped up cross-border infiltration 
5986 Suvit said the motive for their intrusions was not clear but he had ordered reinforcements to beef up security along the porous frontier 
5987 The DKBA was formed in late 1994 by hundreds of guerrillas who split from the anti-Rangoon Karen National Union KNU and allied themselves with Burmese government army their former enemies 
5988 DKBA members have since launched intermittent cross-border attacks on Karen refugee camps in Thailand where the majority of inhabitants are KNU supporters and on Thai villages and police posts near the border 
5989 Bangkok has complained to Rangoon about the raids but Burmese military authorities say they have no contol over the faction 
5990 Thai army commanders reject the explanation saying they have evidence the Burmese army supplies and directs the renegade ethnic minority splinter faction 
5991 U.S. F-14 catches fire while landing in Israel 
5992 JERUSALEM 1996-08-25 
5993 A U.S. fighter plane blew a tyre and caught fire while landing on Sunday at Israel 's Ben Gurion airport an airport spokesman said 
5994 A U.S. F-14 military plane while landing at Ben Gurion airport blew a wheel and a fire broke out said spokesman Yehiel Amitai adding that the two pilots on board were not injured 
5995 Airport officials declared an emergency situation at the highest level and the fire brigade put out the flames while the plane was landing he said 
5996 Egypt hopes jars will reveal secrets of mummies 
5997 CAIRO 1996-08-25 
5998 Archaeologists in Egypt have found pots used by ancient Egyptians in burial rites that they say may reveal the secrets of mummification 
5999 Mohammed Saleh director of the Egyptian Museum told Reuters television a U.S. team found the pots some of which contain human intestines in a tomb built into the rocks while digging in Dahshour a village 40 km 25 miles south of Cairo 
6000 Dahshour is the site of Egypt 's second largest pyramid built for the pharaoh Seneferu more than 4,500 years ago 
6001 Saleh said the team from New York 's Metropolitan Museum found four Canopic jars and two unguent jars in the tomb which belongs to an unidentifed person who lived during the 12th Dynasty 1991-1786 BC in the Middle Kingdom 
6002 This finding is important because one of the jars still contains substances and materials used in the conservation of mummies and the conservation of the intestines and all the things which were in the cavity of a person we have not identified yet Saleh said 
6003 We hope that the analysis of such substances and liquids will reveal some secrets of the mummification process and materials used in this process he added

6065 Israeli president invites Arafat to home paper 
6066 JERUSALEM 1996-08-25 
6067 Israeli President Ezer Weizman has invited Yasser Arafat to meet him at his private home Israel 's biggest newspaper said on Sunday 
6068 The Yedioth Ahronoth daily reported that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu who has said he has no desire to hold talks with the Palestinian president opposes the meeting due to be held this coming week 
6069 The newspaper said Weizman scheduled the meeting at his private residence in the central Israeli village of Caesarea after Arafat sent him an emotional appeal to save the peace process 
6070 Netanyahu met Weizman last Tuesday and voiced his opposition Yedioth said 
6071 I am prepared to postpone the meeting under one condition that you give me a commitment right now to meet Arafat yourself within 10 days the paper quoted Weizman as telling Netanyahu 
6072 It said Netanyahu had yet to give Weizman an answer 
6073 The office of Israeli president is largely ceremonial 
6074 But Weizman a former defence minister and an architect of Israel 's peace treaty with Egypt has spoken out frequently on the peace process with the Palestinians at times urging the former Labour government to slow it down 
6075 Corporate America taking new view on compensation 
6076 Anne Murray 
6077 NEW YORK 1996-08-23 
6078 Corporate America is planning major changes in employee compensation in the next few years according to a recent study 
6079 What it comes down to is this If you 're highly skilled you 'll benefit nicely 
6080 But if you 're not and cannot contribute to your employer 's goals you 'll be paid less 
6081 The survey conducted in late 1995 and the early part of this year by management consulting firm Towers Perrin showed that the focus will be on an employee 's overall value to the company 's bottom line rather than how well an employee performs a specific task 
6082 Presently for example if an accountant 's job involves doing five specific tasks he or she can expect a certain salary said Sandra O'Neal a Towers Perrin principal 
6083 In the future the accountant will be evaluated solely on knowledge skill and abilities she said 
6084 In addition to using accounting skills the accountant will also have to be creative work well in a team be sensitive to customer needs and set productivity goals 
6085 The good news is if you 're highly skilled and have many abilities you 'll be paid more said O'Neal 
6086 The bad news is if you 're not skilled and ca n't contribute to a team to customer service and the organisation 's goals you 'll be paid less 
6087 Of the 750 mid-to-large size corporations surveyed 81 percent had undergone a major restructuring in the last three years and more than two-thirds reported that productivity and profits were up as result 
6088 Next on the agenda for these firms is developing a new compensation structure and 78 percent report that they are considering a new skills-based plan for both management and non-management employees 
6089 This coming shift O'Neal said is not just isolated or a fad 
6090 It 's an inexorable change 
6091 After World War II corporations adopted a military model creating hierarchical organisations where the concept of defined tasks worked great she said 
6092 But as the economy became global customers were more demanding and problems became more complex 
6093 Multi-layers kept management at a distance from its customers O'Neal said 
6094 Now organisations must change to stay competitive 
6095 O'Neal says firms will place a greater emphasis on teams and team performance in giving raises 
6096 If your team does well you 'll do well 
6097 If it does n't do well do n't expect a raise 
6098 Is this fair to an employee who can go the distance but is on a team that ca n't keep up ? 
6099 That 's an important question we used to ask a lot said O'Neal 
6100 It 's not a question we ask any more 
6101 The more important question is Do we have results ? 
6102 To get those results 27 percent of the companies surveyed plan to eliminate base pay increases in favour of cash bonuses and incentives such as employee and team award programmes and education 
6103 Companies that can change their culture and view employees as business partners will do well O'Neal said 
6104 For example the survey rated some participants in the survey as high-performing companies based on their return on equity above 16 percent 
6105 Those companies also said they already offer employees variable pay and business education give their managers more control over pay decisions and celebrate employee and team success 
6106 They respect employees more they trust employees more and they value their employees more O'Neal said 
6107 The key to success at high-performance companies is engaging employees in a business partnership 
6108 It will improve a company 's bottom line 
6109 Belgian police arrest detective in Dutroux affair 
6110 Geert de Clercq 
6111 NEUFCHATEAU Belgium 1996-08-25 
6112 Investigators arrested a senior police detective on Sunday in connection with their inquiries into Belgium 's child sex scandal Public Prosecutor Michel Bourlet said 
6113 Georges Zicot was arrested and will be charged with truck theft insurance fraud and document forgery Bourlet told a news conference 
6114 He said there had been searches at three sites on Sunday including one at the Charleroi judicial police headquarters where Zicot worked 
6115 Zicot 45 is a specialist in tackling vehicle theft 
6116 Belgian media reported that he had been questioned twice in the past two years about thefts but released both times 
6117 He was promoted to chief detective earlier this year 
6118 Bourlet said two other people had also been arrested 
6119 One was Gerard Pignon the owner of a warehouse where stolen vehicles were allegedly stored 
6120 The other was insurer Thierry Dehaan 
6121 Bourlet said the investigation into the vehicle theft ring would be added to the inquiry into the paedophile sex scandal in which five other people have already been arrested 
6122 He said the connection was through Bernard Weinstein an accomplice of convicted child rapist Marc Dutroux the central figure in the paedophile scandal that has sent shockwaves across Europe 
6123 Weinstein was found dead last weekend alongside the bodies of eight-year-olds Julie Lejeune and Melissa Russo in a house belonging to Detroux who said they starved to death earlier this year nine months after being abducted in June 1995 
6124 Two other girls have been rescued and police are hunting for at least two more who Dutroux has admitted kidnapping a year ago 
6125 Dutroux has admitted killing Weinstein after a disagreement between the accomplices in an affair of truck theft Bourlet said 
6126 Another four people were also questioned at the weekend but had not been detained Bourlet added 
6127 Anne Thily public prosecutor in the eastern city of Liege where Julie and Melissa lived said this was a major case involving some 50 investigators including two from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation

6134 19 die as bus falls in river in Pakistani Kashmir 
6135 MUZAFFARABAD Pakistan 1996-08-25 
6136 A bus fell from a mountain road into a river in Pakistan-ruled Azad free Kashmir on Sunday killing at least 19 people and injuring 11 police said

6140 North Afghan highway opening put off radio says 
6141 ISLAMABAD 1996-08-25 
6142 The planned reopening of Afghanistan 's main northern Salang highway as a result of peace talks with an opposition alliance has been put off until Wednesday official Kabul Radio said on Sunday 
6143 The embattled Afghan government said last week that the Kabul-Salang highway would be opened on Monday or Tuesday following talks with the Supreme Coordination Council alliance led by Jumbish-i-Milli movement of powerful opposition warlord General Abdul Rashid Dostum 
6144 The radio said on Sunday the postponement of the opening had been made due to precautions

6147 Hekmatyar rejoined the government as prime minister last June under a peace pact with Rabbani and has since been trying to persuade other opposition factions to follow suit 
6148 Earlier this month Jumbish denied a Kabul government statement that the two sides had agreed to a ceasefire in the north 
6149 Students burn Hasina effigy battle police 
6150 Anis Ahmed 
6151 DHAKA 1996-08-25 
6152 Students backed by opposition parties battled police and burned an effigy of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina during a strike in the north Bangladeshi town of Bogra on Sunday 
6153 The strikers barricaded streets attacked the local office of the ruling Awami League fought running battles with police and set alight hundreds of copies of the popular Janakantha newspaper alleging it was pro-government 
6154 Police used batons and teargas to try to disperse students who were throwing stones and home-made bombs witnesses said 
6155 The strike called by the main opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party BNP to denounce the deaths of four students killed by police over the last few days coincided with a visit to the area by Hasina 
6156 Local officials said one policeman was killed by gunshots during clashes with pro-opposition students on Thursday 
6157 Hasina told a cross section of people at the Bogra police headquarters on Sunday that the government had already suspended three police officers and ordered a judicial probe into the violent incidents 
6158 The prime minister offered financial grants to the families of those killed ordered the best possible medical care for the injured and urged Bogra residents to call off the strike 
6159 Opposition legislators walked out of parliament in Dhaka on Sunday denouncing unprecedented police barbarity against opposition students and supporters 
6160 They renewed their call for the resignation of Home Interior Minister Rafiqul Islam 
6161 Hundreds of police raided the Dhaka university on Sunday arresting nearly 30 outsiders who had been living in student dormitories and seizing weapons university officials said 
6162 Police stormed ten residence halls on the campus flushed out people at gunpoint and searched their baggage 
6163 They seized revolvers sawn-off rifles shotguns and knives 
6164 The students were later allowed to return 
6165 The swoop followed the resignation of the university 's Vice-Chancellor Dr. Emajuddin Ahmed on Saturday over the deteriorating law and order situation on the campus 
6166 Authorities closed down the 28,000-student university on Wednedsay following gunbattles between students and police 
6167 Police said they fought armed activists from the BNP headed by former prime minister Begum Khaleda Zia 
6168 Hasina told police the home ministry had already given a blanket order to arrest terrorists and possessors of illegal firearms irrespective of their political identities 
6169 Nearly 100 students have been injured in the clashes in Dhaka and Bogra police told reporters 
6170 16 die as bus crashes in Pakistani Kashmir 
6171 MUZAFFARABAD Pakistan 1996-08-25

6175 FEATURE Fertile Ukraine faces drought of cash and rain 
6176 Irene Marushko 
6177 BATKIVSHCHYNA COLLECTIVE FARM Ukraine 1996-08-26 
6178 Four shiny new green-and-yellow John Deere combines parked at this 1,750-hectare 4,325-acre farm in the grain-growing regions south of Kiev do n't fill its chief agronomist with enthusiasm 
6179 They did a good job this year but they need good diesel and good engine oil said Ivan Odnosum 
6180 God help us if there is a breakdown he said of the machinery loaned to the farm after the Ukrainian government bought it earlier this year 
6181 The country 's grain harvest this year is forecast to fall by more than 23 percent to only 28 million tonnes and two harsh factors are to blame 
6182 A drought scoured the steppes in May and June stunting the growing wheat 
6183 And the farming sector making the painful transition from Soviet central planning to a market economy simply has no money 
6184 Ukraine 's black soil is so fertile that a diplomat described it as rich enough to grow rubber boots 
6185 But recently Ukraine has been losing its reputation as a breadbasket of Europe earned in the years before brutal forced collectivisation under Soviet dictator Josef Stalin 
6186 The wheat will not be of a good quality this year said Hryhory Borsuk a scientist at the Mironivka Wheat Institute run by the Ukrainian Academy of Agrarian Sciences 
6187 The temperature on the ground reached 62 decrees Celsius 143.60 Fahrenheit this summer 
6188 We 've never seen anything so bad he said in an interview in his office unlit since the government cut off electricity because of unpaid power bills 
6189 The harvest is gathered in the dry areas but rainfall in Western Ukraine has delayed harvesting there 
6190 While Mironivka 's scientists some unpaid for months carry on developing new strains of wheat resistant to Ukraine 's extreme continental climate Borsuk said the lack of cash in Ukraine 's agricultural sector is as bad as the drought 
6191 Collective farms and Ukraine 's nascent private farming sector have no money for fertiliser no money for herbicides and pesticides no money to repair old or buy new machinery no money for fuel and none to buy good seed 
6192 This year 's harvest is down from last year 's 36.5 million tonne harvest which in turn compares with 50 million tonnes in 1990 the year before independence 
6193 The decline is all the worse for people who recall wasteful Soviet times when the Kremlin imported grain but priced bread so cheaply that people bought it to feed their pigs 
6194 Agriculture is very expensive and there are no solutions to our problems on the horizon said Odnosum 
6195 He said his farm its 260 workers now readying the fields for winter wheat sowing expected the land to yield 5.2 tonnes per hectare 2.5 acres but ended up with 3.9 tonnes still better than the national average of 2.11 tonnes per hectare this year 
6196 We did not have money for fertiliser we 're in debt for fuel and we 're borrowing diesel Odnosum said 
6197 A few kilometres miles down the two-lane road which passes Odnosum 's farm where the occasional horse-drawn buggy passes by is the 1,700-hectare 4,200-acre Shevchenko collective farm built next to a village still neat and tidy despite post-Soviet decay 
6198 Chief Accountant Natalya Sypron said the collective is strapped for cash earlier this year bartering 220 tonnes of grain for diesel to fuel six rickety grain combines and tractors badly in need of repairs and basic maintenance 
6199 The average family earns 160-200 million karbovanets a year $ 800 $ 1,000 but many have not been paid in months Soprun said 
6200 People are working out of their own dedication 
6201 Borsuk said the farm sector has two options We can sit down and cry or we can do something 
6202 He said the government plans to increase the sowing of the winter wheat which will be harvested next year 
6203 Planted in late summer and early autumn the grain is Ukraine 's largest export item and traditionally grows better than summer wheat in Ukraine 's soil 
6204 Further plans he said called for full provision of resources like fertiliser and herbicides for 25 percent of Ukraine 's arable land next year for 50 percent in 1998 and 100 percent of the land in 1999 
6205 If we follow this we 'll be able to sell 10 million tonnes of grain by the year 2000 Borkus said 
6206 The government has been trying to phase out huge subsidies to the farm sector and in a move back to pre-Soviet days has given up to 50 hectares 124 acres of land to some 36,000 private farmers willing to go it alone 
6207 Collective farms will last for the next few years because most private farms now only produce enough to feed themselves with maybe a little extra to sell said one private farmer In the future maybe but it 's better not to hurry 
6208 Collectivisation brought us a lot of pain 
6209 And it went too fast 
6210 Privatising too quickly can also have a negative outcome 
6211 Gencor swells profit despite setbacks 
6212 Melanie Cheary 
6213 JOHANNESBURG 1996-08-26 
6214 Gencor Ltd on Monday said it had swelled its year attributable profit and streamlined operations to strengthen it for the current financial year despite a variety of divisional setbacks 
6215 Announcing the group 's results for the year ended June 30 chairman Brian Gilbertson said Happily the strong improvement in financial performance is not an illusion arising from the recent weakness of the rand relative to the dollar 
6216 Gencor raised attributable earnings to 1,803 million rand from 1,003 million rand previously in dollar terms an increase to $ 469 million from $ 279 million and won despite the group 's Impala Platinum Holdings Ltd posting dismal results 
6217 Not everything has gone well 
6218 We 've had substantial production difficulties at a number of our operations 
6219 The most obvious one with the greatest effect on the corporation was at Impala where we had the furnace failure Gilbertson said 
6220 Implats posted year attributable profit of 176 million rand from 281 million previously 
6221 Not only did the company lock in 3.92 rand per dollar in February March but it suffered output losses due to a furnace shutdown last August 
6222 The rand was last bid at 4.5350 against the dollar 
6223 Nor was Implats the only operation to fail output targets 
6224 Ingwe Coal Corporation Ltd was hit hard by heavy rains 
6225 It forfeited nearly one million tonnes of production to flooding at its mines in Mpumulanga province 
6226 But Gilbertson said the greatest gloom in the year came from the European Commission 's blocking of Implats proposed merger with Lonrho Plc 's platinum interests 
6227 The big disappointment for the year was the failure of the platinum merger 
6228 From Gencor 's perspective we are taking the position that it is not on Gilbertson said 
6229 Looking ahead to the current financial year he said that Gencor would boost earnings further 
6230 Gencor is well placed to take up the challenges of the future 
6231 The group is soundly structured and prudently financed and is blessed with an excellent portfolio of world-class businesses 
6232 I think we can look forward to further growth 
6233 Citing the disposal of Gencor 's stake in industrial holdings group Malbak Ltd for one billion rand among other smaller disposals Gilbertson said Gencor had pruned its portfolio to concentrate on core assets 
6234 We 've tried to clean up our overall portfolio by disposing of non-core assets 
6235 The biggest of those was Malbak 
6236 Overall a very substantial pruning 
6237 leaving Gencor clearly structured along commodity lines Gilbertson said 
6238 He added that the group still had about 85 million rand after tax invested in various shares which were market for disposal when required 
6239 Referring to Gencor 's increased 41.5 percent stake in Ingwe Gilbertson said the group would wait for coal shares to be cheaper before considering snapping up more 
6240 I think we would have liked to have more of Ingwe but it 's the question of adding value 
6241 When we bought the shares we bought 
6242 at quite a bit lower than the price is now 
6243 maybe if we just wait another few years for the next downturn in coal 
6244 Finally Gilbertson said a growing proportion of Gencor 's income was coming from offshore and unlisted investments 
6245 Johannesburg newsroom +27 11 482-1003 
6246 Advanced Medical buying IVAC Medical 
6247 SAN DIEGO 1996-08-26 
6248 Advanced Medical Inc. said Monday it will buy IVAC Medical Systems Inc. a former Eli Lilly & Co 
6249 unit for about $ 400 million in cash creating one of the world 's largest makers of intravenous infusion therapy products 
6250 Under the agreement IVAC and Advanced Medical 's wholly owned subsidiary IMED Corp. will merge to form a new company that will develop and manufacture infusion pumps that regulate the amount of intravenous fluid being administered to a patient as well as proprietary disposable products 
6251 The combined company will have estimated revenues of $ 353 million 
6252 Advanced Medical through IMED is already one of the nation 's largest developers and manufacturers of intravenous infusion pumps and proprietary disposable products 
6253 It has sales in 38 foreign countries 
6254 San Diego-based IVAC is a major provider of infusion systems and related technologies to the health-care industry 
6255 It has manufacturing plants in San Diego ; Creedmoor N.C. ; Hampshire England ; and Tijuana Mexico and distributes its prodcuts in more than 120 countries 
6256 Eli Lilly sold IVAC on Dec. 31 1994 to DLJ Merchant Banking Partners LP River Medical Inc. and other investors 
6257 Advanced Medical said it expects to take an unspecified one-time charge to pay for the merger 
6258 It did not say when the charge would be taken 
6259 The addition of IVAC is expected to contribute to financial results in the full second quarter of 1997 the companies said 
6260 The merger will add to both companies historical leadership in infusion therapy and technology-based drug delivery devices they said 
6261 In 1968 IVAC introduced the world 's first infusion therapy monitoring device 
6262 A year later IVAC improved its system with the addition of an IV pump that regulated the flow of liquids through positive pressure 
6263 IMED introduced the world 's first volumetric infusion pump in 1974 
6264 IMED had profits of $ 1.7 million or 6 cents per fully diluted common share on $ 53.9 million in revenues in the first half of 1996 
6265 Excluding the effect of a one-time restructuring charge of $ 17.4 million IVAC had net income of $ 4.2 million on net sales of $ 112.8 million for the 1996 first half 
6266 Advanced Medical reported profits of $ 8.4 million on sales of $ 29.2 million in the quarter ended June 30 
6267 William J. Mercer IVAC president and chief executive officer will become the president and CEO of Advanced Medical 
6268 He led the transition of IVAC to a privately held company and was previously senior vice president at Mallinckrodt Group Inc 
6269 Joseph Kuhn Advanced Medical and IMED president will become the new company 's executive vice president and chief financial officer 
6270 The deal is expected to close by the first quarter of 1997 subject to regulatory approval 
6271 It has already been approved by both companies boards 
6272 Dow rises on Philip Morris other stocks lower 
6273 NEW YORK 1996-08-26 
6274 The Dow Jones industrial average opened slightly higher on Monday boosted by Philip Morris which gained four to 92 
6275 Other shares were slightly lower mirroring bonds 
6276 The Dow was up eight to 5,731 while the NASDAQ Index was off fractionally to 1,143 and the S&P Index down one to 666 
6277 New York Stock Exchange advances lagged declines by 476/698 while NASDAQ advances led declines 837/763 
6278 The 30-year U.S. Treasury bond was off 2/32 to yield 6.96 percent 
6279 RUGBY LEAGUE ST HELENS CLINCH SUPER LEAGUE TITLE 
6280 ST HELENS England 1996-08-26 
6281 St Helens completed their first league and Challenge Cup double in 30 years on Monday when they thrashed Warrington 66-14 to clinch the inaugural Super League title 
6282 St Helens secured the two points they needed in the last game of the season at Knowsley Road to win their first championship since 1975 and their first double since 1966 
6283 In rain-soaked conditions centre Alan Hunte grabbed a hat-trick of tries while Tommy Martyn Anthony Sullivan and Paul Newlove each scored two 
6284 Captain and goalkicker Bobbie Goulding scored 18 points 
6285 St Helens 's triumph marked the end of Wigan 's seven-year reign as British champions 
6286 St Helens needed to win on Monday to take the title a defeat or draw would have allowed Wigan their eighth consecutive championship 
6287 They were also the toast of London Broncos who managed to scrape into the top four ahead of Warrington and qualify for the end-of-season play-offs 
6288 Bradford finished third 
6289 St Helens have now set their sights on taking the treble by winning the end-of-season premiership which begins with next Sunday 's semifinal against London

6305 RALLYING MAKINEN STEPS UP TITLE BID WITH LAKES WIN 
6306 JYVASKYLA Finland 1996-08-26 
6307 Tommi Makinen took a significant step towards becoming world rally champion with a brilliant victory in the 1000 Lakes Rally on Monday 
6308 Mitsubishi driver Makinen stopped experienced fellow Finn Juha Kankkunen in his tracks on the final day of the 1,452-km rally doubling his lead on the first two decisive stages 
6309 This was the most difficult win three days at 125 percent effort said Makinen whose success completed his 1,000 Lakes hat-trick 
6310 Kankkunen was runner-up in his Toyota as Finland 's Jarmo Kytolehto produced a remarkable drive to finish third in his Ford 
6311 Swede Kenneth Eriksson kept Subaru in the hunt for the manufacturers title with fifth place in spite of a gearbox problem that nearly forced him off the road close to the end of the event 
6312 Maakinen 's and Mitsubishi 's positions were strengthened by the late retirement of Spain 's Carlos Sainz when his Ford gearbox failed 
6313 Makinen with 95 points now leads his nearest championship rival Sainz by 32 points 
6314 RALLYING MAKINEN WINS 1,000 LAKES RALLY 
6315 JYVASKYLA Finland 1996-08-26 
6316 Tommi Makinen of Finland driving a Mitsubishi on Monday won the 1,000 Lakes Rally sixth round of the world championship 
6317 SOCCER SHARPE HITS WINNER TO EASE PRESSURE ON LEEDS 
6318 LEEDS England 1996-08-26 
6319 Winger Lee Sharpe hit a superb strike from the edge of the penalty area to give Leeds their first win of the season on Monday and leave hapless Wimbledon anchored at the bottom of the England premier league 
6320 Sharpe repaid a huge slice of the 4.5 million pound $ 6.98 million fee Leeds handed Manchester United for his services with a top-draw second-half goal to hand Wimbledon their third successive defeat 
6321 Ian Rush the Welsh striker signed from Liverpool in the close season set up the goal feeding Sharpe as he galloped forward and the former England winger cut inside onto his unfavoured right foot to arc a shot into the right-hand corner of the net 
6322 The only goal of the match also brought some relief for under-fire Leeds manager Howard Wilkinson following the team 's poor start to the season 
6323 Home fans frequently booed their own side until Sharpe turned the jeers to cheers

6559 SOCCER SEYCHELLES FAIL IN BID FOR HISTORIC VICTORY 
6560 Mark Gleeson 
6561 JOHANNESBURG 1996-08-26 
6562 The tiny islands of the Seychelles failed to make soccer history at the weekend when they bowed out of the preliminary rounds of the African Nations Cup 
6563 Trailing fellow Indian Ocean islanders Mauritius 1-0 from the first leg they were held to a 1-1 draw at home on Saturday despite playing against 10 men for most of the match 
6564 The 2-1 aggregate took Mauritius into the group phase of the qualifiers for the 1998 finals and kept up the Seychelles record of never having won an official match in their 10 years of FIFA membership 
6565 The Seychelles must have thought they were on course for a historic breakthrough when Mauritian midfielder Andre Caboche was sent off for a crude tackle in the 19th minute 
6566 But the visitors responded to the setback immediately veteran striker Ashley Mocude scoring a minute later to give them a two-goal aggregate lead 
6567 Although Danny Rose 's 50th-minute equaliser gave the Seychellois renewed hope they could not find the net again and were eliminated 
6568 Mauritius now play in group seven of the qualifiers against Malawi Mozambique and favourites Zambia 
6569 Namibia who drew 0-0 with Botswana in their first leg won the second leg in Windhoek 6-0 to stretch their unbeaten run to eight matches and continue their remarkable progress on the African soccer stage 
6570 They now play in group five with Cameroon Gabon and Kenya 
6571 German-based striker Bachirou Salou returned home to Togo to score the decisive only goal of their tie against Congo 
6572 Salou who plays for MSV Duisburg in the Bundesliga scored in the 53rd minute of Sunday 's match in Lome for a 1-0 aggregate win which takes his side into group six where they will meet Liberia Tanzania and Zaire 
6573 Ethiopia needed a penalty shoot-out in Addis Ababa to overcome Uganda after a 2-2 aggregate scoreline 
6574 Both legs ended 1-1 before Ethiopia won the spot kick decider 4-2 
6575 Uganda 's elimination follows their humiliating 5-1 aggregate defeat by Angola in June 's World Cup qualifying preliminaries 
6576 The other preliminary round second leg match between Mauritania and Benin in Nouakchott was postponed until Friday 
6577 Benin won the first leg 4-1

6623 SWIMMING POPOV IN `SERIOUS CONDITION AFTER STABBING 
6624 MOSCOW 1996-08-26 
6625 Russian double Olympic swimming champion Alexander Popov was in a serious condition on Monday after being stabbed on a Moscow street 
6626 A doctor said it was too early to say whether Popov the only man to retain the Olympic 50 and 100 metres freestyle titles would return to top-level sport 
6627 His condition is serious said Rimma Maslova deputy chief doctor of Hospital No 31 in the Russian capital 
6628 But he is conscious and is talking and smiling 
6629 Maslova told Reuters she was not an expert in sports medicine but said it was too early to judge Popov 's chances of returning to competitive swimming 
6630 Popov who won gold in the 50 and 100 metres freestyle at the recent Atlanta Olympics was stabbed in the abdomen late on Saturday after an argument with a group of roadside watermelon sellers in south-west Moscow 
6631 Maslova said the wound had affected a lung and a kidney 
6632 Doctors operated on Popov 24 for three hours 
6633 Popov told NTV television on Sunday he was in no danger and promised he would be back in the pool shortly 
6634 There 's no need to worry 
6635 We 're going to be walking soon and swimming he insisted cheerfully from his bed in the intensive care unit 
6636 Interfax news agency said police had detained one of the attackers 
6637 It said the row started when Popov and a group of his friends were returning from a party 
6638 Vitaly Smirnov president of the Russian National Olympic Committee said President Boris Yeltsin had given the swimmer Russia 's top award for his Olympic performance 
6639 I am not a doctor but I think he is doing all right said Smirnov 
6640 Smirnov said the Olympic Committee might ask the government to take measures to protect the country 's best athletes some of whom have already chosen to live abroad for fear of a surge in crime in post-Soviet Russia

6771 SOCCER PLAYERS LEAVE MATCH EARLY TO CATCH PLANE 
6772 Brian Homewood 
6773 RIO DE JANEIRO 1996-08-26 
6774 Two key players left a Brazilian championship match early on Sunday because they had to catch a plane to Russia to play with the national team 
6775 Sao Paulo midfielder Andre and Santos defender Narciso were both substituted during their teams game taken to Sao Paulo airport and flown to Rio de Janeiro in a private jet chartered by the Brazilian Football Confederation CBF 
6776 At Rio they joined up with the national team squad for the journey to Moscow where Brazil will face Russia in a friendly international on Wednesday 
6777 The problem arose because the Sao Paulo-Santos clash was selected as the day 's televised live match forcing it to be put back three hours from the usual kickoff time 
6778 Santos suffered more from their loss as Narciso 's replacement Jean gave away a penalty from which Sao Paulo scored the decisive goal in a 2-1 win 
6779 Sao Paulo lead the first stage of the championship on goal difference from surprise package Juventude who beat Internacional 2-1 
6780 Corinthians who played in a tournament in Spain last week also faced a plane marathon as they attempted to keep up with a hectic fixture list 
6781 They were due to leave Spain Monday night arrive in Sao Paulo on Tuesday morning catch another plane to the southern city of Curitiba one hour later and then play away to Atletico Paranaense in the Brazilian championship the same evening 
6782 Botafogo striker Tulio who was overlooked by Zagalo for the tour which also features a game away to the Netherlands on Sunday scored his third goal in three games as the defending champions beat Bahia 2-1 away 
6783 Tulio who has been top-scorer in the competition for the last two seasons has been struggling against injury for most of this year

6907 TENNIS QUENCH YOUR THIRST IF YOU CAN AFFORD IT AT U.S. OPEN 
6908 Bill Berkrot 
6909 NEW YORK 1996-08-26 
6910 A message on television monitors all around the National Tennis Centre reads Due to hot weather please seek shade and drink plenty of fluids sound advice until you check out the price of fluids 
6911 Perhaps the advisory was cut off before concluding ...and bring plenty of money 
6912 A small bottle of a garishly-coloured sports drink at the sun-drenched U.S. Open is going for $ 3.75 while a litre of basic life-sustaining water will set you back $ 4.00 for water ? 
6913 At the Olympics water was only a dollar and that was the Olympics said one incredulous fan noting that the Atlanta Games had been notorious for price gouging 
6914 U.S. Open officials managed to insult most of the male tennis players last week with their controversial handling of the seeding and draw 
6915 When the tournament began on Monday it was the fans turn to be offended 
6916 That baked lasagna better be good for $ 8.50 said New Yorker Rebecca Weinstein a U.S. Open regular who was eating a sandwich she had brought from home 
6917 A trio of hungry fans at the food court who had already forked over the lasagna money pronounced it good but Carol Perry chimed in The water is ridiculous they want four dollars for the water you might as well get a glass of wine 
6918 Indeed a nice glass of chardonnay or white zinfandel was going for $ 4.75 while an imported beer was just a bit more than the water at $ 4.50 
6919 What 's the message here ? 
6920 Maybe they want us to be alcoholics Perry joked before lifting her glass of wine 
6921 Fans will be shelling out $ 12.50 for a hamburger and a large french fries 
6922 And that little snack is guaranteed to make you thirsty 
6923 Make that $ 16.50 
6924 Even a sandwich as pedestrian as a ham and swiss cheese is going for a whopping $ 8.00 
6925 Of course it is served on a tuscan roll 
6926 It must be the cost of flying those rolls over from Tuscany every day that drives up the price of the sandwich 
6927 TENNIS HUBER AND MALEEVA FALL UP-AND-COMERS ADVANCE AT OPEN 
6928 Larry Fine 
6929 NEW YORK 1996-08-26 
6930 Martina Hingis led a youthful charge and Australian Open finalist Anke Huber and Magdalena Maleeva were fallen seeds on Monday in a hot sunny opening to the U.S. Open tennis championships 
6931 The 15-year-old Hingis seeded 16th was honoured to play the first match of the season 's last Grand Slam on Stadium Court but happy to hurry off with a straight-sets victory over the 112th-ranked Angeles Montolio of Spain 
6932 It was very hot and I did n't want to stay long on the court said a cheery Hingis who had no worries in racing to a 6-1 6-0 victory against the overmatched Spaniard 
6933 Hoping for a longer engagement on the cement at Flushing Meadows were the sixth-seeded Huber of Germany and 12th seed Maleeva of Bulgaria 
6934 Huber who lost to Monica Seles in the Australian Open final fell victim to an unfortunate draw in bowing to dangerous floater Amanda Coetzer of South Africa 
6935 Coetzer ranked 17th avenged her defeat to Huber in the Australian Open semifinals by winning 6-1 2-6 6-2 
6936 I looked at it as not a first round match just a great challenge for me said Coetzer 24 
6937 I was really concentrating on keeping my own momentum and my own rhythm 
6938 She is tough to play in that way because she plays very up and down 
6939 She played one great game and than a few errors 
6940 The challenge was just for me to keep playing my own game 
6941 Huber who reached the final a week ago at Manhattan Beach could only mourn her luck of the draw 
6942 I was n't happy when I saw the draw 
6943 She was the first non- seeded player said the 21-year-old German 
6944 It 's always tough to play somebody like that in the first round in a Grand Slam 
6945 I think I did n't play that bad today 
6946 It was maybe my best first round match in a Grand Slam I ever played 
6947 Monday brought the best out in U.S. Open rookie Aleksandra Olsza of Poland ranked 110th 
6948 The 18-year-old Olsza last year 's Wimbledon junior champion celebrated her debut in the main draw of the Open by removing Maleeva 6-4 6-2 
6949 The curtain-raising victories by Hingis and Olsza provided a ringing endorsement for the newest wave of women 's players coming up from the junior ranks 
6950 The Swiss teenager a twice French Open junior champion and a Wimbledon juniors winner had already proven her main stage mettle by reaching the quarters at this year 's Australian Open 
6951 I hope I can get into the last 16 said Hingis seeded to face third seed Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in the fourth round 
6952 Hingis has been working hard on conditioning and has lost eight pounds 3.5 kilos in advance of the championships 
6953 There will be tough matches but I hope I can get there she said 
6954 Then we 'll see if Arantxa will be there too 
6955 The fast-moving Olsza 18 was cool in her opening match 
6956 I was n't scared when I heard that I was playing Maleeva said Olsza 
6957 I know that if I want to play professional tennis I have to do my best to try to beat her and I ca n't be scared 
6958 Olsza is undaunted by the level of competition in the pros 
6959 In terms of tennis I think the junior players are really good now 
6960 In a few years it could change a lot among the top players 
6961 Two big-serving women 's players made quick work of Japanese opponents 
6962 Brenda Schultz-McCarthy of the Netherlands the 13th seed was a 6-1 6-4 winner over Japan 's Nana Miyaga while Czech veteran Helena Sukova prevailed over Yone Kamio 6-2 6-3 
6963 Austrian Barbara Paulus seeded 14th also reached the second round with a 6-2 6-1 victory over Yi Jing-Qian of China 
6964 TENNIS STICH GLAD HE STAYED AFTER OPEN VICTORY 
6965 Richard Finn 
6966 NEW YORK 1996-08-26 
6967 Michael Stich nearly pulled out of the U.S. Open in protest over the men 's seeding fiasco but the former Wimbledon champion was glad he stayed after sweating out a four-set win on Monday over qualifier Tommy Haas 
6968 I still feel it 's embarrassing what happened and I was about to pull out yesterday and say That 's it said Stich one of a host of men who cried foul over seeding procedures that forced an unprecedented remaking of the men 's draw last week 
6969 But there are so many reasons to play especially spectators and the kids who come out here and want to enjoy watching tennis that I decided to stay 
6970 In a break from tradition the Open did not seed in strict accordance with ATP rankings instead taking into account other factors that raised objections of favourtism toward U.S. players 
6971 One prominent player that did not stay for the Open was French Open champion Yvegeny Kafelnikov who after being dropped three spots from his ATP ranking to a seventh seeding withdrew and returned home to Russia 
6972 Kafelnikov had pulled out of last week 's tournament with a rib injury 
6973 At a news conference attended by approximately 50 players on Sunday U.S. Davis Cup player Todd Martin expressed the players outrage at the seedings 
6974 The way the U.S. Open has seeded here tampering with the ranking system has tarnished the image and reputation of this U.S. Open in the players mind and we think that is damaging to our sport Martin said 
6975 Stich said he felt the players ought to have organised an active protest 
6976 I feel that we made it a little easy for the USTA 
6977 They did n't really get hurt as much as I think they should have said Stich 
6978 I feel that we should have maybe just cancelled out the Monday not show up today and start the tournament tomorrow 
6979 But once the 27-year-old Stich got on the court he focused his energies on trying to win the year 's last Grand Slam 
6980 He took a positive first step with his 6-3 1-6 6-1 7-5 win over compatriot Haas on a sun-baked Grandstand court 
6981 Others advancing early on Monday included 11th-seeded American Malivai Washington the Wimbledon runner-up Sweden 's Magnus Gustafsson and two-time former French Open champion Sergi Bruguera of Spain who will be Stich 's next opponent 
6982 The suspicion however lingers in Stich 's mind that U.S. Open officials did tamper with the seeding process in order to benefit homegrown players 
6983 I get the feeling that everything is done here for the American players and they forget about all the other players said Stich who lost the 1994 Open final to Andre Agassi 
6984 It was Agassi who was at the centre of the controversy that engulfed the tournament since the original draw was completed on Wednesday 
6985 The flamboyant American star was bumped up two spots from his ATP ranking of eight to a seeding of six 
6986 He Agassi should be seeded the way he is playing tennis right now said Stich about the unfairness of moving up Agassi who made early exits from the French Open and Wimbledon 
6987 Stich not seeded here for the first time since 1990 might have benefitted from some fiddling with the seedings himself after Kafelnikov withdrew 
6988 Ranked 18th in the world Stich might have been slipped into that spot ahead of Spain 's Felix Mantilla who is 16th but had never been played in the Open and had been left out of the seedings originally 
6989 But Stich did n't want to play that game 
6990 I think he deserves to be seeded as everybody else who is in the top 16 deserves to be seeded Stich said

7055 BASEBALL CUBS EDGE BRAVES WITH RUN IN TOP OF NINTH 
7056 ATLANTA 1996-08-25 
7057 Brian McRae singled in Tyler Houston in the top of the ninth inning to snap a tie as the Chicago Cubs avoided a three-game sweep with 3-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves on Sunday 
7058 The Braves scored four runs in the ninth for a 6-5 victory on Saturday 
7059 Kevin Foster 5-2 won his second straight start allowing two runs and six hits with two walks and three strikeouts over eight innings 
7060 The biggest thing was my fastball I was able to rotate it pretty good Foster said 
7061 Also I was able to keep my changeup down 
7062 At Colorado Vinny Castilla homered twice and drove in four runs and Larry Walker went 3-for-4 with a homer and three RBI as the Colorado Rockies outslugged the Pittsburgh Pirates 13-9 in the rubber game of a three-game series 
7063 Castilla 's first homer of the game a solo shot in the seventh off reliever Marc Wilkins 3-1 extended Colorado 's lead to 9-7 
7064 He added a three-run homer in the eighth off John Ericks to make it 13-8 
7065 At Florida Edgar Renteria 's two-out single in the bottom of the ninth inning scored Jesus Tavarez with the winning run as the Florida Marlins edged the Cincinnati Reds 6-5 
7066 Right after Edgar made contact I knew I had to score said Tavarez 
7067 I knew I would score even if he fielded it cleanly he could n't throw me out 
7068 Edgar is a tremendous player right now said Florida manager John Boles 
7069 But I ca n't wait to see how good he 'll be when he grows up 
7070 In San Francisco Osvaldo Fenandez fired a seven-hitter and Trenidad Hubbard belted a two-run homer as the San Francisco Giants ended a three-game losing streak by defeating the Montreal Expos 7-2 
7071 Fernandez 6-13 allowed two runs walked one and struck out eight for his second career complete game both against Montreal 
7072 In Los Angeles Greg Gagne had a run-scoring single and Chad Curtis drew a bases-loaded walk in the bottom of the eighth inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers rallied for a 6-5 victory and a three-game sweep of the New York Mets 
7073 It was one of these games where you get three straight pinch-hits and a walk of a pinch-hitter that 's how you win pennants Dodgers manager Bill Russell said 
7074 Mike Piazza 
7075 In San Diego Steve Finley and Jody Reed drove in three runs apiece as the San Diego Padres built a six-run lead after three innings and cruised to an 11-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies 
7076 Ken Caminiti added two RBI for the Padres who have won six of their last seven games and remained one game ahead of the Los Angeles Dodgers in the National League West 
7077 In Houston Jeff Bagwell homered and Donne Wall allowed one run over seven innings as the Houston Astros defeated the St. Louis Cardinals 4-1 
7078 Wall 8-4 allowed three hits walked two and struck out seven as the Astros moved 1-1/2 games ahead of the Cardinals for the lead in the National League Central 
7079 He left the game with a knot in his right shoulder
