7134 BASEBALL BONDS CONSECUTIVE GAME STREAK ENDS 
7135 SAN FRANCISCO 1996-08-25 
7136 San Francisco Giants All-Star left fielder Barry Bonds did not appear in Sunday 's 7-2 victory over the Montreal Expos ending his consecutive games streak 
7137 After appearing as a pinch-hitter in the previous two games Bonds who has been battling a hamstring injury did not see any action today ending his streak at 357 consecutive games 
7138 It was the second-longest streak by an active player in the the majors behind Baltimore 's Cal Ripken who appeared in his major-league record 2,282nd straight game today a 13-0 loss to the California Angels 
7139 Bonds has been limited to a pinch-hitting role since an MRI Friday showed a mild strain of his left hamstring 
7140 Bonds came out of Wednesday 's game against New York in the ninth inning after suffering a mild hamstring strain 
7141 He was back in the starting lineup Thursday night and went 1-for-2 before exiting in the third inning 
7142 The 32-year-old Bonds is hitting .307 with 35 homers and 107 RBI and has been one of the few bright spots for the last-place Giants 
7143 Chicago Cubs outfielder Sammy Sosa had the third-longest streak at 304 games but that ended earlier this week when he suffered a broken bone in his right hand 
7144 Atlanta Braves first baseman Fred McGriff owns the second-longest streak at 295 games 
7145 SOCCER JONK RETURNS TO DUTCH SQUAD FOR BRAZIL FRIENDLY 
7146 ROTTERDAM 1996-08-26 
7147 Dutch coach Guus Hiddink on Monday recalled midfielder Wim Jonk after a 14-month absence for a friendly against World Cup holders Brazil in Amsterdam on Sunday 
7148 Feyenoord midfielder Jean-Paul van Gastel was also named to make his debut in the 18-man squad 
7149 Hiddink did not name a replacement captain for Danny Blind who announced his retirement from international soccer on Sunday 
7150 Ronald de Boer and Dennis Bergkamp are the likely contenders to lead the team 
7151 The 35-year-old Blind who won 42 caps for the Netherlands said he wanted to concentrate on playing for his Dutch club Ajax Amsterdam 
7152 AC Milan midfielder Edgar Davids who was sent home early from the European championship in England after a clash with the coach was left out of the squad

7242 Lamonts Apparel files reorganization plan 
7243 [ CORRECTED 18:00 GMT ] 
7244 KIRKLAND Wash 
7245 1996-08-26 
7246 Lamonts Apparel Inc an operator of 42 family apparel stores in six northwestern states said it has filed a reorganization plan in bankruptcy court in Seattle 
7247 Corrects to make clear a reorganization plan has been filed 
7248 The reorganization plan calls for all secured claims to be paid in full 
7249 Unsecured claims including those of company bondholders will be satisfied by issuing new common stock and warrants 
7250 Unsecured claims are estimated at about $ 90 million 
7251 Lamonts said it plans to issue 9 million shares of new common stock 
7252 Of that amount 4.05 million and 5.67 million shares will be allocated to the company 's trade creditors 
7253 Between 4.75 and 3.13 million shares will be allocated to bondholders and other unsecured non-trade creditors and 200,000 will be allocated to existing shareholders in exchange for all existing stock of the company 
7254 Bondholders and other unsecured non-trade creditors will receive warrants four about 2.2 million shares when the company 's market capitalization reaches $ 20 million 
7255 Bondholders other unsecured non-trade creditors and existing shareholders also will receive warrants entitling them to roughly 800,000 shares when the company 's market capitalization reaches $ 25 million 
7256 Management will receive options to purchase 10 percent of the company 's outstanding common stock with protection against dilution at an option exercise price of $ 1 million 
7257 Passengers rescued from blazing ferry off France 
7258 LONDON 1996-08-26 
7259 More than 100 people were safely evacuated on Monday from a ferry that caught fire soon after leaving Guernsey in Britain 's Channel Islands police said 
7260 Police said the 111 passengers and six crew on board the ferry Trident Seven owned by France 's Emeraud line were rescued by a variety of private and commercial boats after fire broke out in the engine room soon after it left port 
7261 An 88-year-old woman was taken to hospital with leg injuries according to a spokesman for Guernsey police 
7262 The ferry which was towed into port had been bound for Jersey another in a cluster of small British-ruled islands off north-west France 
7263 OSCE delays decision on refugee voting 
7264 Kurt Schork 
7265 SARAJEVO 1996-08-26 
7266 Bosnia 's election organisers will decide on Tuesday whether or not to postpone municipal elections scheduled as part of nationwide balloting an OSCE spokeswoman said on Monday 
7267 Officials from the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe OSCE are considering the postponement following allegations of serious irregularities in the registration of Serb refugees 
7268 International observers say the alleged irregularities could affect the outcome of voting for municipal assemblies 
7269 Tomorrow 
7270 the Provisional Election Commission will consider the possible postponement of municipal elections only 
7271 the other elections will be held on September 14 OSCE spokeswoman Agota Kuperman told reporters in Sarajevo 
7272 I think that it would be very difficult to select which municipal elections would have to be cancelled 
7273 I think probably if the decision to cancell were to be taken it would probably be all municipal elections .. 
7274 Kuperman added that options other than postponement were also on the table but she refused to specify what they were 
7275 The Dayton peace agreement gave the OSCE a mandate to organise Bosnian elections 
7276 The Provisional Election Commission is OSCE 's top rule-making body for the poll 
7277 More than 600,000 refugees have registered to vote in 55 countries around the world representing about 20 per cent of Bosnia 's total electorate 
7278 They are due to begin voting on Wednesday August 28 just one day after the PEC is supposed to make its decision 
7279 Balloting inside Bosnia is scheduled for September 14 when citizens are slated to elect municipal and cantonal assemblies separate Moslem-Croat and Serb parliaments a national House of Representatives and a three-man Presidency 
7280 A Sarajevo daily newspaper Dnevi Avaz which is close to Bosnia 's Moslem nationalist SDA party on Monday said the OSCE would postpone the municipal-level elections until the Spring of 1997 because of the refugee registration problems 
7281 SDA has a representative on the Provisional Election Commission 
7282 I do n't know what the source of the Dnevi Avaz report is but it is consistent with what I have heard from western diplomats and from inside the OSCE said an OSCE staff member in Sarajevo who asked not to be named 
7283 The word is that Frowick has decided to postpone municipal elections but that he will wait for one more session of the PEC on Tuesday to take everyone 's temperature on the issue 
7284 Ambassador Robert Frowick an American heads the OSCE mission in Bosnia 
7285 OSCE and independent monitors allege that Serb authorities have systematically discouraged refugees from registering to cast a ballot in the places they lived before the war 
7286 Instead the refugees were said to have been directed by their authorities to vote from strategic towns which had Moslem majorities before the 43-month Bosnian war but which are now underpopulated as a result of ethnic cleansing 
7287 Diplomats explain the purpose of this electoral engineering is to secure Serb control over pivotal towns inside the 49 per cent of Bosnia known as the Serb republic consolidating through the ballot box what was initially taken in war 
7288 The top U.N. refugee official in the Balkans highlighted the voter registration problem on Monday 
7289 Results of the registration for September elections herald a dismal future for multi-ethnicity in Bosia-Hercegovina warned Soren Jessen-Petersen Special Envoy for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees in Former Yugoslavia 
7290 In the run-up to elections nationalistic political leaders are playing the ethnic sectarian card drumming up support within their constituencies by playing on bitter memories or fear 
7291 After truce Lebed faces tougher Chechen problem 
7292 Alastair Macdonald 
7293 MOSCOW 1996-08-26 
7294 Alexander Lebed may finally get to discuss his Chechen peace proposals with Boris Yeltsin on Tuesday after a lost weekend in the region when he was forced to abandon plans to sign a new political treaty with the separatist rebels 
7295 It could be a sobering experience for the Kremlin security chief who just two months after being appointed by the president and two heady weeks after taking charge of the Chechen crisis had promised to wrap up the 20-month war by the weekend 
7296 Despite a mood of compromise in the region after some of the worst fighting of the war Lebed may be just finding out that concluding a long-term settlement somewhere between rebel demands for independence and Moscow 's insistence that Chechnya remain part of Russia will be no easy matter 
7297 A chain-smoking former paratroop general with a sharp line in deadpan putdowns and a soldier 's knack for making life sound simple Lebed managed to arrange an ambitious ceasefire in the region last week days after the Russian army threatened to bomb its way back into the rebel-held Chechen capital Grozny 
7298 He returned at the weekend pledging to conclude a political settlement that would make this truce work where all others have failed 
7299 But then he apparently thought better of it 
7300 Saying he needed to tidy up legal loose ends on the deal and also cover his back against unnamed pro-war schemers in Moscow he flew back to the capital empty-handed on Sunday 
7301 He met Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin on Monday and according to the press service of Lebed 's Security Council could meet Yeltsin on Tuesday 
7302 It was not clear if the start of Yeltsin 's holiday announced later would affect plans to talk 
7303 Moscow 's as yet undisclosed proposals on Chechnya 's political future have meanwhile been sent back to do the rounds of various government departments 
7304 It is not known what caused the delay in the peace plan 
7305 Speculation mounted last week that Lebed was operating out on a limb in Chechnya as Yeltsin hardly seen since his reelection last month kept out of sight and then gave an interview criticising his envoy just as he clinched a truce 
7306 But Chernomyrdin took pains at the weekend to insist Lebed was playing for a united team and that the proposals he took to rebel chief-of-staff Aslan Maskhadov had been agreed by Yeltsin 
7307 If that were the case it was unclear why Lebed suddenly found it necessary to have the deal verified in Moscow 
7308 Lebed himself said he was concerned that powerful interests in Moscow who have profited from the war and want it to go on would seize on any inadequacy in the deal to remove him 
7309 Maskhadov warned that Lebed risked the same fate as a former Russian army commander in the region who sought a compromise and was blown up last year by so the Chechens say Russian forces 
7310 Maskhadov may also have made new demands on Lebed forcing him to check back with the Kremlin on what he could offer 
7311 A rebel spokesman said the two military men had come close to agreement on a face-saving formula acceptable to both sides and involving a referendum on independence at some future date 
7312 Chernomyrdin said voters should decide Chechnya 's future but stressed there was no question of the government letting the region quit the Russian Federation something Moscow fears could encourage separatist tendencies in other ethnic regions particularly in the strategic North Caucasus 
7313 Lebed may be be finding that closing that political gap between the two sides is more difficult than just ending a war 
7314 Yeltsin on holiday from Monday Interfax 
7315 MOSCOW 1996-08-26 
7316 Russian President Boris Yeltsin began a new summer holiday on Monday but would remain in control of affairs of state Interfax news agency said 
7317 The head of state 's holiday has only just begun the agency quoted Sergei Yastrzhembsky as saying adding that the president was currently in a Kremlin residence near Moscow 
7318 Interfax said Yastrezhembsky did not exclude that Yeltsin could spend some time in other places 
7319 He would continue working on various documents and might meet one state offical or another 
7320 One must give B. Yeltsin a chance to rest and recover his health after the elections Interfax quoted Yastrezhembsky as saying 
7321 Yeltsin controls internal and international policies daily receives a big packet of documents from Moscow which demand his intervention 
7322 Many of those documents return to the president 's administration the same day he said 
7323 Yeltsin went on a two-day trip outside Moscow last week to check out a holiday home 
7324 Yugo Zastava workers protest enters 2nd week 
7325 BELGRADE 1996-08-26 
7326 Thousands of workers of Serbia 's Zastava arms factory entered the second week of protests on Monday over unpaid wages and the lack of a programme to revive the plant 's production 
7327 We are stubborn have strength and time to persist until our demands are met said the factory 's trade union secretary Dragutin Stanojlovic 
7328 We are united and we are waiting for the government to decide what to do with us 
7329 Trade unions demanded payment of June and July wages and last year 's holiday pay and called on government to develop a revival programme for the plant 
7330 The former Yugoslav national army consumed 90 percent of Zastava 's pre-war output but like the rest of Yugoslavia 's economy the new army of Serbia and Montenegro is crippled by lack of funds 
7331 In Kragujevac where the plant is based 9,000 to 10,000 people gathered in the central square to express their bitterness at what Stanojlovic called government indifference 
7332 The ruling Socialist Party last week accused Serbia 's opposition of stirring up social unrest and using workers already difficult social position for their own interests 
7333 Late wages no work and the lack of a production programme are the main reasons for their protests a senior member of the local Socialist Party branch told Reuters 
7334 But there is a significant influence of opposition parties that are collecting points ahead of coming elections 
7335 Federal Yugoslav elections are due on November 3 
7336 The party official said the union 's figure on the number of protesters was exaggerated 
7337 There were about 1,400 to 1,600 people at the protest today much less then last week 
7338 But there were more observers and passers by he said 
7339 Gordana Kukic Belgrade Newsroom +381 11 222 4254 
7340 Croatian lending rate falls to 8.0 vs 9.1 pct 
7341 ZAGREB 1996-08-26 
7342 The Croatian lending rate fell to 8.0 percent on Monday from last Friday 's 9.1 percent after thin demand for kuna forced bank lenders to trim their rates further 
7343 Interbank call money was down to 8.0 from 10.0 percent 
7344 Insurers five-10 and 10-15 day loans were made at a steady 8.0 percent after last week 's drop from an earlier 15 percent 
7345 Total Zagreb Money Market settlements shrank to 17.4 million kuna of which dealers put new borrowing at a meagre 5.5 million 
7346 Supply stood at a high 180 million kuna 
7347 Overnight trade at the weekend left a surplus of 1.2 billion kuna on the supply side after 40 million were settled 
7348 Croatia 's central bank again stayed out of the foreign exchange market 
7349 It calculated the kuna midrates for Tuesday 's trade stronger at 5.2420 against the dollar and slightly weaker at 3.5486 against the German mark 
7350 Kolumbina Bencevic Zagreb Newsroom 385-1-4557075 
7351 SVCD Bulgaria air traffic controllers to strike September 3 
7352 SOFIA 1996-08-26 
7353 Bulgarian air traffic controllers will go on strike on September 3 demanding higher pay the chief of the Bulgarian association of air traffic controllers Bulatka said on Monday 
7354 Stefan Raichev told a news conference the strike by more than half of the 1,380 traffic controllers and technicians would paralyse traffic which has increased by 10 percent since last year 
7355 More than 1,500 planes per day fly over Bulgaria in a strategic location between Europe and the Middle and the Far East Raichev said 
7356 The director general of the air traffic service Valentin Valkov said last Friday that a controllers strike would be illegal 
7357 Valkov said he could not curb the summer charter flights of national carrier Balkan Airlines which carries thousands of foreign tourists to the Bulgarian Black Sea resorts 
7358 But Raichev said it would be discrimination against the other airlines if only Balkan planes were guided in 
7359 Under the law before launching the strike we have to sign an agreement with our employer for a minimal transport servicing of emergency flights Raichev said 
7360 Raichev said a lock-out with military air controllers was impossible as they did not speak English 
7361 The controllers are demanding the monthly wage be increased to $ 1,000 per month from the current $ 230 as well as the resignation of the air traffic service 's management 
7362 They also demand the financial separation of the 350 air controllers from the technical staff 
7363 Liliana Semerdjieva Sofia Newsroom 359-2-84561 
7364 Yeltsin 's wife has kidney operation 
7365 MOSCOW 1996-08-26 
7366 Naina Yeltsin wife of the Russian president has undergone a planned operation on her left kidney and is in a satisfactory condition Itar-Tass news agency said on Monday 
7367 Tass quoted the Kremlin press service as saying the operation took place on Saturday in the Central Clinical Hospital which treats top officials 
7368 Mrs Yeltsin would be released from hospital in a few days 
7369 Doctor Sergei Mironov told Tass Naina was in permanent contact with her husband and two daughters Yelena and Tatyana 
7370 The state of health of Boris Yeltsin who had two heart attacks last year has been the centre of media and market speculation after he won a second term in office in the July 3 election run-off and all but disappeared from the public eye 
7371 A presidential spokesman said on Monday Yeltsin was in Moscow but could give no details about his agenda or whether meetings were planned 
7372 Yeltsin is expected to go on holiday in the near future but officials have not yet said where he will go or when 
7373 Mostostal Z shareholders approve bonds 
7374 WARSAW 1996-08-26 
7375 Shareholders of the Polish construction firm Mostostal Zabrze Holding SA approved a 25- million-zloty five-year convertible issue with a par value of 100 zlotys each the company 's spokesman said on Monday 
7376 Piotr Grabowski told Reuters that a Mostostal extraordinary shareholders meeting on Saturday had decided that the price of the 250,000 bonds would be set as a 10-session average price of Mostostal shares plus a premium 
7377 The premium will be no lower than 15 percent and will be set by management before the issue 
7378 which we expect at the beginning of next year Grabowksi said 
7379 Mostostal based in southern Poland wants to offer the bonds to large investors in a public offering paying an annual coupon of no more than 80 percent of the yield of the benchmark 52-week T-bill 
7380 The firm has signed an agreement with the Polish Development Bank PBR to manage the issue and plans them to be listed on the Warsaw bourse 's bond market 
7381 Grabowski also said shareholders approved the issue of 1.6 million shares for which the bonds could be exchanged a ratio of 6.4 shares per bond 
7382 He also said shareholders approved the issue of 2.6 million new shares two million of which are earmarked for large investors and 600,000 for retail domestic investors 
7383 The price will be determined through book-building 
7384 Mostostal plans to use the proceeds from the issues to add companies to its holding and modernise its plant

7386 Unknown group kidnaps Dutch couple in Costa Rica 
7387 SAN JOSE Costa Rica 1996-08-26 
7388 Kidnappers have seized a Dutch couple who manage a farm in northern Costa Rica and have demanded a $ 1.5 million ransom authorities said on Monday 
7389 Officials said Humberto Hueite Zyrecha and his wife Jetty Kors both 50 were kidnapped late on Saturday or early Sunday 
7390 Col 
7391 Misael Valerio head of border police at the Security Ministry told reporters surveillance of the northern border with Nicaragua has been stepped up to keep the kidnappers from fleeing Costa Rica 
7392 Preliminary reports said the couple were kidnapped on the Altamira farm owned by Dutchman Richard Wisinga at Aguas Zarcas de San Carlos near the Costa Rica-Nicaragua border 
7393 Unconfirmed news reports said a vehicle belonging to them was found abandoned at Santa Maria de Pocosol about 12 miles 20 km north of the site of the abduction 
7394 The reports said authorities found a statement supposedly from the kidnappers in the vehicle addressed to Wisinga and demanding a $ 1.5 million ransom 
7395 Wisinga was believed to be travelling in Europe they said 
7396 A Swiss tourist guide and a German tourist were kidnapped in the same area on New Year 's Day by a group of former Nicaraguan guerrillas 
7397 Regula Susana Siegfried 50 and Nicola Fleuchaus 25 were released after 71 days after a $ 200,000 ransom was paid 
7398 In a bizarre twist Fleuchaus and the leader of the kidnappers Julio Cesar Vega Rojas developed a sentimental attachment during her captivity according to photographs printed in Costa Rican newspapers and court documents including a love letter written by Vega 
7399 Interacciones ups Mexico GDP forecast lowers peso 
7400 MEXICO CITY 1996-08-26 
7401 Interacciones brokerage on Monday raised its forecasts for 1996 gross domestic product growth to 4.3 percent from 3.8 percent but it kept its 1997 projection unchanged at 4.5 percent a statement said 
7402 Economist Alonso Cervera said the revisions were chiefly fueled by stronger than expected growth of 7.2 percent in the second quarter and he forecast an annual GDP rise of 6.1 percent in the third quarter and 4.9 percent in Q4 
7403 The firm also revised down its year-end peso forecast to 7.85-8.15 per dollar from 8.20-8.50 
7404 It forecast an end 1997 peso in the range of 9.20-9.40 
7405 Interacciones kept its 1996 and 1997 inflation forecast unchanged at 26 percent and 20 percent expecting the government 's 1997 inflation target to be around 15 percent 
7406 It bumped up its average interest rate projection in 1997 to 25.8 percent from 23 percent 
7407 Fiscal policy was expected to be loosened a bit in the second half of this year boosting growth without running into a deficit 
7408 Next year the fiscal policy will have less margin of freedom because the government will have to face commitments that it has taken on under different support schemes for the banks debtors and firms the brokerage said

7411 MEXICO CITY 1996-08-26 
7412 A top official of export development bank Bancomext said the peso 's appreciation against the dollar this year has not hurt demand for Mexican exports 
7413 We have a suitable exchange rate 
7414 We have n't felt a drop-off in demand .... 
7415 We have no basis for saying that the exchange rate is affecting exports Rafael Moreno Turrent deputy director general for foreign trade promotion at the bank said at a news conference 
7416 Colombian peso closes lower importers buy dlrs 
7417 BOGOTA 1996-08-26 
7418 Colombia 's peso closed lower at 1,044 after coming under pressure from dollar-buying by importers seeking to meet their commitments abroad interbank dealers said 
7419 It was the second consecutive session that saw the peso which ended at 1,041 Friday close lower 
7420 The dollar 's rise was due to demand from importers who have a lot of wire transfers accumulated one dealer said 
7421 Contributing to the peso 's weakness another dealer said banks who might have sold greenbacks in Monday 's trading appeared to shy away from the market 
7422 This according to the trader was typical of month-end position-squaring and the fact that a stronger U.S. currency helps limit some foreign exchange losses 
7423 Dealers reported 355 trades for a total of $ 142 million and said the peso hit an intra-day high of 1,037 before heading lower into the close 
7424 Juan Guillermo Londono Bogota newsroom 571 610 7944

7430 Nicaraguan president has operation in U.S 
7431 MANAGUA Nicaragua 1996-08-26

7433 Doctors at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore found an inflamation in her spinal column that once treated will free her of chronic pain in her back and one leg that has limited her movement a government statement said 
7434 Chamorro is in good health and according to her doctors will be able to return to Nicaragua next week it said 
7435 Chamorro 66 had complained of lower back pain since a trip to Taiwan in May when pain forced her to go to Taipei University Hospital for an examination 
7436 She suffers from osteoporosis a disease that weakens the bones and has repeatedly flown to Washington for treatment 
7437 She is scheduled to step down in January after a term of nearly seven years

7463 The injured which included a pregnant woman were taken to hospital but were not in a serious condition an ambulance spokesman told Reuters 
7464 A Public Transport Corporation spokesman said the train collided with the truck loaded with concrete pylons in the north Melbourne suburb of Preston just before 8.30 a.m .. 
7465 The train was derailed when a corner of the driver 's compartment caught the rear of the truck the spokesman said 
7466 The truck was overturned spilling its load onto the crossing and careered into the nearby Bell St Station 
7467 Remarkably both the train driver and the truck driver were not injured the rail spokesman said 
7468 It had the potential to be quite a nasty accident

7499 Indonesian rupiah stable in quiet late trading 
7500 JAKARTA 1996-08-26 
7501 The Indonesian rupiah was stable against the dollar in quiet trading on Monday dealers said 
7502 They said volume was thin following a public holiday in Hong Kong and the United Kingdom 
7503 We did n't see anything from Singapore operators either 
7504 It 's a pretty quiet day one foreign bank dealer said 
7505 Spot rupiah was quoted at 2,342.0 42.5 at 0915 GMT unchanged from the opening level 
7506 It was softer in the morning due to relatively ample rupiah liquidity but recovered later 
7507 Tomorrow and today rupiah closed at 2,342.00 42.45 and 2,341.5 42.0 respectively 
7508 Another dealer said operators were reluctant to unload rupiah despite ample conditions due to the month-end factor 
7509 There are two factors which determine the market at present 
7510 The liquidity at month-end and the next court hearing scheduled for Thursday the dealer said 
7511 Megawati Sukarnoputri deposed leader of the Indonesian Democratic Party PDI has sued the government for ousting her as PDI leader 
7512 The central Jakarta court adjourned the case last Thursday for possible out-of-court settlement 
7513 The hearing is due to resume on Thursday 
7514 Megawati 's lawyers said they were still discussing a possible out of court settlement but they was not optimistic an agreement could be reached 
7515 The dealer said this issue remained a factor but its importance to the market seemed to diminish 
7516 He said liquidity would be the main concern for the next few days 
7517 Overnight swap was at 0.45 0.48 and tom next at 0.50 0.55 
7518 One-month swap was at 18.0 18.5 two at 34.0 35.0 three at 52.75 53.50 and six at 106.5 107.0 points

7537 Kurds clash again in Iraq dozens reported dead 
7538 ANKARA 1996-08-26 
7539 Heavy fighting broke out between two rival Kurdish factions in northern Iraq at midnight Sunday and at least 29 people were killed one of the groups said on Monday 
7540 The Kurdistan Democratic Party KDP said the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan PUK had broken the U.S.-brokered ceasefire agreed between the two parties last week 
7541 The factions reached a ceasefire on Friday after a week of fierce fighting which had put an end to a truce agreed a year earlier 
7542 The PUK leadership who pledged to end fighting and cooperate with the latest U.S. initiative started a major military offensive against KDP positions the KDP said in a statement 
7543 It said heavy fighting started at midnight in the region dividing the two warring factions with the PUK aiming to break through to KDP 's headquarters in Salahuddin 
7544 The KDP said 29 PUK fighters were killed in the attack 
7545 It did not provide details of KDP casualties and a PUK spokesman was not immediately available for comment 
7546 The statement said the PUK resumed its attack on Monday morning on KDP positions near Rawandouz and indiscriminately shelled the town of Dayana killing a priest and injuring some civilians 
7547 The fighting has threatened a U.S.-led peace plan to unite the mountainous Kurdish region in northern Iraq against President Saddam Hussein 
7548 A U.S.-led air force has protected Iraqi Kurds against attack from Baghdad since shortly after the Gulf War in 1991

7558 Cairo says several Egyptian militants on the run from death sentences or convictions for violent attacks at home have taken shelter in Britain

7644 Gore presents new image of lead attack dog 
7645 Michael Posner 
7646 CHICAGO 1996-08-26 
7647 No more mild-mannered and meek Al Gore the vice president and likely heir apparent to President Bill Clinton emerged on Monday as the new Democratic attack dog leading a front-line assault on Bob Dole and House Speaker Newt Gingrich 
7648 While Clinton takes a train trip to the Democratic Convention that will renominate him on Wednesday for a second term Gore is the bright star in the convention city now 
7649 Crowds anxiously wait for his appearances thrusting out hands for him to grip as they scream 12 more years a wishful hope to eight years of Gore after a Clinton re-election 
7650 Over a 15-hour span from Sunday evening to Monday morning so many people jammed Gore events that the fire marshal stopped members of Congress reporters and others from entering a pro-Israel rally and a meeting of the New York delegation 
7651 In his appearances the often stiff and wooden Gore seemed transformed into a new energetic gesturing pol as he ripped into Republican presidential nominee Dole and Gingrich who has emerged as the favorite right-wing foil of Democrats 
7652 Gore told a roaring labor rally of about 1,000 union workers that Dole and Gingrich were the virtual personifaction of evil without even mentioning that former Housing Secretary Jack Kemp is Dole 's running mate 
7653 With equal measures of ignorance and audacity this two-headed monster of Dole and Gingrich has been launching an all out assault on decades of progress of behalf of working men and women Gore said to whoops of 12 more years 
7654 They want to drive you out of politics and they ca n't he added 
7655 They want to silence your voices in elections 
7656 At a downtown hotel Monday the 48-year-old Gore gave Wisconsin delegates a taste again of the new Gore 
7657 I want you to ask this question 
7658 What would Wisconsin face if the same extremist coalition the Gingrich Dole Congress also controlled the executive branch ? 
7659 Gore said 
7660 Noting the next presidential term will probably see two or three Supreme Court justice nominations he warned Their extremist agenda would come out of the Gingrich Congress into and through the Dole White House down through the Supreme Court 
7661 He painted a scene of horrors he saw if Republicans controlled the White House and the Congress they hold now 
7662 Our personal and religious liberties would be at risk 
7663 Medicare would be at risk of withering on the vine 
7664 Medicaid would be at risk of being taken away from poor children 
7665 Education would be at risk 
7666 The environment would be at risk from the polluters that control that coalition he said 
7667 His new style mixed an assault on Republicans with what he sees as productive opportunity a vision for the future that lifts up working families that builds Wisconsin stronger that builds America stronger 
7668 With your help we can re-elect Bill Clinton 
7669 Dole 's tax cut plans were called deja-voodoo economics .... It 's a warmed-over plan that failed and drove our economy into a ditch 
7670 We got burned once and we wo n't let that happen to our nation again 
7671 Gore ridiculed Dole 's defense of the tobacco industry praised Clinton for courage in advancing regulations of it 
7672 To the delegates of Wisconsin a leading dairy state Gore had the right audience in poking fun at Dole 's comparison to addiction to tobacco to those who ca n't tolerate milk 
7673 Some people say milk is bad for you Gore said as Wisconsin delegates held aloft a plastic inflated cow 
7674 He praised Clinton for vetoing the Republican Congress attempt to repeal parts of the Clean Air Act and criticized Republicans for slashing money to combat drugs in schools 
7675 The choice has never been starker the stakes today have never been higher Gore said 
7676 We 're not going to let them get away with that 
7677 Actor Reeve highlights Democrats first night 
7678 CHICAGO 1996-08-26 
7679 The highlights of the first day of the Democratic convention on Monday were expected to feature a mix of party leaders and people who have overcome adversity 
7680 Among the latter were gun control advocate Sarah Brady and actor Christopher Reeve and the politicians included Rep 
7681 Richard Gephardt and Sen 
7682 Thomas Daschle 
7683 Here are thumbnail profiles of the convention 's key Monday speakers 
7684 Sarah Brady The nation 's toughest gun control law is named after Ronald Reagan 's press secretary James Brady but it was his wife who was the major force behind its passage 
7685 As head of Handgun Control Inc. Sarah Brady 54 campaigned nonstop for tough gun control in the years following the shooting of her husband and then President Reagan in 1981 
7686 Her reward was the passage in 1993 of the Brady Bill which requires a mandatory five-day waiting period for purchase of handguns and also mandates background checks for would-be gun purchasers 
7687 Reagan recovered fully from his wounds but Brady who was close to death after being shot by John Hinckley Jr 
7688 suffered serious brain damage 
7689 Sarah was Brady 's second wife and they have a son James Scott Brady Jr 
7690 Before the assassination attempt she had worked for Republican congressmen and for the Republican Party 
7691 Christopher Reeve Reeve was best known for playing the comic book hero Superman in four movies but his greatest heroics came in real life 
7692 Reeve an accomplished rider who owned several horses suffered multiple injuries including two shattered neck vertebrae when he was thrown from his horse at an equestrian event in Culpepper Virginia on May 27 1995 
7693 Almost entirely paralyzed Reeve underwent extensive surgery to fuse the vertebrae to the base of the skull and prevent any further damage to his spine 
7694 That allowed him to be moved to a semi-upright position 
7695 Over time he regained the power of speech so much so that he was asked to address the opening night of the Democratic National Convention 
7696 Reeve 43 was classically trained as an actor but became the prototypical handsome leading man 
7697 He performed in summer stock and soap operas before being plucked as an almost unknown to play the lead in Superman and three sequels 
7698 Richard Gephardt Gephardt House Democratic leader is a politician with a Mr Clean reputation who sought the presidency eight years ago and is widely believed to still have ambitions for the job 
7699 Gephardt 55 the son of a milkman from a working class district of St. Louis is a consummate congressional insider sufficiently skilled in compromise and the ways of the legislature to manage the often-unruly House Democrats 
7700 A former lawyer he was in the front line of President Bill Clinton 's battle with the Republican-led Congress over the budget but has opposed the president 's decision to sign the Republican-written welfare reform bill 
7701 He advocated tough action against foreign countries to cut U.S. trade deficits but sometimes been out of step with the party 's liberal wing 
7702 He was an opponent of abortion until 1986 and voted for President Ronald Reagan 's big tax cut bill 
7703 Gephardt a red-haired square-jawed man is a less than fiery orator 
7704 His 1988 bid for the Democratic nomination only took off after he recreated himself as a firebreathing reformer of the establishment standing up for blue collar workers and farmers 
7705 Tom Daschle Daschle 48 was largely unknown outside Washington and his state of South Dakota when he surprisingly beat more prominent rivals to become Senate Democratic leader after the party lost its majority to the Republicans in 1994 
7706 A mild-mannered and youthful man who rose rapidly after entering the Senate in 1987 he presented himself as a Midwest moderate as a Democratic winner in a Republican state able to unite Senate factions 
7707 Concern that he might be steamrollered by the vastly more experienced Republican leader Bob Dole was dispelled when he showed a tough edge outmaneuvering Dole in a wrangle over scrapping a gas tax and raising the federal minimum wage 
7708 In his early Senate years he was seen as a prairie populist working on legislation protecting farmers prices and also on compensating veterans sickened by Agent Orange defoliant spraying in the Vietnam War 
7709 Daschle was a key player in President Bill Clinton 's failed attempt at sweeping healthcare changes but when he became minority leader he declared he would be no water-carrier for the White House 
7710 He has made clear he opposed Clinton 's signing of the Republican-initiated welfare reform bill 
7711 He has spent his adult life in politics coming to Congress as an aide in 1972 after three years in the Air Force and then being elected to the House of Representatives himself in 1978

7713 DALLAS 1996-08-26 
7714 A 13-year-old Dallas boy has been charged with murdering his adoptive mother over the weekend police said on Monday 
7715 Margaret McCullough 55 was found dead in her home on Saturday with gunshot wounds to the head

7719 They are talking to him now about the motive and everything else 
7720 McCullough had adopted the boy who was the grandson of her late husband shortly after his birth but neighbours said they often had loud arguments

7741 Nicholas Shaxson London newsroom +44 171 542 8167 
7742 Prairies saw no frost Monday none rest of week 
7743 WINNIPEG 1996-08-26 
7744 Canada 's Prairies saw no frost on Monday morning and none was expected anywhere on the grainbelt until late in the Labour Day long weekend Environment Canada said 
7745 Apparently we 're home free for the rest of the week 
7746 We 're not calling for any frost until after the weekend when it starts to cool off in northwestern Alberta after the weekend probably Monday or Tuesday meteorologist Gerald Machnee told Reuters 
7747 Sprague Manitoba on the Minnesota border was the cold spot of the Prairies Monday morning at 4.0 Celsius 39.2 F 
7748 Temperatures at ground level can be 2.0 to 5.0 Celsius lower than at chest level depending on windspeed sky conditions and ground surface moisture 
7749 Freezing occurs at 0 Celsius 32.0 F 
7750 North Battleford Sask 
7751 reported a low of 5.0 Celsius 41.0 F and Grande Prairie Alta 
7752 in the Peace River Valley reported 7.0 Celsius 44.6 F 
7753 Machnee dismissed talk of frost Wednesday by proponents of the full moon frost soon school of thought 
7754 Lows on August 28 across the Prairies should range from 8.0 to 12.0 Celsius with highs around 30.0 Celsius 
7755 Gilbert Le Gras 204 947 3548 
7756 Brush Wellman comments on beryllium lawsuits 
7757 CLEVELAND 1996-08-26 
7758 Brush Wellman Inc said Monday that 10 of 24 lawsuits involving chronic beryllium disease have been dismissed since July 1 
7759 The leading U.S. beryllium producer said in a conference call it has traditionally been pro-active regarding the workplace disease a lung ailment which can affects a small percent of people whose immune systems are susceptible 
7760 Of the 14 remaining suits 10 were filed by employees of industrial Brush Wellman customers and Brush Wellman liability in such suits is typically covered by insurance Timothy Reid vice president of corporate communications said on the call 
7761 The company was responding to an article in Sunday 's New York Times 
7762 He said the article largely reiterated information about the suits and the disease which had previously been made public via Securities and Exchange Commission filings and annual reports 
7763 Brush Wellman has been a leader in dealing with health and safety issues related to chronic Beryllium disease for nearly 50 years he said 
7764 We have a record of going beyond regulatory requirements and we consistently share the most current information available with customers and employees 
7765 The customer employee suits were filed in 1990-95 he said 
7766 A class action filed by a former Brush Wellman employee in April 1996 was dismissed in July he said 
7767 The company is vigorously defending the remaining four suits filed by former and current Brush Wellman employees he said 
7768 After a delayed opening the stock was off 1-1/2 to 18-7/8 
7769 Cleveland Newsdesk 216-579-0077

7834 Chelsea makes political debut on Clinton train trip 
7835 CHILLICOTHE Ohio 1996-08-25 
7836 Chelsea Clinton until now carefully shielded from the exposure of public life made her political debut on Sunday on her father 's whistlestop train trip 
7837 Chelsea 16 was at President Bill Clinton 's side as he rode the rails through parts of West Virginia Kentucky and Ohio and was introduced at every stop 
7838 She even worked ropelines shaking hands with excited fans 
7839 Hillary Rodham Clinton saw her husband and daughter off on the trip in Huntington West Virginia and then went on to Chicago to begin a rigorous Democratic Convention schedule 
7840 Asked if Chelsea would have a prominent role in the campaign White House spokesman Mike McCurry said She 'll do what she did today when she can 
7841 She has to go back to school 
7842 The president 's daughter is going into her senior year of high school at Sidwell Friends School a private school in Washington 
7843 McCurry said Chelsea has asked to go on the train trip and attend the convention where her father will be renominated but said her exposure did not signal the start of a new political career 
7844 Chelsea is a very poised young lady but she 's not that much interested in politics the spokesman said 
7845 Dutch closing share market report 
7846 AMSTERDAM 1996-08-26 
7847 Dutch shares drifted to a lower close on Monday dragged down by weakness in the domestic bond market and turnover depressed by the UK bank holiday and lack of any significant U.S. economic data 
7848 The AEX index of leading shares closed 4.54 points easier at 556.19 the day 's low 
7849 The Dutch market had been on the defensive all day but a softer start to Wall Street did little to boost sentiment in late trade dealers said 
7850 It was always going to be a tough day with participation so low 
7851 But the only thing really worrying the market was the bonds and that dragged us lower one dealer said 
7852 Stocks were down across the board with Dutch PTT topping the volume list and closing down 1.90 guilders at 58.70 
7853 The post and telecoms firm posted an 8.5 percent rise in first half earnings on Friday just below analysts expectations 
7854 IHC Caland reported first half results well under forecasts on Monday and the shares suffered as a result 
7855 They were trading unchanged just before the release of figures but closed 2.40 guilders down at 80.70 after it reported net profits of 34.9 million guilders against 36.6 million last year and estimates ranging from 37.5 to 47.2 million 
7856 IHC also forecast post tax earnings rising 21 percent for the full year 
7857 Banking group ING traded ex-dividend today and finished 0.60 guilders weaker at 52.90 as a result 
7858 But Nutricia shrugged off its ex-div tag to soar a further 4.10 guilders to 214.40 continuing its explosive rally sparked by the 51 percent jump in first half net profits last week which set the market alight on Friday sending the shares up 18.40 at 210.00 by the close 
7859 Engineering concern Stork started the day well as the shares attracted some follow-through interest to the announcement late on Friday that its Fokker Aviation unit had won a major order 
7860 But the rally was short-lived and Stork ended just 0.20 up at 51.00 guilders 
7861 Amsterdam Newsroom +31 20 504 5000 
7862 Tapie to quit French assembly seat as film opens 
7863 PARIS 1996-08-26 
7864 Former businessman and soccer boss Bernard Tapie said that he would give up his seat in the National Assembly by Wednesday the day a film by Claude Lelouche in which he stars opens in France 
7865 I will no longer be deputy by the time the film opens he said in a broadcast interview 
7866 Just about he told Europe 1 radio when asked whether he had sent his letter of resignation to Assembly speaker Philippe Seguin 
7867 A Seguin spokeswoman confirmed that no letter or call had yet been received 
7868 Tapie 53 was resigning just ahead of expected government action to eject him from the Assembly following a finding by the Supreme Court that he was bankrupt and thus ineligible for public office for a five-year period 
7869 Tapie the target of a blizzard of legal actions over his now-destroyed business empire and the Marseille soccer team he once ran has a starring role in Lelouche 's Homme femmes mode d'emploi Men women instructions for use 
7870 He plays a power-hungry lawyer in the movie described as a tender and cruel comedy by Lelouche who is making his 35th film 
7871 I have paid too dearly for mixing two careers Tapie said 
7872 In France you cannot be a film artist and a national politician at the same time 
7873 That is why I will no longer be deputy by the time the film opens 
7874 Justice Minister Jacques Toubon began last month the formal process of ejecting Tapie from the French parliament as well as stripping him of his seat in the European parliament 
7875 The French procedure was expected to be completed before October 2 when the National Assembly is to reconvene after a summer break but the European procedure was expected to take longer 
7876 Tapie 's lawyer has said he intends to appeal to the European Court of Human Rights in an effort to prevent or delay the loss of his European seat 
7877 But such an appeal even if the court were to accept the case which it is not obliged to do would not suspend enforcement of the French judgement against him 
7878 Tapie faces a probable spell in prison after he loses his parliamentary immunity since two appeal courts have confirmed jail sentences of eight and six months against him for tax fraud and rigging a soccer match 
7879 He is appealing in both cases to the Supreme Court 
7880 Bank of France drains 3.9 bln Ffr at tender 
7881 PARIS 1996-08-26 
7882 The Bank of France drained 3.9 billion francs at a securities repurchase tender held on Monday to allocate funds for injection into the money market on Tuesday 
7883 It accepted bids for 44.3 billion francs in new liquidity 3.9 billion less than the 48.2 billion leaving the market on Tuesday when a previous pact expires 
7884 The new pact expires on September 3 
7885 The Bank of France said it allocated 13.4 billion francs to bidders offering Treasury bills as collateral satisfying 3.4 percent of such demand 
7886 It allotted a further 30.9 billion to bidders putting up private paper satisfying 12.5 percent of this demand 
7887 Paris Newsroom +33 1 4221 5452 
7888 RABOBANK [ RABN.CN ] SEES H2 NET GROWTH UNDER 10 PCT 
7889 AMSTERDAM 1996-08-26 
7890 Dutch co-operative bank Rabobank Nederland BA 's net profit growth might slow to less than than 10 year percent in the second half of 1996 executive board chairman Herman Wijffels said on Monday 
7891 The unlisted bank earlier announced a 1996 interim net profit of 853 million guilders up 21.5 percent on the 702 million guilders reported in the first half of 1995 
7892 He said second-half profit growth would depend on customer demand for loans which was already easing and the performance of financial markets which were strong in the first half and boosted securities trading and underwriting income 
7893 We expect reasonable growth in the second half 
7894 Maybe it will be in single-digits Wijffels told Reuters 
7895 He said growth in customer demand in the first half was 50 percent above normal but it was hard to maintain this pace 
7896 Rabobank 's net profit was 1.43 billion guilders in 1995 
7897 The bank earlier warned that profit growth would slow in the second half citing the increasing momentum in profit growth in the comparative period of 1995 and increased investment 
7898 But Wijffels was unable to quantify second half investment to improve and extend domestic and offshore services

7914 BRIGHT-BELGIANS SPEED AFTER SCHUMACHER 'S WIN 
7915 BRUSSELS 
7916 Michael Schumacher 's victory in the Belgian Formula One Grand Prix at Spa-Francorchamps sparked a speeding epidemic on Belgian roads after the race was over 
7917 Belga news agency reported that police checked more than 3,000 drivers amd booked 222 for speeding on their way home after the race 
7918 Some were clocked doing 180 kilometres an hour 112 miles per hour Belga said 
7919 Schumacher won the race in 1 hour 28 minutes 15.125 seconds at an average speed of 208.442 km hour 130 m.p.h. 
7920 Thai PM proposes Sept 18 for no-confidence debate 
7921 BANGKOK 1996-08-26 
7922 Thai Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa on Monday proposed September 18 as the date for parliamentary debate on an opposition no-confidence motion accusing him of incompetence 
7923 The president of parliament had earlier said September 11 could be set for the debate 
7924 The opposition motion against Banharn accuses him of being incompetent lacking ethical leadership and alleges his administration is corrupt 
7925 His critics allege he may be attempting to delay the debate 
7926 Banharn has denied the accusations and said he is ready to clear himself in parliament 
7927 In my opinion September 18 would be a convenient date for the government to answer questions 
7928 This has nothing to do with the accusation that I am trying to escape the debate Banharn told reporters after meeting coalition partners 
7929 Banharn 's 13-month-old six-party coalition government controls 209 seats in the 391-seat lower house of parliament 
7930 Political infighting within Banharn 's Chart Thai party has raised doubts whether he can hold his supporters together and defeat the opposition motion political analysts said 
7931 We are still waiting to fix a date 
7932 September 18 is regarded as tentative because we still have not received the order to fix it on the agenda said an official at parliament 's agenda section 
7933 The last no-confidence debate against Banharn 's coalition in May was won by the government

7953 RESEARCH ALERT Aronkasei cut 
7954 TOKYO 1996-08-26 
7955 Nomura Research Institute Ltd downgraded Aronkasei Co Ltd to a 2 rating from its previous 1 market sources said on Monday 
7956 In its three-grade rating system the research institute assigns a 2 rating to issues whose values it sees moving within 10 percentage points in either direction of the key 225-share Nikkei average over the next six months 
7957 Nomura officials were not immediately available for comment

7966 U.N. official Ekeus heads for Baghdad 
7967 MANAMA 1996-08-26 
7968 Senior United Nations arms official Rolf Ekeus left Bahrain for Baghdad on Monday for talks with Iraqi officials a U.N. spokesman said 
7969 The spokesman said Ekeus chairman of the United Nations Special Commission UNSCOM would spend two or three days in Iraq but declined to give further details 
7970 U.N. oficials have said Ekeus would hold talks with Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Tareq Aziz and other officials as part of an agreement Iraq reached with the United Nations in June to hold higher level political talks with Ekeus 
7971 The Security Council on Friday asked Iraq to stop blocking arms inspectors search for concealed weapons or materials they believe were being shuttled around to avoid detection 
7972 Disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction under 1991 Gulf War ceasefire terms is a prerequisite before the lifting of crippling sanctions imposed on Iraq in 1990 for invading Kuwait

8008 Tamils demonstrate outside U.N. headquarters 
8009 GENEVA 1996-08-26

8012 The demonstrators delivered an appeal to the U.N. human rights centre demanding an immediate end to state terrorism against Tamils and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam LTTE 
8013 FOCUS Eurobourses end mixed but London recovers 
8014 Leonard Santorelli 
8015 LONDON 1996-08-27 
8016 European bourses closed mixed on Tuesday with London clawing back most of the day 's losses despite an unsteady start on wall Street hit by inflation worries 
8017 The dollar weakened during the day with many dealers sidelined because of uncertainty over Tokyo 's monetary direction ahead of the important Japanese Tankan economic survey out on Wednesday 
8018 But it recovered at the close of trade 
8019 Stocks in London started the week badly after a three-day weekend slipping 0.3 percent but bargain-hunters later moved in and the FTSE index recovered most of the lost ground to end only just in negative ground 
8020 Tuesday 's patchy showing in London followed a string of records last week culminating in Friday 's trading high of 3,911 fuelled by a wave of European interest rate cuts 
8021 The London bourse drew little help from the unsettled morning on Wall Street which slipped in and out of positive ground after a stronger-than-expected August consumer confidence report refuelled inflation fears pulling U.S. Treasuries back from their early peaks 
8022 Shortly after the report appeared showing the confidence index rising to 109.4 in August from a revised 107.0 in July Wall Street relinquished virtually all its morning gains 
8023 Treasuries remain very sensitive to any indication of a strong economy and we 're still in that summer doldrum period of light trading said Alan Ackerman market strategist at Fahnestock & Co 
8024 Consequently stocks and bonds are both subject to rapid swings 
8025 Frankfurt was the one bright spot in Europe 
8026 Floor trading ended up 0.25 percent and the computerised IBIS index climbed nearly 0.4 percent given a push by the performance of chemical shares 
8027 The market is trading 100 percent on fundamentals at the moment as interest rate fantasy disappears it 's all company news said one trader 
8028 French shares ended slightly down amid growing unease about a difficult autumn for the government which also weighed on the franc dealers said 
8029 Bond prices were weaker and the franc was quoted at 3.4210 per mark for the first time since August 13 as worries about the government 's autumn budget and a weak U.S. currency lifted the mark and squeezed French investments 
8030 The dollar which dropped sharply on Monday because of jitters over the Japanese Tankan survey weakened further in quiet trading but regained losses to end the day close to Monday 's levels 
8031 Besides the Tankan there 's nothing really until the U.S. jobs numbers next week said a UK bank corporate dealer 
8032 There is still the summer malaise hanging over the market 
8033 Foreign exchange markets regard the Tankan report as an important indication of the country 's future monetary policy direction 
8034 If it points to weakness in the economy the report will help the dollar regain some lost ground as speculation of a near-term rise in Japanese interest rates will evaporate 
8035 The Japanese discount rate is currently at a record low of 0.5 percent 
8036 The dollar was also pressured by the mark 's strength against European currencies amid renewed concerns over Europe 's economic and monetary union EMU timetable 
8037 CURRENCIES 
8038 The dollar was at 1.4788 marks and 107.74 yen at the close of European trading compared with 1.4789 marks and 107.55 yen on Monday 
8039 STOCK MARKETS 
8040 The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British shares ended 1.8 points lower at 3,905.7 
8041 In Paris the CAC-40 share index finished down 2.43 at 2,017.99 
8042 The 30-share DAX index in Frankfurt closed up 6.48 at 2,558.84 
8043 PRECIOUS METALS 
8044 Gold closed at $ 388.55 an ounce compared with Monday 's close of $ 388.75 on international markets 
8045 Silver ended up one cent $ 5.24 
8046 More hostages freed from hijacked Sudanese plane 
8047 STANSTED England 1996-08-27 
8048 Armed hijackers believed to be Iraqis released between 60 and 70 people on Tuesday from a Sudan Airways plane carrying 199 passengers and crew that landed in London after being diverted on a flight from Khartoum to Amman authorities said 
8049 A spokesman for Stansted airport said that the unidentified hijackers were demanding to see a British-based member of the Iraqi Community Association called Mr Sadiki and that police were trying to trace him 
8050 Police spokeswoman Kim White said police had already contacted Sadiki and were trying to arrange to bring him to Stansted 30 miles 48 km north-east of London to talk to the hijackers 
8051 The airport spokesman said the six hijackers who police said were armed with grenades and possibly other explosives were believed to be Iraqi nationals 
8052 The hijackers started to release people for the Airbus plane in batches of 10 starting with women and children in what police described as a controlled release 
8053 Police said most of the passengers were Sudanese but that there were also an unknown number of Iraqis Jordanians Palestinians Syrians and Saudis 
8054 Later they said the number of passengers released from the plane had reached 80 
8055 FEATURE Eco terrorists target UK builders 
8056 Edna Fernandes 
8057 LONDON 1996-08-27 
8058 Ecological warfare has broken out across the British construction industry striking some of the biggest corporates as activists give up peaceful protests and seek to hit builders where it hurts their profit margins 
8059 Described by one British company as eco-terrorism it is seen as the new business risk of the 1990s 
8060 Famous names like Tarmac Plc Costain Group Plc and ARC a unit of conglomerate Hanson Plc have all been targeted 
8061 Activist groups are no longer seen by British firms as a harmless badly organised ragbag of students and hippies 
8062 You only have to see them in action at protests said David Harding spokesman at ARC Hanson 's aggregates company 
8063 They walk around with mobile phones and camera equipment they communicate and gather support for demos via the Internet we 're talking about a highly sophisticated organisation 
8064 One road protestor under the codename Steady Eddie told construction journal Building earlier this year If it comes down to full-scale economic warfare we will aim to drive them out of business 
8065 As well as financial threats companies also emphasise the terror tactics used 
8066 Costain 's contract to build the controversial Newbury bypass which runs through a conservation area has led to violent protests delaying building bomb threats staff intimidation and picketing of chief executive Alan Lovell 's home 
8067 A Costain spokesman told Reuters We 've had all sorts of protests at the head office and the chief executive 's house 
8068 But it 's when it gets to the employee families that it goes across the line 
8069 Tactics used by some underground groups including the cryptic Berkshire Wood Elves which distribute leaflets with instructions on home-made explosives are now the subject of a police investigation 
8070 Other larger activist groups include Earth First The Land is Ours Alarm UK and Road Alert 
8071 The groups have targeted specific projects like the Newbury bypass and the M3 motorway through Twyford Down in the southern county of Hampshire 
8072 But they are also campaigning on broader issue such as stopping the government road building programme and out-of-town superstores which they say create more traffic pollution and damage local communities 
8073 The government has slashed its road-building spending 
8074 Although protests may have contributed to the decision it has been seen primarily as economic rather than ecological 
8075 Graham Watts chief executive of the Construction Industry Council said I do n't think many firms involved in tendering for sensitive projects realise the impact environmental activity has on the cost of running a project 
8076 But they are more alert than they were 3-4 years ago 
8077 There 's no doubt it 's a big issue now 
8078 He says the damage comes in two forms Tangible in the form of extra costs additional security threats to staff and the more intangible damage caused by negative publicity 
8079 Watts said the cost of protesting can be heavy once the company is locked into a contract 
8080 I do often hear on the industry circuit of tales where the company tenders at low margins and the demonstrations which follow means they are running the project at a loss 
8081 ARC says it 's not just contractors in the front line but also suppliers like itself 
8082 Its own quarries came under attack after it emerged that it may be a supplier for the Newbury bypass 
8083 It was called the First Battle of the Newbury bypass said ARC 's Harding 
8084 We had 300 Earth First protestors invade and occupy our site 
8085 Hundreds of thousands of pounds dollars of damage was done in one day 
8086 Plus there was the knock-on cost of lost production and extra security in future 
8087 Simon Brown analyst at investement bank UBS said this new phenomenon has led to a change in the way the industry evaluates project risk 
8088 When talking to Tarmac about the M3 link through Twyford Down they made it fairly clear that their risk assessment methods have been changed and now involve a very clear environmental risk analysis 
8089 Harding says others have done the same 
8090 As a result of eco-terrorism we are looking at controversial jobs more closely to see if the profit margins are wide enough to cover things like extra security 
8091 For an industry already suffering from razor-thin margins overcapacity and stagnant demand eco-terrorism is the latest bizarre twist in the construction sector 's tale of woe 
8092 London Carnival ends in high spirits 
8093 LONDON 1996-08-26 
8094 London 's annual Notting Hill Carnival the largest in Europe and second in the world only to Rio ended peacefully on Monday with an estimated 800,000 revellers singing and dancing the day away in high spirits 
8095 Police said they made 30 arrests and there were two stabbings 
8096 But there was no repeat of the ugly scenes that used to scar the street festival and police praised the crowds over the two days of festivities as good-natured 
8097 Around 400 police were wounded in riots in 1976 when the carnival now in its 31st year acquired its darker reputation from which it is now only slowly recovering 
8098 Shopkeepers still board up their windows and many residents leave town for the weekend but for four or five years there has been no disorder and relatively little crime

8108 Indonesia newspaper reports central bank scandal 
8109 JAKARTA 1996-08-27 
8110 Indonesia 's central bank suffered seven billion rupiah $ 2.9 million in losses resulting from fake transactions the Jakarta Post reported on Tuesday 
8111 A Bank Indonesia spokeswoman confirmed the newspaper report but declined to give further details 
8112 The bank 's governor Sudradjat Djiwandono was quoted as saying on Monday about 5.4 billion rupiah of the seven billion rupiah had been recovered 
8113 The newspaper said it was the central bank 's first public scandal in its 43-year history 
8114 The paper said five people had been arrested and police were looking for two more suspects 
8115 $ 1 2,341 rupiah 
8116 GOLF PLAYERS DIVIDED ON CART REQUEST FOR OLAZABAL 
8117 NORTHAMPTON England 1996-08-27 
8118 Seve Ballesteros and Colin Montgomerie are divided on whether Jose Maria Olazabal should be allowed to return to the European PGA Tour using a motorised cart to transport him around the course 
8119 The Spaniard has not played for nearly a year because of rheumatoid arthritis in both his feet and organisers of a pairs event to be staged in Bordeaux France from October 17 to 20 have been asked to provide him with a buggy 
8120 If the Tour 's tournament committee decides to change the rule I would not be against it said Ballesteros Olazabal 's compatriot and Ryder Cup captain 
8121 But commitee member Montgomerie said it could set an unhelpful precedent 
8122 I know Olly 's situation is very unfortunate but I do n't think we can start giving dispensations he said 
8123 You 've got to have a rule for everybody and I do n't think it 's feasible 
8124 The use of carts is generally prohibited in the professional game and if Olazabal is allowed to use one in Bordeaux he might then request one for the qualifying tournaments for next year 's Ryder Cup

8135 SOCCER THOMSON RESIGNS AS MANAGER OF RAITH ROVERS 
8136 KIRKCALDY Scotland 1996-08-27 
8137 Jimmy Thomson became Scotland 's first managerial casualty of the season on Tuesday when he quit Raith Rovers bottom of the premier division 
8138 Thomson resigned after the club 's directors asked him to return to his previous position as youth team coach 
8139 He had been in charge for six months 
8140 Raith lost their first two games of the season away to Rangers and Celtic then crashed 3-0 at home to Motherwell on Saturday 
8141 A club statement said The directors of Raith Rovers FC invited Jimmy Thomson to relinquish the post of manager and to resume his former position as youth team coach 
8142 Regrettably Jimmy has felt unable to accept that offer and has accordingly left the club 
8143 Thomson said I am leaving with my dignity and my pride intact and that is very important to me 
8144 While not agreeing with the directors decision I respect their reasons for making it

8158 SOCCER BALL RESIGNS AS MANCHESTER CITY MANAGER 
8159 MANCHESTER England 1996-08-27 
8160 Former England midfielder Alan Ball resigned as manager of first division side Manchester City on Monday night the club said 
8161 Ball appointed in July 1995 was unable to prevent City being relegated from the premier league last season and his record read 13 wins 14 draws and 22 losses in 49 games 
8162 They have lost two of their three matches so far this season 
8163 Club secretary Bernard Halford said in a statement The chairman and Board would like to place on record their appreciation of his endeavours and efforts whilst in his period of office and wish him well in the future

8344 CRICKET GOOCH TO PLAY ANOTHER SEASON FOR ESSEX 
8345 LONDON 1996-08-27 
8346 Graham Gooch the 43-year-old former England captain is to continue playing county cricket for at least another season his club Essex announced on Tuesday 
8347 Opener Gooch 's decision comes towards the end of a season in which he has underlined his consistency by becoming the leading scorer in Essex 's history beating Keith Fletcher 's aggregate of 29,434 
8348 Gooch who retired from test cricket after the 1994-95 tour of Australia but is now an England selector is seventh in this season 's first-class averages with 1,429 runs at 64.95 having hit five centuries and one double century 
8349 Essex secretary-general manager Peter Edwards said He is a remarkable batsman and still the best in this country 
8350 No-one will argue with that 
8351 You just have to look at his record to appreciate that fact 
8352 SOCCER ROMANIA CLUB BOSS BANNED FOR HEADBUTT 
8353 BUCHAREST 1996-08-27 
8354 The Romanian Soccer Federation has banned first division club Jiul Petrosani 's president Miron Cozma for two years for headbutting a visiting team player a federation statement said 
8355 Romania 's soccer bosses also fined Cozma a well-known miners union leader 10 million lei $ 3000 for the half-time attack on Dinamo Bucharest 's Danut Lupu last Sunday 
8356 Miners led by Cozma rioted in Bucharest in 1990 and 1991 bringing down the reformist government of premier Petre Roman 
8357 Cozma is awaiting trial for assault and criminal damage in a bar in his home town of Petrosan 300 kms west of Bucharest 
8358 The attack on Lupu came during a tunnel skirmish between opposing players as they left the field 
8359 Cozma 's blow was not too painful because I 'm a tall man Lupu told Reuters on Tuesday 
8360 Lupu is one of the tallest players in Romania 's first division towering over Cozma by some 17 cms 
8361 Jiul Petrosani promoted to the first division this year won the league game 1-0 
8362 Cozma is barred from taking part in any official soccer activity during the ban

8383 TENNIS EDBERG EXTENDS GRAND SLAM RUN TOPPLES WIMBLEDON CHAMP 
8384 Larry Fine 
8385 NEW YORK 1996-08-27 
8386 Stefan Edberg produced some of his vintage best on Tuesday to extend his grand run at the Grand Slams by toppling Wimbledon champion Richard Krajicek in straight sets at the U.S. Open 
8387 Edberg competing in the 54th consecutive and final Grand Slam event of his illustrious career turned back the clock at Stadium Court with a flowing 6-3 6-3 6-3 serve-and-volley victory over the fifth-seeded Dutchman 
8388 It 's a win that I can be proud of said the 30-year-old Swede winner of two U.S. Opens and six Grand Slam titles in all 
8389 It 's never easy to beat the Wimbledon champion 
8390 Edberg who has said he will retire at season 's end made it look easy under gray skies at the National Tennis Centre 
8391 The unseeded Swede struck quickly breaking Krajicek in the first game and never let loose his grip on the one hour 44 minute match as he served and volleyed with the grace that made him one of the dominant players of his time 
8392 There 's not doubt about it Richard was definitely off his game and I took advantage said Edberg 
8393 I still have my days where I feel great out there 
8394 Also reaching the second round were top-seeded defending champion Pete Sampras a 6-2 6-2 6-1 winner over last minute replacement Jimy Szymanski of Venezuela called on after Adrian Voinea of Romania withdrew because of a sprained ankle 
8395 Third seed Thomas Muster of Austria also charged into the second round with a 6-1 7-6 7-2 6-2 romp over Javier Frana of Argentina 
8396 Marcelo Rios of Chile the 10th seed also advanced 
8397 Rios claimed a 4-6 6-1 6-4 6-2 victory over Romania 's Andrei Pavel 
8398 On the women 's side second seed Monica Seles got off to a strong start by beating fellow-American Anne Miller 6-0 6-1 and was joined in the second round by Spain 's Arantxa Sanchez Vicario seeded third Olympic champion Lindsay Davenport 8 and Karina Habsudova of Slovakia 17 
8399 The women 's draw lost another seed when Austrian Judith Wiesner overcame Iva Majoli of Croatia 2-6 6-3 6-1 
8400 The fifth- seeded Majoli joined Anke Huber 5 and Magdalena Maleeva 12 on the sidelines

8550 BASEBALL GIANTS EDGE PHILLIES 1-0 
8551 SAN FRANCISCO 1996-08-27 
8552 William VanLandingham pitched eight scoreless innings and Glenallen Hill drove in the game 's only run with a first-inning single as the San Francisco Giants claimed a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies on Monday 
8553 VanLandingham 8-13 who entered the game with one complete game in the first 56 starts of his career limited the Phillies to two hits and two walks with four strikeouts 
8554 We 've been working all year on my follow-through and I really concentrated on that VanLandingham said 
8555 It gave me more life in all of my pitches so the ball moved more 
8556 At Colorado Andres Galarraga homered and drove in three runs as the Colorado Rockies had 10 extra-base hits and Billy Swift won his first game in almost a year in a 9-5 rain-shortened seven-inning victory over the Cincinnati Reds 
8557 Swift 1-0 who made his first start since June 3rd and underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder earlier in the season allowed five runs and six hits in five innings 
8558 In Houston Andy Benes allowed two runs over seven innings and Royce Clayton had a run-scoring single in the seventh to lift the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros 
8559 Benes 14-9 allowed five hits walked five and struck out 10 for his 11th win in 12 decisions 
8560 The Cardinals moved within one-half game of first-place Houston in the National League Central Division 
8561 BASEBALL ORIOLES WIN YANKEES LOSE 
8562 BALTIMORE 1996-08-27 
8563 Cal Ripken 's bases-loaded walk scored Brady Anderson with the winning run in the bottom of the 10th as the Baltimore Orioles regained control of the top spot in the wild-card race with a wild 12-11 victory over the Oakland Athletics 
8564 Trailing by a run entering the 11th the Orioles rallied against Oakland reliever Mark Acre 0-2 with a walk and a triple by Brady Anderson to tie the game 
8565 Then Oakland manager Art Howe decided to intentionally walk Rafael Palmeiro and Bobby Bonilla to load the bases but Acre was nowhere near the plate to Ripken 
8566 The decisive pitch nearly hit Ripken and gave the Orioles a one-half game lead over the Chicago White Sox in the wild-card race 
8567 In Seattle Jay Buhner 's eighth-inning single snapped a tie as the Seattle Mariners edged the New York Yankees 2-1 in the opener of a three-game series 
8568 New York starter Jimmy Key left the game in the first inning after Seattle shortstop Alex Rodriguez lined a shot off his left elbow 
8569 The Yankees have lost 12 of their last 19 games and their lead in the AL East over Baltimore fell to five games 
8570 At California Tim Wakefield pitched a six-hitter for his third complete game of the season and Mo Vaughn and Troy O'Leary hit solo home runs in the second inning as the surging Boston Red Sox won their third straight 4-1 over the California Angels 
8571 Boston has won seven of eight and is 20-6 since August 2nd 
8572 The Red Sox are two games over .500 for the first time this season 
8573 In Chicago Cal Eldred pitched 5-1/3 scoreless innings and John Jaha scored one run and doubled in another as the Milwaukee Brewers held off the slumping Chicago White Sox 3-2 
8574 Eldred 6-5 walked one and struck out three 
8575 Angel Miranda retired one batter and Bob Wickman retired the next four but loaded the bases in the eighth 
8576 In Detroit Jim Thome 's solo homer in the ninth inning snapped a tie and Charles Nagy pitched a three-hitter for his first win in over a month leading the Cleveland Indians to their 11th straight victory over the Detroit Tigers 2-1 
8577 With the score tied 1-1 in the ninth Thome hit a 2-2 pitch from starter Felipe Lira 6-11 over the left-field fence for his 29th homer 
8578 In Toronto Juan Guzman allowed three runs over seven innings to make homers by Joe Carter and Carlos Delgado stand up as the surging Toronto Blue Jays held off the Minnesota Twins 5-3 
8579 Toronto returned home from a 10-game road trip and won for the eighth time in nine games as Guzman 11-8 allowed nine hits and struck out eight without a walk
