11305 Briton held in Thailand over 4.4 kg heroin find 
11306 BANGKOK 1996-08-28 
11307 Thai airport police arrested a British bartender for allegedly attempting to board a flight for Amsterdam with nearly 4.4 kg 9.68 lb of heroin in his luggage police said on Wednesday 
11308 Police said James Lee Williams 28 was stopped at a Bangkok airport departure lounge on Monday after officials found the drug in a bag that Williams planned to carry onto the plane 
11309 Williams hometown was not immediately available 
11310 The maximum sentence for heroin trafficking is the death penalty although it is normally commuted to life imprisonment 
11311 PLO Council calls for halt to contacts with Israel 
11312 RAMALLAH West Bank 1996-08-28 
11313 The Palestinian Legislative Council on Wednesday called for a halt to contacts with Israel just hours after President Yasser Arafat said the Jewish state had effectively declared war on the Palestinians by pursuing its hardline policies 
11314 A resolution released by the council called for halting contacts with the Israeli side and leaving the mechanism to carry out this to Palestinian President Yasser Arafat 
11315 The council was meeting in Ramallah to discuss Israel 's new policy of Jewish settlement expansion and its uncompromising line on Jerusalem since Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June 
11316 Council resolutions are not necessarily binding 
11317 Arafat had earlier blasted Israel saying its policies amounted to a declaration of war against the Palestinian people 
11318 He also called for the first general strike in two years in the West Bank and Gaza on Thursday 
11319 What happened concerning continuous violations and crimes from this new Israeli leadership means they are declaring a state of war against the Palestinian people Arafat told the council 
11320 Council speaker Ahmed Korei said the decision was part of a comprehensive plan to confront Israeli settlement policy land confiscation and what he termed other violations of the Israeli-PLO peace deals 
11321 Iraqi Kurd group says agrees new ceasefire 
11322 ANKARA 1996-08-28 
11323 An Iraqi Kurdish group on Wednesday said it had agreed a new U.S.-brokered ceasefire with a rival faction after a previous accord was shattered by sporadic fighting between the groups in recent days 
11324 The Patriotic Union of Kurdistan PUK leadership declares its endorsement for a ceasefire arrangement with the KDP Kurdistan Democratic Party to take effect as of 8:00 a.m. on August 28 the PUK said in a statement 
11325 The PUK said the ceasefire was agreed after talks between U.S. Assistant Secretary for Near East Affairs Robert Pelletreau and PUK leader Jalal Talabani 
11326 The KDP led by Massoud Barzani had said a previous ceasefire negotiated by Pelletreau last Friday was broken by the PUK 
11327 Talabani has agreed to take part in talks in London on reaching a comprehensive settlement for the PUK-KDP conflict the PUK statement said 
11328 It said the KDP was responsible for breaking the previous ceasefire by refusing to endorse it publicly 
11329 Kurd group says Iraqi troops massing near north 
11330 ANKARA 1996-08-28 
11331 An Iraqi Kurdish group on Wednesday said Iraq was massing troops near Kurdish regions in the north where a U.S.-led allied air force protects the local population against attacks from Baghdad 
11332 The Iraqi regime has started threatening the Kurdish population by massing troops in preparation to attack Kurdish towns and population centres the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan PUK said in a statement 
11333 The PUK said it had received confirmed reports that Iraqi troops supported by tanks artillery and armoured vehicles have already penetrated some Kurdish areas 
11334 It said the military presence reflects cooperation between President Saddam Hussein and the PUK 's rival the Kurdistan Democratic Party KDP 
11335 The PUK statement follows KDP assertions that the PUK is receiving military support from Iran 
11336 Hostilities between the two warring Iraqi Kurdish factions have continued in the last few days despite a U.S.-brokered ceasefire last Friday 
11337 The PUK called on the United Nations and allied forces to halt the Iraqi aggression 
11338 U.S. French and British aircraft have safeguarded the Iraqi Kurdish population against aggression from Baghdad since shortly after the Gulf War in 1991 
11339 The allied force known as Operation Provide Comfort is based in southern Turkey 
11340 Iraq says hijackers were not diplomats 
11341 BAGHDAD 1996-08-28 
11342 Iraq on Wednesday said the hijackers of a Sudanese airliner were not Iraqi diplomats and added that noble Iraqis would never contemplate such an action 
11343 The official Iraqi News Agency INA quoted Iraq 's ambassador in Khartoum as saying that Iraq 's embassy in the Sudanese capital had nothing to do with the Monday night hijacking 
11344 Iraq 's ambassador in Khartoum denounced the hijacking and described it as a terrorist act which had nothing to do with the morals and values of noble Iraqis INA said 
11345 Ambassador Abdulsamad Hameed Ali told INA there was only one diplomat among the 199 passengers and crew on the Sudan Airways Airbus 
11346 He was not involved 
11347 on the contrary he was harassed by the elements which carried out the hijacking he said 
11348 INA did not say the hijackers were Iraqis 
11349 The hijack started when the flight left Khartoum for Amman on Monday night 
11350 The hijackers told the crew they had grenades and other explosives and threatened to blow up the plane if they were not taken to London 
11351 The airliner refuelled at Larnaca Cyprus and landed at London 's Stansted airport in the early hours of Tuesday 
11352 Seven Iraqi suspected hijackers surrendered and British police said they had apparently asked for political asylum 
11353 Several had brought their families along including children 
11354 Dole blasts Clinton for ignoring teen drug use 
11355 Judith Crosson 
11356 VENTURA Calif. 1996-08-28 
11357 Republican presidential candidate Bob Dole Wednesday accused the Clinton administration of ignoring drug use among teenagers and said if elected he would use the National Guard to stop drugs from entering the United States 
11358 He 'll probably mention his war on drugs which he 's going to start like everything else next year 
11359 It 's too late Mr. President Dole told an outdoor crowd of several hundred at a private religious school 
11360 He also commented briefly on published reports that the administration was planning to announce a plan to lower capital gains taxes for home sales 
11361 Welcome to the club 
11362 We 've had it out there for weeks and weeks and weeks Dole said 
11363 Dole said former first lady Nancy Reagan was laughed at with her just say no anti-drug message 
11364 But it worked Dole said 
11365 Meanwhile in Los Angeles Dole 's running mate Jack Kemp campaigned aggressively for the black vote in an area that was the flashpoint of the 1992 Los Angeles riots 
11366 Kemp told a crowd of about 300 African Americans in south central Los Angeles Keep your eyes open keep your ears open keep your heart open 
11367 I want to tell you with all my heart that we want to win your vote 
11368 In Dole 's address to a group that was largely white the presidential nominee likened the stream of illegal drugs into the United States to missiles aimed at American children and promised to appoint federal judges who would be tough on illegal drug use 
11369 They 're aiming millions and millions of missiles right at these young people whether it 's a needle whether it 's a cigarette whatever the delivery system is it 's poison and it 's got to stop in America 
11370 he said 
11371 Dole said 70 percent of the cocaine that entered the United States and 40 percent of the marijuana came from Mexico 
11372 We 've got an international problem and I 'm prepared to use our military might 
11373 We want to stop drugs at the border he said 
11374 Dole 's remarks prompted questions about whether he was seeking a ban on cigarettes 
11375 I did n't say anything about cigarettes 
11376 I was talking about drugs 
11377 I said you should n't smoke either 
11378 That 's all I said he replied as he was shaking hands with well-wishers 
11379 When asked specifically if he was suggesting a ban on cigarettes Dole replied Oh no 
11380 Come on you know better than that 
11381 Dole campaign aides said the candidate was telling young people not to smoke 
11382 Dole also said he opposed California Proposition 215 which if approved by voters would allow the cultivation of marijuana plants for medicinal uses 
11383 Dole said the initiative would allow marijuana to be used for anything from a headache to an ingrown toenail 
11384 In an effort to paint the drug issue in non-political terms Dole said three times during his 20-minute address that illegal drug use was neither a Democratic nor a Republican issue but one that involves all people 
11385 The anti-drug message is a theme Dole feels has strong voter appeal 
11386 On Sunday near Chicago he accused President Bill Clinton of raising the white flag in the war on drugs 
11387 A recent survey showed that illegal drug use among 12-17 year-olds had doubled in the past four years 
11388 Dole was flanked by several California Republican politicians including Gov 
11389 Pete Wilson who said local and state governments cannot fight illegal drugs alone 
11390 We need all the help we can get 
11391 We need to get the kind of help we used to get when Ronald Reagan and George Bush were in the White House Wilson said

11420 CME lumber futures close lower on profit taking 
11421 CHICAGO 1996-08-28 
11422 Profit taking continued to weigh on CME lumber futures but prices ended only slightly lower as strong cash markets underpinned futures traders said 
11423 The same pattern of the past few days persisted with futures declining early on the profit taking before firming late 
11424 There was cash-related buying late from people who want to take delivery of the September contract they said 
11425 Cash sources noted that although the cash market is generally quiet prices remain firm on demand for prompt delivery wood they added 
11426 Random Lengths quoted cash spruce at $ 419 per tbf up $ 5 from last Friday and $ 7 over the last midweek quote 
11427 Reduced concern over Hurricane Edouard prompted some of the early profit taking 
11428 Expectations the storm would turn more to the north partly eased concerns they said 
11429 Lumber closed $ 2.20 to $ 0.20 per tbf lower with September off $ 0.70 at $ 413.20 and November off most at $ 369.00 per tbf 
11430 Jerry Bieszk 312-408-8725 
11431 WHEAT--Rains boost U.S. HRW planting prospects 
11432 Greg Frost 
11433 KANSAS CITY Mo 
11434 1996-08-28 
11435 Above-normal summer rainfall in the U.S. High Plains has produced near-ideal conditions for planting the 1997 hard red winter wheat crop analysts said Wednesday 
11436 From central Texas north to Kansas rains throughout July and August have relieved most of the drought conditions that plagued the region earlier this year 
11437 Our moisture situation is excellent especially for fall planting of winter wheat said Kim Anderson extension wheat marketing economist at Oklahoma State University 
11438 The irony of the above-average summer rainfall was not lost on High Plains wheat producers who only three months ago were caught in a drought so severe that old-timers likened conditions to the Dust Bowl days of the 1930s 
11439 It 's definitely a turnabout from this past year but you know last year we had pretty good moisture about this time of year and then about October 1 it quit said Mark Hodges executive director of the Oklahoma Wheat Commission 
11440 Hopefully that 's not going to happen this year 
11441 According to figures released by the Oklahoma Climatological Survey an average of 20.19 inches fell across the state between March 1 and August 26 1996 
11442 That 's about 1/2 inch above the average for the same time period according to Howard Johnson associate state climatologist at the University of Oklahoma 
11443 He noted that the majority of that 20.19 inches had fallen since July 
11444 As an example of just how dry it was data showed that between October 1 1995 and March 1 1996 the state received an average of only 4.6 inches of rainfall 
11445 In northern Texas the current rainfall situation was similar to most of Oklahoma said Rodney Mosier executive assistant for the Texas Wheat Producers 
11446 Up here in the Texas Panhandle we 've had some extremely beneficial rains that came through within the last several days and are really setting us up for ideal conditions for planting wheat Mosier said 
11447 But he warned that the situation was not as ideal in central and southern Texas where mositure levels were still short despite the rains brought by Hurricane Dolly last week 
11448 In Kansas typically the number one U.S. hard red winter wheat producer topsoil moisture levels were rated mostly adequate during the week ended Sunday according to the state 's agricultural statistics service 
11449 In its weekly report released Monday the service said Kansas topsoil moisture was rated eight percent surplus 77 percent adequate and 15 percent short to very short 
11450 Oklahoma 's Agricultural Statistics Service showed similar conditions rating topsoil moisture levels as seven percent surplus 81 percent adequate and 12 percent short to very short 
11451 Data on topsoil moisture ratings were not released by the Texas Agricultural Statistics Service 
11452 Greg Frost 816 561-8671 
11453 First Union National Bank of Fla. settles suit 
11454 JACKSONVILLE Fla. 1996-08-28 
11455 First Union National Bank of Florida said on Wednesday it agreed to settle a class action law suit involving its collateral protection insurance CPI program 
11456 To provide for the settlements First Union has established a common fund of $ 4.7 million for cash refunds and $ 19.4 million in credit refunds for outstanding CPI balances 
11457 The bank is a division of First Union Corp 
11458 The bank said most of the charges resulted from loan portfolios from banks and thrifts that were acquired in the 1980s 
11459 First Union said it has discontinued CPI as an element of its motor vehicle or boat installment loan contracts 
11460 As part of the settlement agreement customers who had CPI placed on loans from January 1 1986 to September 31 1996 will receive cash or credit refunds the bank said 
11461 Cash refunds will go to those who paid their loans to First Union while credit refunds will go to those who have existing loan balances the bank said 
11462 Amoco says in talks over Yemen oil acreage 
11463 NEW YORK 1996-08-28 
11464 Amoco Corp officials said the company is in talks over crude oil production sharing in Yemen but declined to comment on a published report Amoco had reached preliminary agreement on a block in the Shabwa area 
11465 We 've been asked by Yemen not to comment on the talks said Amoco spokesman Dan Dietsch 
11466 We can neither confirm nor deny that report he said 
11467 According to Middle East Economic Survey MEES Yemen and Amoco signed a memorandum of understanding for a production-sharing agreement in Shabwa Block No 
11468 S-1 in the former South Yemen which united with North Yemen in 1990 
11469 According to another Amoco official the company is not exploring now for oil anywhere in Yemen 
11470 The officials said Amoco was deferring to the Yemeni Ministry of Petroleum and Minerals for any specific comments on the Amoco-Yemen talks 
11471 The former Soviet Union was displaced as contractor of the potentially rich Shabwa oilfields once it collapsed in December 1991 according to the International Petroleum Encyclopedia 
11472 Oliver Ludwig New York Energy Desk +1 212 859 1633 
11473 Burundi defends military regime to hostile UN 
11474 Evelyn Leopold 
11475 UNITED NATIONS 1996-08-28 
11476 Burundi 's ambassador on Wednesday lashed out at economic sanctions imposed by African states and said any thought of an arms embargo would be a windfall for guerrillas fighting his army-run government 
11477 In a lengthy debate on Burundi before the U.N. Security Council Ambassador Nsanze Terence said the new military government took over to stabilise the country and wanted negotiations under former Tanzanian President Julius Nyrere 
11478 Nearly every African member who spoke as well as most Security Council members however were unsympathetic towards the government of President Pierre Buyoya an army major put in power in a July coup by the Tutsi-run military which is locked in a guerrilla war with the majority Hutus 
11479 These African brothers should have been the first to bind the wounds of Burundi Terence said of the economic embargo 
11480 Quite the contrary Burundi has seen economic war declared against it by fellow African people a gratuitous immolation of the people of Burundi 
11481 He said his government had just asked U.N. human rights monitors to increase their numbers in Burundi in an effort to put an end to this vicious circle of violence 
11482 More than 150,000 people have been killed in violence between the minority Tutsis and the majority Hutus since 1993 
11483 Botswana 's envoy Mothusi Nkgowe said coups should be relegated to the dump heap of history as there could be no justification for the overthrow of a legitimate government 
11484 Chile has proposed a resolution still under discussion that would impose an immediate arms embargo on Burundi and call for negotiations 
11485 The draft suggests further sanctions against those who impede a political solution 
11486 Among the council 's five permanent members Russia and the United States appeared to support most elements of the Chilean proposal while Britain France and China were cautious 
11487 Terence a Tutsi said any arms embargo would leave the army unable to defend itself against Hutu guerrillas and leave the population exposed to armed terroritsts 
11488 But Chilean Ambassador Juan Somavia said Every weapon that reached Burundi is a weapon aimed mainly at killing an unarmed civilian 
11489 We must not send a signal different from the African leaders themselves 
11490 Inaction is becoming the worst possible course of action 
11491 Burundi 's parliament has been suspended and political parties are banned but Terence told reporters Buyoya would reconvene a new type of national assembly in October 
11492 The United States said the coup leaders had taken no steps to restore democracy and indiscriminate killings continued 
11493 Ambassador Karl Inderfurth said the new government should have unconditional negotiations with all parties inside and outside of the country 
11494 He said Washington strongly supported the economic sanctions imposed already and if these did not work the council would consider an arms embargo or targeted sanctions against faction leaders 
11495 But he said the international community had to be prepared for the worst and avoid a replay of the horrors in neighbouring Rwanda where widespread genocide broke out against the Tutsis two years ago 
11496 He again said the United Nations should draw up contingency plans for a rapid humanitarian intervention 
11497 Swiss arrest Rwandan on genocide suspicion 
11498 BERNE 1996-08-28 
11499 Swiss authorities said on Wednesday they had arrested a former Rwandan mayor now living in Switzerland on suspicion of violating human rights during the genocide in his country in 1994 
11500 The Defence Ministry said in a statement that investigations were still in the preliminary stage but it was cooperating closely with police in the cantons of Geneva and Freiburg 
11501 It did not identify the man

11514 French tax office sucks in money 
11515 PARIS 1996-08-28 
11516 Workers fixing the ceiling of a tax office in Paris found a dozen seven-year-old cheques for a total of six million francs $ 1.2 million in a ventilation pipe the weekly Le Canard Enchaine said on Wednesday 
11517 A Finance Ministry official explained that the cheques for corporate tax payments had been sucked into the ventilation system the weekly reported 
11518 The companies had been contacted at the time and had not been fined for failing to pay the official said 
11519 Swiss bond market closing report 
11520 ZURICH 1996-08-28 
11521 Swiss bonds ended mostly higher in generally quiet activity with the September confederate bond futures contract holding just above 113.00 
11522 Today was very quiet after a lot of activity on Tuesday said one Swiss bond futures trader 
11523 He said the market began strong gave up some gains at midday and then was able to recover back at the close but all on light volume 
11524 In the primary market Eksportfinans and Suedwest LB launched issues for 100 million and 300 million Swiss francs respectively 
11525 Eksportfinans seven-year issue was quoted at a yield of 3.98 percent and Suedwest LB 's five-year issue was quoted at 3.60 percent 
11526 Swiss money market rates remained lower at around 1.75 percent offered 
11527 As to fundamentals economists at Credit Suisse said they expect the country 's gross domestic product to be flat to negative in 1996 and to grow only 0.6 percent in 1997 
11528 The Swiss government also said Wednesday it had made progress in cutting Switzerland 's projected spending for 1997 
11529 Switzerland reports July consumer prices later this week

11537 Anti-Bhutto rally draws about 8,000 in Karachi 
11538 KARACHI Pakistan 1996-08-28 
11539 About 8,000 protesters marched through Karachi on Wednesday demanding the removal of Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto witnesses said 
11540 From here we will march to Islamabad and by God we will not let Benazir and Bhutto 's husband Asif Ali Zardari escape justice Nawaz Sharif leader of the main opposition Pakistan Muslim League told a rally organised by a 16-party alliance 
11541 Sharif accused Bhutto of corruption and nepotism charges she has denied in the past 
11542 Witnesses said protesters carrying colourful party flags walked for several miles chanting anti-government slogans 
11543 The event was part of an opposition campaign launched on August 14 Pakistan 's independence day 
11544 Sharif said similar rallies would be held in the Balochistan provincial capital Quetta and the Punjab provincial capital Lahore before an opposition march on the capital Islamabad 
11545 I promise the people of Karachi that those responsible for the extra-judicial killing of innocent youths would not be spared Sharif said 
11546 Karachi 's ethnic Mohajir National Movement MQM accuses the government of killing many of its militants in cold blood 
11547 The government has denied the charge and blames the MQM for much of the violence that killed 2,000 people in the city last year 
11548 Political observers said the turn-out was disappointing for a city of about 12 million people possibly indicating that the MQM although a member of the opposition alliance had not mobilised its supporters for the event 
11549 The turbulent southern port has been calmer this year but police say more than 300 people have died in political unrest 
11550 The MQM speaks for Urdu-speaking Moslems who migrated from India at Partition in 1947 and their descendants 
11551 Sharif a former prime minister is the main political rival of Bhutto who defeated him in the October 1993 election 
11552 He said only the removal of the government and an early election could save Pakistan from disaster 
11553 We will dislodge the Bhutto government 
11554 It is a holy war for us he said 
11555 Bhutto has vowed to complete her five-year term 
11556 India ACC Apr-Jul 96 sales output up 
11557 BOMBAY 1996-08-28 
11558 India 's leading cement firm Associated Cement Companies ACC said on Wednesday its cement sales rose to 3.1 million tonnes in April-July 1996 from 2.93 million a year ago 
11559 ACC Chairman Nani Palkhivala told shareholders at the firm 's annual meeting cement output rose to 3.14 million tonnes in the first quarter of 1996/97 April-March from 3.01 million a year ago 
11560 Palkhivala said ACC had secured government approval to take over a sick cement firm with a grinding capacity of 275,000 tonnes per year 
11561 We will take it over early next month he said 
11562 Talking about the cement industry in general Palkhivala said Indian production rose by about 10 percent in 1995/96 
11563 The industry saw capacity expansion of about 13 percent over 1994/95 from 77.79 million tonnes to 87.45 million tonnes Palkhivala told shareholders 
11564 He said Indian cement exports dropped about eight percent from the previous year because of stiff international competition and inadequate infrastructural facilities 
11565 ACC 's own export performance was marginally better than in 1994/95 on account of a 36 percent rise in exports to Nepal and the opening of a new market Sri Lanka he said 
11566 Despite power shortages ACC achieved a satisfactory growth in production during the year with the help of its power plants 
11567 ACC sold 9.4 million tonnes in 1995/96 retaining its top position in the Indian cement industry Palkhivala said

11569 Belgium bank sanctions $ 6.5 mln loan to India WSRL 
11570 BOMBAY 1996-08-28 
11571 Belgium 's Kredietbank has approved a $ 6.5 million loan to India 's Welspun Stahl Rohren Ltd WSRL to part-finance its submerged arc welded pipes plant the Indian company said in a statement on Wednesday 
11572 The loan is at LIBOR plus one percent it said 
11573 The loan maturing in six years is guaranteed by Indusind Bank for $ 3.5 million and by UTI Bank for $ 3 million it said 
11574 The WSRL plant located in the western Indian state of Gujarat will have a capacity to manufacture 175,000 tonnes per annum of longitudinal pipes and 25,000 tonnes per annum of spiral welded pipes the statement said 
11575 The longitudinal pipes plant is expected to be complete by the second quarter of September 1997 and the saw arc welded pipes plant by September 1996 it said 
11576 WSRL is part of the Welspun group which has a presence in the cotton yarn terry towels and polyester yarn industry the statement said

11578 India fishermen say forced to carry Tamil refugees 
11579 P.V. Krishnamoorthy 
11580 RAMESWARAM India 1996-08-28 
11581 Indian fishermen said on Wednesday they had been forced at gunpoint to ferry refugees fleeing the ethnic war in Sri Lanka to India as a protest strike by more than 30,000 fishermen entered its ninth day 
11582 There is little we can do when at mid-sea 
11583 The LTTE Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam accosts us and at the point of a gun forces us to take refugees said senior fishermen leader P. Arulanandam 
11584 Some 850 refugees have landed in recent weeks at the port of Rameswaram in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu home to 50 million Tamil-speaking people port officials say 
11585 Rameswaram is 15 km 10 miles off the coast of Sri Lanka 
11586 State chief minister M. Karunanidhi has publicly welcomed the refugees who are fleeing the 13-year war between Tamil separatists and government troops that Colombo says has cost 50,000 lives 
11587 But the influx has triggered fears of a repeat of the 1980s when some 200,000 refugees landed in Tamil Nadu 
11588 Intelligence officals said more than 5,000 Tamils were waiting on the western coast of Sri Lanka to cross into India 
11589 The Indian government has warned its fishermen that their boats would be impounded if they were caught ferrying refugees 
11590 The fishermen went on strike last week to protest the government 's cancellation of three trawlers fishing licenses after the boats were caught carrying Tamil refugees 
11591 All Fishermen 's Association secretary N.J. Bose said the strike would continue indefinitely and the fishermen would block road and rail traffic if their demands were not met 
11592 Until the government releases our boats from naval custody and Sri Lankan naval custody and gives us assurance it will not revoke licences of boats ferrying refugees we will not call off our strike Bose said 
11593 LTTE spokesmen could not immediately be reached for comment but Sri Lankan fishermen denied that Indians were being coerced into carrying refugees across the Palk Strait 
11594 Indian fishermen come right up to Pesalai to fish and when refugees request them to ferry them across they readily oblige 
11595 Only some take money Sri Lankan boatman Chinnathambi said 
11596 Arulanandam denied the fishermen charged the refugees for passage to India and said it was unfair to penalise them for the refugees arrival 
11597 We have not gone to sea since August 19 but refugees are arriving daily nevertheless 
11598 How could we alone be held responsible for the influx ? 
11599 he said 
11600 An Indian Fisheries Department official said the government planned to urge fishermen not to cross the international boundary between India and Sri Lanka but admitted this would be hard to enforce because of Sri Lanka 's pomfret-rich waters

11616 MILTIADIS EVERT HEADS TO ALEXANDROUPOLIS THIS WEEKEND 
11617 ATHENS 1996-08-28 
11618 Conservative New Democracy ND party leader Miltiadis Evert will be hitting the campaign trail and head to Alexandroupolis this weekend to speak to the city 's businessmen on Sunday morning ND said 
11619 Evert will depart for Alexandroupolis on Saturday afternoon 
11620 Prime Minister Costas Simitis criticized Evert today for unleashing a seven-point economic package that offers tax relief to merchants and other professionals higher pensions to farmers and support for small business 
11621 The finance ministry estimated the cost of ND 's economic measures to over 600 billion drachmas but ND officials put the figure much lower to about 300 billion drachmas 
11622 Simitis blamed ND for the low absorption rate of EU funds and said the socialists will increase farmers pensions combat tax evasion and accelerate GDP growth rates to 4.0 percent in a few years 
11623 Faster economic growth is a major component of ND 's economic programme and Evert has repeatedly blamed the socialists for the slow economic growth 
11624 Dimitris Kontogiannis Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4 
11625 Dow pushes London stocks to new record 
11626 Peter Griffiths 
11627 LONDON 1996-08-28 
11628 A firm start on Wall Street helped push leading London shares to a new record high on Wednesday and German stocks closed floor trading up but the Paris bourse slipped sharply hit by a weakening franc and fears of industrial unrest 
11629 On the foreign exchange markets a survey indicating weaker than expected Japanese business sentiment boosted the dollar in early trading but it failed to build on its gains against the yen and slipped lower against the mark in quiet afternoon trade 
11630 London shares boosted by Wall Street added to early gains with the blue chip FTSE 100 index hitting a new peak of 3921.8 before dropping back slightly 
11631 One focus was British Airways which rebounded after fears faded that the cancellation of open skies talks between the U.S. Transportation Department and the British government may jeopardise its tie-up with American Airlines 
11632 The conclusion of an open skies agreement had been made a prerequisite of the proposed link-up by the U.S 
11633 Better-than-expected British trade figures had little impact on equities 
11634 The non-EU July trade deficit totalled 506 million sterling $ 788 million while June 's world deficit was 1.12 billion pounds 
11635 Forecasts were for deficits of 900 million sterling and 1.4 billion sterling 
11636 German shares shed some gains on profit-taking but nonetheless ended the floor session higher buoyed by demand for chemical stocks and a stable dollar 
11637 The 30-share DAX index closed at 2,563.16 points up 4.32 
11638 However French stocks extended opening losses to more than one percent in morning trading falling through the 2000 point resistance level on the main CAC-40 index 
11639 Dealers blamed a weakening franc and worries about the 1997 budget and possible autumn strikes 
11640 Louis Viannet leader of France 's Communist-led CGT union criticised government plans for spending cuts in the 1997 budget on Wednesday and warned of labour unrest as France gets back to work after the holidays 
11641 Later in the day helped by the firmer Wall Street opening Paris climbed back to the 2000 level but still remained well into negative territory 
11642 In foreign exchange the dollar was trading at around 108.40 yen in the European afternoon up from its European close on Tuesday of 107.55 but off the day 's highs 
11643 It had been boosted overnight by the Bank of Japan 's quarterly corporate survey or tankan of major manufacturers an important gauge of business sentiment 
11644 The unexpectedly weak figures convinced markets that Japanese interest rates would stay at rock-bottom levels weakening the yen 
11645 The Japanese discount rate is currently at a record low of 0.5 percent 
11646 The BOJ sought to put the best face on the data which defied economists predictions of improving sentiment and was the first decline in business sentiment in a year 
11647 A BOJ spokesman said the doors to the recovery have not been shut 
11648 the recovery is still continuing 
11649 These remarks gave the yen some backbone and the dollar failed to progress further 
11650 The dollar 's gains were less than spectacular suggesting that while it 's likely to benefit from revised Japanese rate expectations a breakout from the established trading range does n't appear likely said currency economist Klaus Baader 
11651 Dealers said shares were also affected by a slippage in bond prices due to lower than expected June industrial production showing the economy was still faltering 
11652 CURRENCIES AT 1500 GMT 
11653 The dollar was at 108.40 yen and 1.4765 marks compared with Tuesday 's European close of 107.78 yen and 1.4779 marks 
11654 STOCK MARKETS AT 1500 GMT 
11655 The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British shares had risen 15 points to 3,920.7 
11656 In Paris the CAC-40 share index dropped 15.09 to 2,002.9 
11657 The 30-share DAX index in Frankfurt closed up 4.32 at 2,563.16 
11658 PRECIOUS METALS 
11659 Gold fixed at $ 388.50 versus Tuesday 's London close of $ 388.55 
11660 Silver was at 521.15 cents 
11661 $ 1=.6421 Sterling

11663 LONDON 1996-08-28 
11664 Air Express International said in a statement that Spain has become the twenty-second country in its network to achieve ISO 9002 quality accreditation

11667 Arafat says Israel declares war on Palestinians 
11668 Wafa Amr 
11669 RAMALLAH West Bank 1996-08-28 
11670 Palestinian President Yasser Arafat said on Wednesday that Israel had declared war on the Palestinians and called for the first general strike in the West Bank and Gaza in two years 
11671 What happened concerning continuous violations and crimes from this new Israeli leadership means they are declaring a state of war against the Palestinian people Arafat told the Palestinian legislature 
11672 Accusing Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of stupidity Arafat launched his strongest attack on the right-wing government since its election in May 
11673 The tirade was sparked by Israel 's announcement on Tuesday of plans to expand the Jewish settlement of Kiryat Sefer and its demolishing of a community centre in Arab East Jerusalem 
11674 Israel has started the war on Jerusalem 
11675 They are idiots to have started the Jerusalem battle Arafat said in Arabic 
11676 There will be no Palestinian state without Jerusalem 
11677 Netanyahu should know he is stupid to have started this battle 
11678 Arafat called for a general strike for Jerusalem on Thursday in all of the West Bank and Gaza Strip 
11679 There has not been a joint shutdown there since May 1994 when Israeli troops began withdrawing under an interim self-rule agreement signed in 1993 
11680 The strike will have little effect on the Israeli economy while hurting Palestinian merchants in East Jerusalem and Bethlehem who cater to the tourist trade 
11681 Some 25,000 Palestinian labourers are likely to stay away from their jobs mainly in construction in Israel 
11682 But Palestinians once the backbone of the building industry have been largely replaced by labourers from Romania and China 
11683 On Friday all Moslems including Palestinians in Israel 
11684 will go to Jerusalem 's Al-Aqsa mosque and pray 
11685 Jews and Christians who do not pray should accompany them and stand behind them Arafat said 
11686 Officials in Netanyahu 's office were not immediately available for comment on Arafat 's remarks 
11687 Israeli travel restrictions imposed after bombings by Moslem militants in February and March ban most of the two million Arabs in the West Bank and Gaza from entering Jerusalem 
11688 Netanyahu who opposes trading occupied land for peace made Jerusalem a central issue in his election campaign accusing Labour Prime Minister Shimon Peres of planning to hand control of the Arab eastern part of the city to the Palestinians 
11689 Israel captured East Jerusalem in the 1967 Middle East war and claims both halves of the city as its capital 
11690 The PLO wants East Jerusalem as the capital of a future Palestinian state 
11691 In his speech to the crowded legislature Arafat signalled he was not abandoning diplomacy although alarm bells are ringing 
11692 He unexpectedly broke off his address to take a telephone call from U.S. Middle East envoy Dennis Ross who held talks in Paris on Tuesday with Israeli and Egyptian officials 
11693 When Arafat returned to the podium he said senior PLO negotiator Mahmoud Abbas better known as Abu Mazen and Netanyahu aide Dore Gold could meet on Thursday 
11694 He quoted Ross as telling him The important thing is the Israelis are prepared to move 
11695 Arafat said he replied is this like their previous promises ? 
11696 No they have good intentions Arafat quoted Ross as saying 
11697 Palestinians have been pressing Israel to carry out a long-delayed partial troop pullout from the flashpoint West Bank city of Hebron agreed by the previous Labour government 
11698 The Israeli government is studying redeployment plans submitted by Defence Minister Yitzhak Mordechai which are likely to demand a wider than agreed army presence in Hebron 
11699 Turkey 's Ciller to hold talks in Jordan 
11700 ANKARA 1996-08-28 
11701 Turkish Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller will visit Jordan on September 3 on her first trip abroad since she took office in June Foreign Ministry spokesman Omer Akbel said on Wednesday 
11702 The two-day visit will take place at the invitation of Jordanian Prime Minister Abdul-Karim al-Kabariti he told reporters 
11703 He said Turkey considered Jordan a suitable country with which to cooperate on Middle East matters 
11704 Bilateral relations and the Middle East peace process would be on the table during the visit Akbel said 
11705 Turkish Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan visited mainly Moslem countries including Iran during a 10-day tour earlier in August 
11706 Italian prime minister to visit Turkey 
11707 ANKARA 1996-08-28

11709 Both countries governments were formed recently 
11710 This visit will create a direct contact opportunity for the two parties to express their views spokesman Omer Akbel told a news briefing 
11711 The Italian prime minister in office since May 18 will be the first Western leader to meet Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan since he came to power on June 28 
11712 Prodi will also meet President Suleyman Demirel and Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller Akbel said 
11713 Turkey says 25 Kurd rebels killed in clashes 
11714 DIYARBAKIR Turkey 1996-08-28 
11715 Turkish troops killed 25 Kurdish rebels in recent clashes in the east of the country security officials said on Wednesday 
11716 The emergency rule governor 's office said in a statement that 10 rebels from the Kurdistan Workers Party PKK were killed in fighting in Tunceli province 
11717 Soldiers killed nine more PKK guerrillas in Sirnak province and six in Hakkari 
11718 The statement did not report any military casualties and did not say exactly when the clashes took place 
11719 Over 20,000 people have been killed in the PKK 's fight for independence or autonomy in southeastern Turkey

11750 Lamm will not endorse Perot for Reform ticket-CNN 
11751 WASHINGTON 1996-08-27 
11752 Former Colorado Democratic Gov 
11753 Richard Lamm has decided not to endorse Ross Perot as the presidential candidate of the Reform Party CNN reported late Tuesday 
11754 CNN quoted aides and family members as saying Lamm who competed with Perot to head the ticket for Perot 's party had told them he would definitely not endorse Perot but they did not know whether he would endorse another candidate 
11755 An announcement was planned in Chicago Wednesday 
11756 Lamm 60 is a three-term Colorado governor who left office in 1987 and vied for the Reform Party nomination after becoming disillusioned with both the Democratic and Republican parties 
11757 Lamm is a friend of President Clinton and supported him in the 1992 election 
11758 Perot won his party 's official nomination as its presidential candidate in a secret ballot earlier this month

11771 US investors mull appeal of Lloyd 's decision 
11772 Patricia Vowinkel 
11773 NEW YORK 1996-08-27 
11774 U.S. investors in troubled Lloyd 's of London were considering late on Tuesday whether to appeal a U.S. court decision in favour of Lloyd 's and pledged to continue pursuing other legal actions 
11775 A U.S. appeals court on Tuesday gave Lloyd 's a reprieve throwing out an injunction that the insurance giant said could have led to its collapse 
11776 A lower court issued the injunction on Friday and ordered Lloyd 's to give investors known as Names more information before requiring them to decide whether to accept a settlement offer as part of a reorganisation plan 
11777 My prediction is that the Names will appeal said Kenneth Chiate a U.S. Name and a chief negotiator for the American Names Association 
11778 At this point it is a sufficiently important decision that I 'm confident that they will appeal he said 
11779 But to say that they definitely will would be premature until we determine what the exact basis for the court 's ruling is 
11780 Under the reorganisation plan Lloyd 's plans to reinsure its massive liabilities into a new company called Equitas 
11781 The arrangement calls for investors to make additional payments to fund Equitas but also provides them with 3.2 billion stg in compensation to help reduce their prior outstanding liabilities 
11782 The Names had been scheduled to decide whether to accept or reject the offer by 1100 GMT Wednesday but Lloyd 's chairman David Rowland said on Tuesday the offer would be extended 
11783 At least eight U.S. states have still some form of litigation pending said John Head spokesman for the Association of Lloyd 's State Chairmen a group representing U.S. Names 
11784 It goes without saying that we 're rather disappointed Head said of the decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit sitting in Baltimore 
11785 But he said we still have hope that somebody is going to see our point of view in this 
11786 The Colorado attorney general told Lloyd 's last week it was considering a new legal action against the British insurance market based on allegations of consumer fraud 
11787 We have notified them of our concerns and asked them to give us a response said Colorado attorney general Gale Norton 
11788 Norton said she was concerned that the Lloyd 's agreement immunizes it from future litigation regarding Equitas and requires that all legal actions be heard outside of Colorado 
11789 In addition she said she was concerned the plan may not offer investors enough protection from additional future liabilities 
11790 Meanwhile an appeal of a lawsuit filed by some 600 Names in California is still pending before the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit Chiate of the American Names Association said 
11791 That lawsuit which seeks rescision and restitution was dismissed in a U.S. district court 
11792 That case is what I call the most significant alternate remedy for us Chiate said 
11793 The individual Names however now must decide whether to accept Lloyd 's settlement offer or reject the offer and pursue litigation 
11794 Chiate said he has advised Names that they must make individually a risk benefit analysis 
11795 Rejection involved forfeiting the compensation offer and risking the possibility of owing Lloyd 's two to three times more than Lloyd 's is now willing to accept he said 
11796 But in rejecting the offer the Names would retain their rights to pursue litigation he said 
11797 German police made Nazi gestures officials say 
11798 NUREMBERG Germany 1996-08-28 
11799 German riot police made Nazi gestures at a private function earlier this month and may face dismissal for their actions the Bavarian Interior Ministry said on Wednesday 
11800 The ministry declined to detail gestures the Nuremberg-based policemen had made at the August 13 function but added seven had been suspended from duty pending an internal inquiry 
11801 A spokesman for public prosecutors in the southern city where dictator Adolf Hitler held some of his most infamous Nazi party rallies in the 1930s said there were no plans to prosecute the officers as the gestures had not been made in public 
11802 Gun-wielding motorist snapped by cool passenger 
11803 BERLIN 1996-08-28 
11804 A motorist threatened a fellow driver with a starting pistol as he overtook him illegally in the inside lane on a motorway near Berlin and was photographed in the act by the driver 's wife prosecutors said on Wednesday 
11805 Prosecutors in the city of Potsdam said the 32-year-old man drew alongside the other car at about 110 kph 70 mph and aimed his pistol at the driver 
11806 But the driver 's wife kept her nerve got out her camera and photographed him 
11807 The man has been charged with dangerous driving coercion and threatening behaviour 
11808 German prosecutors file sex tourism charges 
11809 BERLIN 1996-08-28 
11810 Berlin prosecutors said on Wednesday they had filed charges against two German men for sexually abusing children in Thailand and distributing pornographic films and pictures of their degrading acts 
11811 The case is one of only a handful in which authorities have managed to track down suspects under a law which lets them pursue Germans who commit sex offences abroad 
11812 The pair identified only as 43-year-old clerk Dieter U and businessman Thomas S 33 are alleged to have carried out acts of sexual indecency with children as young as 10 years old between 1994 and 1995 
11813 Their videos included pictures of one of the accused tying up a Thai boy and performing acts of sadistic torture on him prosecutors said in a statement 
11814 In another scene a young girl performed oral sex with an unidentified adult man 
11815 The new law was introduced with much fanfare in 1993 
11816 But prosecutors face huge difficulties in gathering evidence and bringing witnesses to testify in a German court and only one person has so far been convicted under the law 
11817 Investigators are probing several other cases 
11818 The Berlin prosecutors said they had been alerted to the two men by customs officials who intercepted packages containing pornographic photographs and order forms

11841 Stephanie of Monaco 's husband snapped cavorting 
11842 ROME 1996-08-28 
11843 Two Italian magazines published pictures on Wednesday of Daniel Ducruet Princess Stephanie of Monaco 's husband and former bodyguard cavorting naked with another woman by a poolside in France 
11844 The magazines Eva Tremila and its sister publication Gente printed up to 26 pages of photos of the woman undressing Ducruet the pair embracing on a sunbed and finally both naked 
11845 Eva Tremila said other even more explicit photos were taken but it did not print them 
11846 The magazines named the woman as Fili Houteman a 26-year-old French singer and dancer in a Belgian cabaret club 
11847 The photographs an Italian exclusive raised eyebrows in the tiny principality where Stephanie 's father Prince Rainier had long disapproved of his daughter 's choice of husband 
11848 Stephanie had two children with Ducruet before their marriage in July last year 
11849 Stephanie Caroline and Albert are the children of Rainier and former Hollywood screen goddess Grace Kelly who was killed in a car crash in 1982 
11850 We have seen the photos but for the moment the palace has no comment a spokeswoman for Prince Rainier told Reuters 
11851 The magazines said the photographs were taken in Cap de Villefranche some 15 km nine miles from Monte Carlo 
11852 Gente said Ducruet a keen racing driver met Houteman during a race in Belgium and photographers had been on their trail ever since 
11853 The magazine said video cameras had also been used to film the couple and that a sound-track existed

11865 Spanish tomato warriors paint the town red 
11866 BUNOL Spain 1996-08-28 
11867 Revellers painted the town red on Wednesday as the 1996 edition of the world 's biggest tomato fight began in the eastern Spanish village of Bunol 
11868 Thousands of people pelted each other with armfuls of ripe tomatoes as streets walls and windows were coated in a blood-red wash 
11869 A single firework after midday signalled the start of the fruit-throwing frenzy during which participants hurl some 100 tonnes of tomatoes trucked in for the occasion 
11870 Local historians say the tradition began in 1945 when disgruntled locals began spontaneously to bombard the priest and mayor at the annual fiesta in Bunol pronounced Boo-nee-OL 
11871 The festival 's fame has grown and now attracts between 15,000 and 20,000 people many of them foreigners

11904 LONDON 1996-08-28 
11905 British bus and passenger rail operator Stagecoach Holdings Plc said on Wednesday that its negotiations to acquire Swedish long distance bus operator Swebus AB were set to lead to a signed agreement next week 
11906 Four weeks ago Stagecoach said it had agreed the deal in principle and it expected to pay 110 million stg-plus for the firm with Swebus current owner the state railway company

11909 NZ bills gain ground after see-saw session 
11910 WELLINGTON 1996-08-28 
11911 0515 GMT 
11912 The New Zealand money market gained slightly at Wednesday 's close after what dealers described as a see-saw trading session 
11913 Ninety-day bank bill rates shed five points to 9.93 percent and September bank bill futures rose four to 90.18 
11914 However bonds finished largely flat 
11915 Our bonds were better bid initially but they sold off on a lack of demand and the short end went with it too on a lower currency 
11916 There were big buyers at the base of where the market sold to and when the currency got bought back on talk of a samurai the market got bought back again a dealer said 
11917 Volumes were reasonable in the money market but thin in bonds 
11918 Dealers said the market seemed to be trading a range and would wait for more political polls to provide direction 
11919 They were confident of further eurokiwi issuance but said the timing was less of a certainty

11921 RTRS Guinness Peat expects strong full yr 
11922 SYDNEY 1996-08-28 
11923 British-based investment company Guinness Peat Group Plc GPG said on Wednesday it expected a strong full year result 
11924 We think we 're in a position to produce a strong result however a lot of our profitability must inevitably depend on a number of company results said GPG director Garry Weiss 
11925 GPG earlier said its net profit for the six months to June 30 rose to 9.77 million pounds from 6.93 million in the previous first half 
11926 The company did not declare an interim dividend as in the previous year 
11927 Weiss said the Australian share market had been somewhat negative for much of 1996 and this had some effect on the company 's first half results 
11928 However it certainly is a very pleasing result for the first six months he said 
11929 Weiss said most of the company 's half year earning stemmed from the sale of its 50 percent stake in Physicians Insurance Co of Ohio 
11930 He said the company decided to sell its U.S. investment in order to consolidate investments closer to its administrative base 
11931 GPG said its stakes in Tyndall Australia Ltd and Mid-East Minerals Ltd both contributed strongly to GPG 's first half earnings 
11932 Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800 
11933 RTRS Newcrest Q4 net profit A$ 4.3 mln 
11934 SYDNEY 1996-08-28 
11935 Gold miner Newcrest Mining Ltd said on Wednesday it posted a A$ 4.3 million profit after tax in the final quarter of the year to June 30 1996 
11936 Earlier Newcrest reported a drop in net profit after abnormals to A$ 20.81 million for the year from A$ 42.4 million the previous year 
11937 Newcrest said earnings from the Telfer and Boddington mines were lower than the previous year due to lower head grades at the mines forcing gold production lower 
11938 Production costs also rose eight percent during the year to A$ 406 per ounce 
11939 RTRS Queensland gunman evades police in bush hunt 
11940 BRISBANE 1996-08-28 
11941 Australian police on Wednesday continued to hunt a gunman in dense bushland after he killed his wife and wounded three other people warning the man is extremely dangerous and may take a hostage to escape 
11942 The shooting occured around 6.30 a.m. 2030 GMT on Tuesday at Glenwood south of Maryborough about 150 km 93 miles north of Brisbane on the Queensland state coast 
11943 Police have declared an emergent situation in the area giving them powers to raid houses search cars close schools quarantine the area and evacuate people 
11944 It is one step short of an emergency situation a police spokesman said via telephone from a command post in the bush 
11945 We have not had any sightings but we suspect he is armed possibly with a .22 rifle and or a self-loading shotgun 
11946 He is considered extremely dangerous he said 
11947 It 's a possibility not a probability he may take a hostage but we have measures in place if that is the case 
11948 William Fox broke into his wife 's home on Tuesday morning shooting her dead and wounding his 16-year-old son his son 's girlfriend and a neighbour police said 
11949 All three wounded are in a satisfactory condition in hospital 
11950 Fox initially fled from the shooting in a car but then abandoned the car and entered dense bushland 
11951 Fox is a skilled bushman who knows the area very well police said 
11952 About 60 police helicopters and fixed-wing aircraft have maintained an overnight cordon around 15 sq km six sq miles of bush near Glenwood 
11953 The area is littered with caves and police believed Fox has a hideout which has enabled him to evade capture 
11954 Australia 's six states and two territories are involved in heated debate over the introduction of tough new firearm laws including the banning rapid fire weapons after a shooting massacre in the island state of Tasmania 
11955 On April 28 a lone gunman went on a shooting rampage at the site of the historic Port Arthur penal settlement killing 35 people 
11956 Shanghai Ek Chor opens new motorcyle plant 
11957 SHANGHAI 1996-08-28 
11958 Shanghai-Ek Chor Motorcycle Co a Sino-Thai joint venture opened a new plant to produce gasoline engines in the Pudong New Area of Shanghai the Xinhua news agency reported on Wednesday 
11959 The plant requiring an investment of three billion baht has a floor space of 50,000 square metres and is designed to produce 600,000 gasoline engines a year to be sold in China South America the Middle East and Africa it said 
11960 Capacity is expected to reach one million engines by the year 2000 it said 
11961 Shanghai-Ek Chor is jointly owned by the Shanghai Automobile Corporation and Ek Chor China Motorcycle 
11962 It started operations in January 1985 and has registered capital of 1.56 billion baht it said but gave no further details 
11963 The joint venture has two motorcycle plants making Xingfu motorcycles and aims to be China 's biggest producer by the year 2000 with output of two million units 
11964 Khmer Rouge 's Ieng Sary confirms break with Pol Pot 
11965 ARANYAPRATHET Thailand 1996-08-28 
11966 Dissident Khmer Rouge leader Ieng Sary confirmed on Wednesday that he had broken with Pol Pot and other hardliners of the guerrilla group and had formed a rival movement 
11967 Ieng Sary said in a written statement the first since his split with Pol Pot earlier this month that the new movement to be called the Democratic National United Movement DNUM would seek an end to civil war and work towards reconciliation with the Cambodian government 
11968 I would like to inform you about my decision to break away from Pol Pot Ta Mok Son Sen 's dictatorial group he said in a copy of the statement obtained by Reuters 
11969 We believe that our country will be reduced to nothing if the Khmer people continue to fight against each other indefinitely .... 
11970 For this reason we decided to break away from that dictatorial group and found a movement named Democratic National United Movement he said 
11971 Ieng Sary was sentenced to death in absentia for his role in the mass genocide in Cambodia during the Khmer Rouge rule of terror between 1975-1979 when over a million people were executed or died of starvation disease or overwork in mass labour camps 
11972 The French-educated former brother-in-law of Pol Pot was foreign minister in the Khmer Rouge government that ruled Cambodia and was seen as the group 's second in command 
11973 Two dead in Cambodia helicopter crash 
11974 PHNOM PENH 1996-08-28 
11975 Two people were killed and six were injured after a helicopter crashed in bad weather in northern Cambodia a government minister said on Wednesday 
11976 The 15 survivors who had been on board the Russian-made MI-17 helicopter were taken to hospital from the remote jungle crash site about 150 km 90 miles north of Phnom Penh Information Minister Ieng Mouly said 
11977 The cause of the crash of the helicopter which went down on Sunday while on a routine resupply flight between Phnom Penh and Stung Treng was not known 
11978 Ieng Mouly said the aircraft went down during a rain storm 
11979 MOF 's Kubo says believes BOJ rate policy unchanged 
11980 TOKYO 1996-08-28 
11981 Japan 's Finance Minister Wataru Kubo told a news conference on Wednesday that he believes that the Bank of Japan 's BOJ interest rate policy which is geared towards ensuring economic growth has not changed after the release of the central bank 's tankan survey 
11982 The BOJ released the August tankan its quarterly short-term corporate survey in the morning and it showed business outlook had worsened 
11983 However Kubo said it did not necessarily show a substantial worsening of the economy 
11984 The question is what the BOJ is going to do with its interest rate policy 
11985 The BOJ governor has made it clear that the BOJ 's policy is aimed at ensuring basis for economic recovery 
11986 I believe this policy has not changed he said 
11987 Asked if a supplementary budget for 1996/97 was needed to support the economy Kubo said the tankan results would not lead to any immediate decision on the need for an extra budget 
11988 I do n't think we should immediately draw a conclusion that the economic recovery has come to a halt or that signs of a economic contraction have emerged Kubo said 
11989 The economy is not recovering smoothly or at a fast pace 
11990 Kubo said he would make a decision on the need for a supplementary budget after an announcement in mid-September of Japan 's gross domestic product for the April-June quarter 
11991 I would like to see how the economy moved in the first half of 1996 he said 
11992 China says militant Japan must face war past 
11993 BEIJING 1996-08-28 
11994 China on Wednesday called on Japan to acknowledge its wartime past and put a stop to a tide of resurgent militarism to prevent similar atrocities in future 
11995 Some Japanese are still unrepentant about the atrocities committed by the Japanese militarists during the war said a commentary in the official China Daily 
11996 If they are still undecided whether the war Japan launched was aggressive in nature it will be difficult to tell whether they will do the same again the newspaper said 
11997 China raised indignant protests after several Japanese cabinet ministers visited a shrine dedicated to their country 's war dead on August 15 the 51st anniversary of Japan 's World War Two surrender 
11998 Numerous Japanese politicians have tried to whitewash their country 's war atrocities in recent years the commentary said 
11999 China estimates 35 million Chinese were killed or wounded by invading Japanese troops from 1931 to 1945 
12000 The Japanese have never genuinely apologised for their wartime crimes the commentary said 
12001 Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto marked the August 15 anniversary by expressing remorse for foreign victims of Japan 's World War Two atrocities 
12002 Japan coalition party leader plans to resign 
12003 TOKYO 1996-08-28 
12004 The leader of a junior partner in Japan 's three-party ruling coalition plans to resign to quell a political rebellion party officials said on Wednesday 
12005 The officials said New Party Sakigake President Masayoshi Takemura finance minister until the beginning of this year promised his resignation in a meeting with the politician who set off the rebellion in the smallest coalition member 
12006 They said the date of Takemura 's resignation would be determined by party officials 
12007 The Sakigake row has caused jitters in its coalition partners Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto 's Liberal Democratic Party LDP the biggest grouping and the Social Democratic Party 
12008 But analysts said the row was not expected to immediately destabilise the government as even if Sakigake splits apart it has so few seats a loss of support would not lead to a general election 
12009 The dispute pits Takemura who founded Sakigake in 1993 as a reform-oriented LDP splinter group against party official Yukio Hatoyama who says he will leave Sakigake to form a reformist political group next month 
12010 Hatoyama the 49-year-old grandson of a 1950s prime minister on Tuesday quit as Sakigake secretary general and has publicly snubbed the 62-year-old Takemura pointedly ruling his mentor out as a possible member of the new political force 
12011 Marathon talks between the two former allies on Tuesday night and Wednesday morning failed to resolve the dispute over the role of Takemura seen by Hatoyama backers as tainted by his senior role in the LDP-dominated coalition 
12012 The presence of Takemura whose role as finance minister in passing an unpopular plan to use taxpayer funds to wind up failed housing loan firms ruined his reputation as a reformer has stalled Hatoyama 's efforts to attract to his new group defectors from the opposition camp analysts said 
12013 Media reports say that at most 10 of 23 Sakigake members joined by a handful of Social Democrats will follow Hatoyama when he bolts far short of the 50 lawmakers needed to topple Hashimoto 's eight-month-old government 
12014 Hashimoto who returns from a 10-day Latin American tour on Saturday must call polls by mid-1997 and has repeatedly said he would not call an early general election 
12015 But many analysts and politicians believe he may dissolve parliament soon after it reconvenes in early October

12037 Shanghai novelist murdered at home 
12038 SHANGHAI 1996-08-28 
12039 A Shanghai novelist was murdered at her home on Sunday an official of the city 's Writers Association said on Wednesday 
12040 The victim was Dai Houying who wrote about China 's 1966-76 leftist Cultural Revolution and the lives of Chinese intellectuals the official said 
12041 The killing was under investigation she said 
12042 She gave no further details 
12043 Born in 1937 in the central province of Anhui Dai came to Shanghai as a student and remained in the city as a prolific author and teacher of Chinese 
12044 She was divorced and lived alone leaving one daughter who received university education in Hawaii and lives in Chicago a friend said 
12045 Dai 's most famous book Ren A Ren People People was translated into German and English he said

12064 With 307 days to go before the British colony reverts to China the Hong Kong media focused mainly on domestic issues concerning alleged pressure on a judge cross straights relations and the democratic lobby 's relationship with Beijing 
12065 The Beijing-funded WEN WEI PO said Taiwan 's government could not hope to stem the island 's economic and trade exchanges with China 
12066 The paper said that using administrative power to limit economic activities across the Taiwan strait would not work 
12067 MING PAO DAILY NEWS said it hoped Chinese officials would soon open dialogue with Hong Kong 's Democratic Party and the newly-established democracy lobby Frontier in order to ease anxieties in the lead-up to the handover 
12068 The English language SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST said the judiciary needed to take swift and decisive action in investigating the allegations that a judge had been subjected to pressure in a New Zealand immigration case involving allegations of fraud 
12069 The independence of the judiciary and the rule of law were of paramount importance to Hong Kong 's survival as a business centre 
12070 The Chinese language daily HONG KONG ECONOMIC TIMES said the Legal Department had been indecisive in its handling of the judge 's case 
12071 Such hesitancy on the part of the government had damaged public confidence in the rule of law the paper said

12099 Iran asks Bonn to extradite ex-president Banisadr 
12100 BONN 1996-08-28 
12101 Iran has asked Germany to extradite its former president Abolhassan Banisadr for alleged hijacking an Iranian embassy spokesman said on Wednesday 
12102 Banisadr angered Tehran last week by accusing top Iranian leaders of ordering the assassination of Iranian Kurdish leaders in a Berlin restaurant in 1992 
12103 He made the allegations at the trial of an Iranian and four Lebanese accused of carrying out the attack 
12104 An Iranian embassy spokesman said in response to an inquiry that Iran had formally requested Banisadr 's extradition for hijacking the military aircraft which he commandeered to flee Iran in July 1981 
12105 We submitted the request three or four days ago he said 
12106 German authorities could not immediately be reached for comment 
12107 Banisadr lives under round-the-clock security in France fearing Tehran could make an attempt on his life 
12108 He is due back in Berlin on September 5 to continue his testimony which has backed up German prosecutors allegations that Tehran ordered the attack on the exiled leaders 
12109 Three dissidents and their translator were killed in the gangland-style machinegun attack 
12110 Iran has warned Germany that bilateral relations could suffer if it pays heed to the testimony of Banisadr an architect of Iran 's Islamic revolution who has been a sworn enemy of Tehran since he fell from favour after a year as president 
12111 NATO military chiefs to visit Iberia 
12112 BRUSSELS 1996-08-28 
12113 Top military officials from North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries will tour Spain and Portugal next month for their annual inspection of alliance country installations and forces 
12114 NATO said in a statement received on Wednesday that its military committee would visit the two countries between September 8 and 13 
12115 The committee consists of the chiefs of defence staff of each alliance country except Iceland which has no armed forces 
12116 NATO 's top military men General George Joulwan Supreme Allied Commander Europe and General John Sheehan Supreme Allied Commander Atlantic will also attend 
12117 The committee 's last tour was in September 1995 in Belgium Luxembourg and the Netherlands

12119 ISS says agreed sale of U.S. unit 
12120 COPENHAGEN 1996-08-28 
12121 Danish cleaning group ISS on Wednesday said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its troubled U.S unit ISS Inc to Canadian firm Aaxis Limited 
12122 An ISS statement said that Aaxis with year-end 1996 assets of US$ 10.9 million and equity of $ 10.5 million would be listed on the Montreal stock exchange but did not say when 
12123 It said that under the sale agreement full financial details of which were not revealed ISS would acquire a 25 percent stake in Aaxis which would become an associated company within the ISS group trading under the ISS name and logo 
12124 ISS Inc senior management would continue to run the business under the new owners it said 
12125 Danish analysts recently estimated ISS Inc 's sale value at up to $ 118 million 
12126 ISS said that the deal included ISS Inc operations in Mexico and the sale of ISS Inc interests in Brazil would be discussed 
12127 On August 15 ISS published first half 1996 results showing a two billion crown loss caused by falsified accounts in ISS Inc and said that charges and provisions earlier estimated at $ 100 million would have to be increased to $ 146 million 
12128 It also wrote down all ISS Inc goodwill and Wednesday 's statement said that the Aaxis purchase would not necessitate further write down if the sale were completed according to the terms of the letter of intent 
12129 Steve Weizman Copenhagen newsroom +45 33969650 
12130 Iraq balks at U.N. staff for oil-for-food deal 
12131 Evelyn Leopold 
12132 UNITED NATIONS 1996-08-28 
12133 Iraq has balked at the number of U.N. staff needed to implement the oil-for-food deal blaming the United States for insisting on stringent monitoring 
12134 In comments to reporters and a statement on Tuesday Iraqi diplomats said the cost of the monitors and other staff which Baghdad has to finance surpasses funds allocated for electricity water sewers education and agriculture 
12135 At issue was a May 20 agreement allowing Iraq to sell $ 2 billion worth of oil to purchase badly needed food medicine and other supplies to ease the impact of sanctions in force since its troops invaded Kuwait in August 1990 
12136 The Iraqi statement said the United States was interfering and pressing to augment the number of international staff and this is not legal and not justified 
12137 Iraq 's deputy ambassador Saeed Hasan noted that the May 20 accord said that the number of personnel would be determined by the United Nations and that the government of Iraq would be consulted 
12138 Saeed in his comments did not threaten to call off the deal and the U.N. officials said they expected it to go into force next month after Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali reports that arrangements are in place 
12139 The U.N. Department of Humanitarian Affairs DHA which has to coordinate the distribution of food medicine and other goods increased the number of monitors earlier this month at the insistence of the United States 
12140 According to U.N. officials and diplomats Iraq would have about $ 1.13 billion to spend for food medicine and other goods after monies for a reparations fund for Gulf War victims and costs for U.N. weapons inspections were deducted 
12141 The cost of the U.N. staff overseeing the distribution of food and other supplies was estimated to cost $ 31 million 
12142 In addition another $ 12 million was anticipated to cover other expenses such as oil experts and administrative costs 
12143 For the distribution and supervision of humanitarian supplies the United Nations estimated it needed 1,190 people including 267 international staff and 923 Iraqi support staff 
12144 Of this number 64 foreign and 598 local staff would be in the northern Kurdish provinces no longer the direct control of the Baghdad government 
12145 Another 203 international staff and 325 Iraqis would run the programme in the central and southern parts of the country 
12146 There are also 14 monitors to watch oil flows 32 customs experts and four New York-based oil experts or overseers to approve contracts 
12147 Yasushi Akashi the DHA undersecretary-general told the Security Council last week that the financial requirements to support the humanitarian programme represent a very modest percentile of the total 
12148 roughly 3 percent

12162 EU Commission cool on changing beef cull plan 
12163 BRUSSELS 1996-08-29 
12164 The European Commission said on Thursday it would study scientific reports saying Britain 's mad cow epidemic would die out by 2001 but offered little prospect the findings would change an agreed slaughter campaign 
12165 Obviously we are interested in this research 
12166 We will ask the EU scientific and veterinary committee to examine it Commission spokesman Gerard Kiely told Reuters 
12167 But he added that new research into the dynamics of the bovine spongiform encephalopathy BSE a fatal brain-wasting disease suffered by cattle was unlikely to alter a slaughter plan agreed by Britain and its 14 EU partners 
12168 We agreed that following detailed scientific analysis using a methodology which would take out the maximum number of BSE cases possible 
12169 I think it would be very difficult to sell to the European Commission a programme which would involve the elimination of fewer BSE cases Kiely said 
12170 We will look at our approach to the plan but we wo n't get involved with the number of animals to be slaughtered he said 
12171 We have always avoided the question of numbers of animals to be slaughtered that 's not the issue 
12172 The issue is the protection of consumers health and the rapid eradication of BSE he added 
12173 The reaction is likely to disappoint British farmers who seized on research by Oxford scientists in the scientific journal Nature saying it would be hard to get rid of the disease any faster than 2001 without killing vast numbers of cattle 
12174 The researchers predicted there would be 340 new infections and 14,000 new cases of BSE before 2001 
12175 British farmers leader called on Wednesday for an urgent meeting with ministers to discuss the report 
12176 I hope the government will now make it clear they believe there is a better way of dealing with this issue National Farmers Union president Sir David Naish told BBC radio 
12177 Naish said there was no need for Britain to carry out a planned cull of some 147,000 cattle to which it had reluctantly agreed to placate its European partners 
12178 The new evidence to me means some of that proposal should be re-examined because we could get away with considerably less animals being culled if in fact scientists throughout Europe accepted this evidence Naish said 
12179 The report could well reopen a damaging row between Britain and the EU which slapped a worldwide ban on British beef after the government said there could be a link between BSE and the human form of the disease 
12180 The issue flared in in March when government scientists admitted that people could become infected with Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease CJD from eating BSE-infected beef 
12181 French farmers set up blockades in mad cow protest 
12182 PARIS 1996-08-29 
12183 Thousands of farmers threw up roadblocks across France overnight stopping and checking lorries suspected of importing meat from outside the European Union French radios reported on Thursday 
12184 Radio stations said around 15,000 farmers angered by a fall in beef prices following the mad cow disease crisis staged protests in many areas and blockaded several main roads and motorways 
12185 By 3 a.m. 0100 GMT more than 2,000 lorries had been stopped and searched 
12186 European beef sales plunged after Britain announced the discovery of a likely link between bovine spongiform encephalopathy BSE or mad cow disease and its fatal human equivalent Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease CJD

12270 CRICKET CROFT RESTRICTS PAKISTAN TO 225-5 
12271 MANCHESTER England 1996-08-29 
12272 Tight bowling from Glamorgan off-spinner Robert Croft helped England to restrict Pakistan to 225 for five in their 50 overs in the first one-day international at Old Trafford on Thursday 
12273 Croft who was one of the few Englishmen to make a good impression in his test debut at The Oval last week showed great control as he first dried up the early flow of Pakistan runs and then collected the wickets of Aamir Sohail and Wasim Akram in a spell of 10-1-36-2 
12274 There was also a wicket each for Ronnie Irani Allan Mullally and Darren Gough although there was no joy for Dean Headley who along with Lancashire batsman Graham Lloyd was making his international debut 
12275 After Wasim had won the toss and chosen to bat first Pakistani made an excellent start as Sohail and Saeed Anwar continued their good form with an opening partnership of 82 
12276 Anwar who struck a superb 176 at The Oval was the more aggressive as he made 57 from 75 balls before skying a catch off Irani to Mullally at long-on 
12277 Sohail and Ijaz Ahmed then added 59 for the second wicket before England struck back with three wickets for 19 in the space of five overs 
12278 First Sohail after making 48 was bowled by Croft as he stepped back to try and hit through the off-side 
12279 Wasim who promoted himself to number four in the order followed for six when Croft drifted another well-flighted delivery behind his legs 
12280 Shortly after Ijaz was also back in the pavilion for 48 after Irani had repaid Mullally with another good catch at long-on 
12281 Gough later bowled Moin Khan with an inswinging yorker but Inzamam-ul-Haq 37 not out and Salim Malik took Pakistan to 225 for five when the overs ran out
