12364 RUGBY UNION TELFER CONFIRMED FOR LIONS COACHING ROLE 
12365 LONDON 1996-08-30 
12366 Scotland 's Jim Telfer was officially confirmed on Thursday as assistant coach for the British Lions tour to South Africa next year 
12367 Telfer who has put on hold his role as Scotland team manager for a year will act as assistant to Ian McGeechan 
12368 The pair last worked together when Scotland won the Five Nations grand slam in 1990 
12369 The tour party will be announced towards the end of March 
12370 ATHLETICS CHRISTIE TO RUN IN BERLIN 
12371 LONDON 1996-08-29 
12372 Linford Christie has confirmed he will run in a Dream Team sprint relay at the Berlin grand prix athletics meeting on Friday 
12373 A spokeswoman for Christie said the former Olympic 100 metres champion had agreed to captain a quality quartet which also includes Canada 's Donovan Bailey the current Olympic champion and world record holder and Namibian Frankie Fredericks 
12374 Christie is retiring from international competition at the end of the season but Berlin promoter Rudi Thiel has persuaded him to join what is intended to be a special tribute to Jesse Owens who won four gold medals 60 years ago at the Berlin Olympics 
12375 SOCCER GROBBELAAR NAMED TEMPORARY ZIMBABWE COACH 
12376 HARARE 1996-08-29 
12377 England-based goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar has been appointed temporary head coach of the Zimbabwe national soccer team for two international matches the Zimbabwe Football Association ZIFA said on Thursday 
12378 ZIFA vice-chairman Vincent Pamire said Grobbelaar would take charge for a match against Tanzania in Harare on September 29 in the five-nation Castle Cup of Africa tournament and an African Nations Cup first round qualifier against Sudan in Khartoum on October 5 
12379 Grobbelaar takes over until a permanent replacement is appointed for Zimbabwe 's previous coach Switzerland 's Marc Duvillard 
12380 Grobbelaar now plays for English second division leaders Plymouth Argyle after years in the top flight with Liverpool and Southampton 
12381 Grobbelaar fellow goalkeeper Hans Segers retired striker John Fashanu and Malaysian businessman Heng Suan Lim pleaded not guilty in May to charges of giving or accepting bribes to fix English premier league matches 
12382 They are due to stand trial next January

12543 BASEBALL YANKEES BRAWL AND CONTINUE TO SLIDE 
12544 SEATTLE 1996-08-29 
12545 Jay Buhner hit a three-run homer and former Yankee Terry Mulholland allowed one run over seven innings as the Seattle Mariners completed a sweep of New York with a 10-2 victory in a game marred by a bench-clearing brawl 
12546 Including the last three games of last October 's Divisional Playoff Series the Mariners have beaten the Yankees 12 of the past 15 meetings overall and 14 of the last 16 in the Kingdome 
12547 Five players were ejected after Yankees outfielder Paul O'Neill and Seattle catcher John Marzano got into a fight after O'Neill had been brushed back 
12548 In Baltimore Don Wengert threw a nine-hitter for his first shutout and Jose Herrera had a two-run double in a three-run fifth inning as the Oakland Athletics blanked the Baltimore Orioles 3-0 
12549 Wengert 7-9 who failed to record a shutout in his previous 86 starts in either the minors or majors did not walk a batter and struck out three for Oakland 
12550 In Chicago James Baldwin scattered five hits over seven scoreless innings and Ray Durham and Ozzie Guillen had RBI hits in the second inning as the Chicago White Sox blanked the Milwaukee Brewers 2-0 
12551 Baldwin 10-4 struck out four and did not walk a batter for Chicago which won for only the fourth time in 15 games 
12552 Dave Nilsson had three hits for the Brewers 
12553 In Kansas City Jose Offerman 's single with two out in the 12th inning scored Johnny Damon with the winning run and lifted the Kansas City Royals to a 4-3 victory over the Texas Rangers 
12554 Rick Huisman 1-1 allowed one hit and a walk in the 12th to post his first major-league win 
12555 In Toronto Pat Hentgen tossed a five-hitter for his fifth consecutive complete game and three players drove in two runs apiece as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the Minnesota Twins 6-1 for their ninth win in 11 games 
12556 Hentgen 17-7 surrendered just three doubles and a pair of singles in tossing his major-league leading ninth complete game 
12557 He walked three and struck out three in winning for the 10th time in his last 11 decisions 
12558 In Detroit Orel Hershiser recorded his fourth straight win and Albert Belle snapped a sixth-inning tie with a grand slam as the Cleveland Indians completed a season sweep of the Detroit Tigers with a 9-3 victory 
12559 Hershiser 14-7 who allowed three runs eight hits and one walk with five strikeouts over seven innings improved to 4-0 in his last six starts including a pair of wins over Detroit in the last 11 days

12561 In Seattle

12582 TENNIS MARTINEZ GETS AGGRESSIVE AT U.S. OPEN 
12583 Larry Fine 
12584 NEW YORK 1996-08-28 
12585 Conchita Martinez decided that when in New York do as the New Yorkers do and the Spaniard 's new-found aggressiveness seems to have put her in the right frame of mind for the U.S. Open 
12586 The fourth-seeded Spaniard who is tackling the world class traffic of New York City as a warm-up by driving to the tennis centre for her matches ran over France 's Nathalie Tauziat 6-1 6-3 on Wednesday to take her place in the third round 
12587 I 've been trying my whole career to be aggressive said the 24-year-old Martinez after crushing Tauziat in just over an hour 
12588 What I 'm trying to do is be aggressive all the time maybe go up to the net a few times like I did tonight 
12589 That would really help 
12590 Martinez the 1994 Wimbledon champion used to struggle at the Open but has come to terms with the noise crowds and chaos 
12591 There is a lot of things that can happen Martinez said about her early difficulties adjusting to tennis on the cement at Flushing Meadows 
12592 Like traffic 
12593 We stay in Manhattan and it 's a long way to come 
12594 The crowds they speak louder or they move 
12595 That does n't happen in other Grand Slams 
12596 That 's where the real champion wins 
12597 You have to concentrate for these two weeks 
12598 It took Martinez four Opens to get as far as the quarters and another four to match that 
12599 Last year Martinez who finished 1995 ranked second in the world reached the semifinals before bowing out to Monica Seles 
12600 Now she feels she is in the swing of things 
12601 I have my own car now and that helps said Martinez 
12602 Sometimes the transportation they the tournament provide gets a little messed up 
12603 This time it did n't happen 
12604 I do the driving and I love it 
12605 It gets my adrenalin going those taxi drivers 
12606 We change lanes all the time in Barcelona 
12607 I 'm used to it and I like to drive fast 
12608 BASEBALL BRAVES SIGN NEAGLE 
12609 ATLANTA 1996-08-28 
12610 The defending world champion Atlanta Braves with the best record and best pitching in baseball added another weapon Wednesday acquiring Denny Neagle the winningest left-hander in the National League from the Pittsburgh Pirates 
12611 The Pirates who conceded earlier this week they would be forced to trim salary from next season 's payroll received Ron Wright a first baseman at Double-A Greenville ; Corey Pointer a pitcher at Class-A Eugene and a player to be named 
12612 It was another stunning mid-season acquisition for the Braves who already have an 11-game lead in the National League Eastern Division 
12613 In the last 15 days Atlanta has traded for third baseman Terry Pendleton claimed outfielder Luis Polonia on waivers and called up minor-league phenom Andruw Jones all in preparation for their fifth post-season

12655 ATHLETICS JOHNSON CHRISTIE BAILEY TO RUN OWENS RELAY 
12656 Adrian Warner 
12657 BERLIN 1996-08-29 
12658 Olympic champions Michael Johnson and Donovan Bailey and former champion Linford Christie will run in a Dream Team sprint relay squad in honour of Jesse Owens on Friday 
12659 Johnson the 200 metres world record holder and Britain 's 1992 Olympic 100 champion Christie confirmed on Thursday that they would join 100 record holder Bailey and Namibia 's Frankie Fredericks in one of the greatest 4x100 squads ever assembled 
12660 They will run against quartets from the United States Europe and Africa in a special race at the Berlin Grand Prix meeting to mark the 60th anniversary of Owens 's four gold medals at the 1936 Olympics in the German capital 
12661 Christie will run the anchor leg after Canada 's Bailey American Johnson and Olympic silver medallist Fredericks have run the first three stages of the relay 
12662 The participation of Bailey and Fredericks had been known before Thursday 
12663 But Christie did not announce his decision to run until the eve of the meeting when organisers also confirmed Johnson would take part 
12664 Christie is due to retire from international competition at the end of the season although he may compete for Britain in next season 's European Cup 
12665 Although Christie who is not racing the individual 100 metres in Berlin took his time to agree to run the veteran was clearly delighted to be part of the tribute to the black American 
12666 When five former Olympic 100 champions from 1948 to 1980 who have been invited to watch the race turned up at a news conference on Thursday Christie was quick to put his autograph book in front of the them 
12667 I do n't normally do this but can you please sign he said thrusting an ornate white book in front of Americans Harrison Dillard 1948 Lindy Remigino 1952 Jim Hines 1968 Trinidad 's Hasely Crawford 1976 and Britain 's Allan Wells 1980 
12668 Jesse Owens inspired everyone here and it is great to have a tribute to him 
12669 Owens 's widow Ruth is not well enough to attend but a message from her will be read out by the sprinter 's grand-daughter Gina Tillman during the meeting 
12670 Berlin organisers hoped to have American 1984 and 1988 champion Carl Lewis in the squad but he injured himself in last Friday 's Brussels meeting 
12671 SOCCER GENOA AWARDED ITALIAN CUP WIN 
12672 MILAN 1996-08-29 
12673 Italian soccer 's sports judge on Thursday ruled that Genoa beaten 3-0 by Lecce in the first round of the Italian Cup should be awarded a 2-0 victory because their opponents fielded a banned player 
12674 The ruling meant that serie B club Genoa now meet local serie A arch-rivals Sampdoria in the second round 
12675 Genoa appealed after their defeat last Saturday on the grounds that Lecce striker Jonathan Bachini who came on in the 71st minute with his team leading 2-0 still had a one-match suspension to serve from last season 
12676 SOCCER NICE SACK COACH EMON 
12677 NICE France 1996-08-29 
12678 Struggling French first division side Nice on Thursday announced they were parting with coach Albert Emon after a string of poor results 
12679 Club president Andre Bois said a successor would be named on Friday 
12680 A former player for Marseille and Monaco Emon 43 has coached Nice since 1992 
12681 The announcement came 24 hours after the team from the French Riviera lost at home to Guingamp 2-1 in a league match 
12682 Nice are 18th in the table 
12683 SOCCER THREE PULL OUT OF DUTCH SQUAD FOR BRAZIL 
12684 AMSTERDAM 1996-08-29 
12685 Three Dutch players have pulled out of the squad for Saturday 's friendly international soccer match against Brazil in Amsterdam 
12686 Ajax defender John Veldman and his team mate Richard Witschge are injured while PSV midfielder Philip Cocu has a fever 
12687 Dutch coach Guus Hiddink called in Feyenoord midfielder Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Vitesse defender Ferdy Vierklau for Cocu and Veldman but did not name a replacement for midfielder Witschge 
12688 BRITAIN WELCOMES ROMANIA-HUNGARY TREATY ACCORD 
12689 BUCHAREST 1996-08-29 
12690 Britain joined the United States on Thursday in welcoming Romania and Hungary 's agreement on the text of a much-delayed friendship treaty which it said would contribute to stability in the area 
12691 The United Kingdom believes that such a treaty will contribute positively to the further development of good neighbourly relations between the two countries and enhance the stability of the region said the British Foreign office statement 
12692 The accord agreed two weeks ago is expected to end years of disputes over the status of Romania 's large ethnic Hungarian minority 
12693 It will also boost both countries ambitions to join NATO and the European Union 
12694 Bucharest and Budapest say the treaty should be signed in the first half of September 
12695 The United Kingdom looks forward to the early signature of the treaty the statement said

12724 Zaire installs first election delegates 
12725 KINSHASA 1996-08-29 
12726 A total of 116 delegates to Zaire 's National Election Commission CNE were formally installed on Thursday launching another phase of the Central African nation 's much-delayed democratic transition 
12727 The 116 representing political parties in the capital Kinshasa will help organise a voter census a constitutional referendum planned for January and efforts to brief potential voters on what balloting involves 
12728 A total of 9,446 delegates will be deployed throughout Zaire 's 11 provinces for the elections which must be held by July 1997 under the transitional constitution 
12729 Presidential parliamentary and municipal elections are planned for May 
12730 We can meet the required deadlines for organising the elections 
12731 All that is needed is for everyone to show goodwill Commission spokesman Yoka Lye Mudaba told reporters 
12732 Delegates to the commission from the other 10 provinces will be installed progressively from next week with the provinces of North and South Kivu Maniema Shaba and Bandundu having priority he said 
12733 The installation of delegates was initially scheduled for July 
12734 Officials said lack of funding had delayed the process 
12735 President Mobutu Sese Seko who seized power in a 1965 coup introduced a multi-party system in 1990 but Zaire 's transition has lagged well behind that of other states in the region 
12736 In the past Mobutu has been elected without opposition 
12737 Nigeria would not refuse Commonwealth officials 
12738 LAGOS 1996-08-29 
12739 Nigeria would not object to a visit by Commonwealth officials but insists its suspension from the organisation be resolved before any other questions are addressed Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi said on Thursday 
12740 Ikimi reiterated his position that the Commonwealth had no mandate to send a fact-finding mission 
12741 The request I have received is for their officials to come and talk to my officials 
12742 We cannot object to people wanting to visit Nigeria Ikimi told Reuters by telephone from the capital Abuja 
12743 The fundamental problem we have with the Commonwealth is our unfair suspension 
12744 Any discussions we have at ministerial level will be a continuation of what we began in London on that 
12745 Before that is accomplished we cannot address anything else 
12746 Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth in November after the execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other minority rights activists in defiance of international pleas for clemency 
12747 A meeting of Commonwealth ministers in London on Wednesday said it planned to send a team of senior officials to Nigeria as soon as possible to persuade Abuja to accept a fact-finding mission 
12748 The timing of that mission has yet to be determined 
12749 The latest diplomatic row between Nigeria 's military government and the club of Britain and its former colonies erupted over the terms of a visit by Commonwealth ministers to discuss Nigeria 's suspension 
12750 Nigeria said they would be restricted to a two-day meeting with government officials but the Commonwealth said it wanted to hold meetings with people outside the government and called off the visit

12756 Senegal bans guns ahead of local elections 
12757 DAKAR 1996-08-29 
12758 With tension rising among Senegal 's political parties ahead of local elections on November 24 the interior ministry on Thursday banned the carrying of guns and ammunition until the end of the year 
12759 It is forbidden for holders of permits for weapons of all categories to transport the said arms and their ammunition outside their homes the statement said 
12760 It said the ban applied to Senegalese nationals and foreign residents

12767 He won 69 percent of votes in the second round of presidential elections on July 3 1996 .. 
12768 His supporters will contest the parliamentary election in a coalition of 30 mainly small parties the Republican Front led by Deby 's Patriotic Salvation Movement

12783 NATO releases Serb police crisis easing NATO 
12784 SARAJEVO 1996-08-29 
12785 NATO forces released a group of Bosnian Serb policemen late on Thursday and a tense confrontation appeared to be easing an alliance spokesman said 
12786 The situation in Mahala seems to be very much on its way toward resolution 
12787 My understanding is the Serb police have been released 
12788 In Zvornik we think the situation is winding down as well NATO spokesman Lieutenant Colonel Max Marriner told Reuters 
12789 NATO troops detained 65 Bosnian Serb policemen early on Thursday after they attacked Moslem refugees returning to homes in Mahala a Serb-controlled village on Bosnia 's internal boundary line 
12790 In apparent retaliation for NATO 's detention of the Serbs an angry Serb mob including policemen trapped six unarmed U.N. police monitors and three local aides in their office in the town of Zvornik east of Mahala 
12791 Marriner said NATO forces confiscated 25 long-barreled AK-47 automatic assault rifles from the detained Serbs before setting them free 
12792 Local radio and television there in Zvornik are advising people to step back and take it easy 
12793 We think that when the word about how things are going in Mahala which is about 35 minutes away by road reaches Zvornik that should help Marriner said 
12794 Storm kills 11 at Macedonian religious festival 
12795 SKOPJE 1996-08-29 
12796 At least 11 people were killed and 60 others injured on Thursday when lightning struck a group of people attending a religious festival in Macedonia police and municipal officials said 
12797 Police in Berovo 150 km 90 miles west of the capital Skopje said there were around 15,000 people gathered around the town 's cathedral when the lightning struck the group during a thunderstorm 
12798 Kornblum Milosevic discuss election crisis 
12799 Peter Greste 
12800 BELGRADE 1996-08-29 
12801 U.S. envoy John Kornblum met Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic on Thursday in an effort to defuse a growing crisis surrounding Bosnia 's post-war elections 
12802 The American diplomat arrived in Belgrade two days after international organisers postponed municipal elections in Bosnia due to irregularities in the registration of Serb refugee voters 
12803 We discussed the decision to postpone the municipal elections and I made clear it was primarily the manipulation of voter registration by the Republika Srpska Bosnian Serb republic which led to this development Kornblum said after three hours of talks 
12804 But he said the United States still believed it was important to go ahead with national elections in Bosnia as scheduled on September 14 to bolster the peace process 
12805 Kornblum gave no indication that he had won any specific commitment from Milosevic the patron of the Bosnian Serbs to rectify any abuses in the registration process 
12806 Bosnia 's Moslem political parties have urged their refugees to boycott the elections until irregularities with voter registration are resolved 
12807 Human rights workers say Serbian and Bosnian Serb authorities coerced refugees to register only in Serb-held territory in Bosnia to solidify the results of wartime expulsions and military conquest 
12808 Serbian officials have denied any abuses occurred during a 10-day registration period and the Bosnian Serbs angry at the postponement of municipal elections have threatened to hold local polls on their territory without the international community 's blessing 
12809 Kornblum said only elections endorsed by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe OSCE would be legitimate 
12810 As we have said publicly before if there is any effort to do so hold local elections these elections will not be valid he said 
12811 The elections which are valid are those conducted by the international community under the management of the OSCE 
12812 After meeting Milosevic Kornblum flew to the Croatian capital Zagreb 
12813 He was due to head to the Bosnian town of Banja Luka on Friday to meet Bosnian Serb acting president Biljana Plavsic and Bosnian Serb opposition leaders 
12814 He also planned to travel to Sarajevo to oversee the formal dissolution of the separatist Croat mini-state in western Bosnia 
12815 U.N. police relief workers and NATO officers have reported a rise in political violence across Bosnia in the run-up to the September 14 elections 
12816 Voters will be choosing a three-member presidency and a parliament to rule over a loose union of Bosnia comprised of a Serb republic and a Moslem-Croat federation 
12817 Gazprom rises to 2,901.48 rbls at auction 
12818 MOSCOW 1996-08-29 
12819 A stake of 10 million shares in Russian gas monopoly RAO Gazprom was sold at auction on Thursday at an average 2,901.48 roubles a share up from 2,891.00 roubles a week ago the Federal Securities Corporation FFK said 
12820 Starting price at the auction was 2,746 roubles a share and the 40 lots sold for between 2,840 and 2,998 roubles a share the FFK said in a statement 
12821 The stake represented 0.042 percent of Gazprom 's capital 
12822 The FFK said that since auctions began 139.75 million shares equivalent to 0.59 percent of Gazprom have changed hands 
12823 Gazprom Russia 's biggest company by market capitalisation has massive reserves and potentially huge earnings 
12824 However its 23.6 billion shares are highly illiquid and management permission is required to sell them 
12825 Gazprom has recently tightened these rules making it harder for shareholders to sell to whoever they want when they want 
12826 The company has organised regular auctions of its shares to create an orderly market in the paper 
12827 At the first auction on March 6 shares sold for an average 406.6 roubles each and prices have been rising steadily since then but the rise in price this week and last was much less than in previous auctions 
12828 On the Russian Trading System Gazprom shares rose 25 percent on Thursday to $ 0.375 from $ 0.300 after falling by over a third earlier this week 
12829 Artyom Danielyan Moscow Newsroom +7095 941 8520 
12830 Serbian policeman shot dead in Kosovo province 
12831 BELGRADE 1996-08-29 
12832 A policeman has been shot dead in Serbia 's troubled Kosovo province Serbian police said on Thursday 
12833 It was the fifth attack on police this month in the southern province a hot spot of ethnic tension where the Albanian majority have boycotted Serbian institutions and set up their own which are considered illegal by Belgrade 
12834 The slain policeman Ejup Bajgora 42 was an Albanian who had served in the Serbian police and state security since 1987 police told the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug 
12835 He was shot on Wednesday afternoon as he stepped off a bus near his family home in the village of Donje Ljupce in the municipality of Podujevo 
12836 Just hours before Wednesday 's shooting three hand grenades were thrown at a police station in Celopek 
12837 They caused damage but no casualties police said 
12838 The Serbian authorities blame Albanian dissidents for the recent spate of attacks 
12839 None of the attackers has been caught 
12840 Kosovo 's autonomy was revoked in 1987 and Serb police forces cracked down on Albanian protests 
12841 Albanian moderates want autonomy restored but hardliners want to join up with neighbouring Albania 
12842 The Serbs who make up 10 percent of the province 's 1.8 million people claim Kosovo as the cradle of their culture 
12843 Viral meningitis epidemic kills 10 in Romania 
12844 BUCHAREST 1996-08-29 
12845 Viral meningitis has killed 10 people in Romania 's capital Bucharest this month in what doctors said on Thursday was the worst epidemic of its type in the country for a decade 
12846 Some 170 middle-aged and elderly people with the disease were being treated in hospital doctors said 
12847 Doctor Emanuil Ceausu head of Bucharest 's Victor Babes hospital for infectious diseases said the epidemic had been caused by a virus yet to be identified 
12848 Illness from viral meningitis lasts around a week 
12849 It affects the gastro-intestinal tract causing high fever headache and vomiting 
12850 In 1986 Romania suffered an epidemic of the more dangerous bacterial meningitis which has killed some 15,000 people in central Africa this year

12853 Workers at Serbia 's Zastava arms factory entered the ninth day of their protest over unpaid wages on Thursday with management accused them of rejecting talks 
12854 The workers keep on gathering in the centre of the town the factory 's general manager Vukasin Filipovic told Reuters

12856 They want to discuss in public at their protest meetings Filipovic said 
12857 And that is impossible 
12858 The Zastava works in the central town of Kragujevac is the backbone of Serbia 's defence industry supplying the army with a whole range of weapons 
12859 Its workers are staging protests in the town 's main square demanding June and July wages and last year 's holiday pay 
12860 On Wednesday the union demanded the resignation of the factory manager 
12861 But Filipovic said he would not quit under pressure 
12862 We can talk about it and I am prepared to take all the consequences of mismanagement if any

12873 Venezuela non-oil exports rise 10.6 pct in July 
12874 CARACAS 1996-08-29 
12875 Venezuela 's non-traditional exports which exclude oil and iron rose 10.6 percent in July to reach $ 334 million compared to $ 302 million in June according to the Central Office of Statistics and Information OCEI 
12876 The rise was due to the end of exchange controls OCEI said 
12877 Foreign exchange controls were removed April 22 as part of a wider IMF-sponsored program 
12878 Nevertheless exports over the first seven months of the year were 16.8 percent lower than during the same period last year at $ 2.240 billion compared to $ 2.693 billion 
12879 Over the seven months the private sector accounted for 76 percent of total exports with common metals the strongest export sector accounting for $ 951 million or 42.5 percent of total exports 
12880 Chemical products came next with a 13 percent share then transport materials with nine percent and finally foods drinks and tobacco with 6.3 percent 
12881 Colombia was the chief market for Venezuela 's non-traditional exports with 27.4 percent 
12882 The U.S. followed with a 24.6 percent share

12884 Buenos Aires fraud cops held in extortion racket 
12885 BUENOS AIRES Argentina 1996-08-29 
12886 Thirteen senior police officers from the fraud squad of Buenos Aires province have been arrested on charges of running an extortion racket security officials said on Thursday 
12887 They included all the top officers from the fraud division of the north of Buenos Aires province including Commissioner Juan Carlos Lago 
12888 Police were seeking a 14th officer 
12889 La Nacion newspaper said the officers were suspected of demanding bribes of $ 50,000 to $ 500,000 from companies being investigated for tax evasion in order to lose their files 
12890 The credibility of the Buenos Aires provincial police the largest force in Argentina has been undermined this year by scandals that included the indictment of three officers for links to the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community centre and the arrest of an entire drugs squad for drug trafficking 
12891 Alberto Piotti security chief of Buenos Aires province told local television that 3,600 dishonest officers had been purged from the force 's ranks in the past five years 
12892 It is an ongoing task 
12893 And these investigations into police corruption are only possible because there are people brave enough to denounce them Piotti said promising a major overhaul of the provincial police next month

12902 Co-ordinated guerrilla attacks in two southern states overnight that left at least 13 people dead have caused nervousness in Mexico 's financial markets 
12903 Bank notes and acceptances including pagares rose 46 basis points to 25.10 percent 
12904 Dealers said that the volume of longer-term government paper declined due to market nervousness

12906 Maturing credits are seen at 2.209 billion pesos and there is an oversupply of 684 billion pesos from the primary auction 
12907 Dealers estimate that the shortfall will increase due to the inflow of funds before the end of the month

12909 Tension builds in Mexican state ahead of elections 
12910 [ CORRECTED 05:53 GMT ] 
12911 CHILPANCINGO Mexico 1996-08-28 
12912 Pre-electoral bickering flared on Wednesday in the troubled western Mexican state of Guerrero as some opposition politicians demanded the army pull out of the area ahead of an upcoming state poll 
12913 The mayor of Acatepec a small town some 310 miles 500 km south of Mexico City sent a letter to Mexico 's National Human Rights Commission complaining the army 's heavy presence in the town would interfere with the Oct. 6 election 
12914 Mayor Antonio Gonzalez Garcia of the opposition Revolutionary Workers Party said in Wednesday 's letter that army troops recently raided several local farms stole cattle and raped women 
12915 The letter was signed by some 200 area residents and indigenous leaders 
12916 Some electoral watchdog groups also said the presence of the army which has fanned out across the state in the past month in search of a new guerrilla group was likely to intimidate voters and had stirred up tension in the state 
12917 A French group of electoral observers Agir Ensemble pour les Droits de l'Homme concluded the army presence exerted a heavy psychological pressure on local farmers and would prevent a fair vote 
12918 Up for grabs in the election are the state legislature and 75 town halls 
12919 Corrects to show elections are not for governor 
12920 Despite the criticism acting state Gov 
12921 Angel Aguirre pledged the elections will be free and fair and said he did not expect any trouble from the elusive new guerrilla group the Popular Revolutionary Army 
12922 The electoral process has been proceeding in accordance with the new state electoral law Aguirre said adding that the poll would be an exercise in true democracy

12928 Globo quoted Pessina 's lawyer as saying he had already been imprisoned in Italy and when freed travelled to Brazil

12933 The letter from National Council of Christian Churches of Brazil and the Coordinate of Ecumenical Service was sent to President Fernando Henrique Cardoso after a seminar on endemic violence gripping rural Brazil 
12934 Thirty-six people have died so far this year in conflicts over land in the Brazilian countryside including 19 landless peasants massacred by police in April in the northern state of Para 
12935 The problem of land is one of the most serious facing Brazil said Lucas Moreira Neves president of the Catholic church 's National Conference of Bishops of Brazil

12937 Thai official flees Hong Kong after passport scam 
12938 HONG KONG 1996-08-29

12940 The unnamed suspect left the British colony after being detained and then freed by the Independent Commission Against Corruption ICAC the radio said 
12941 The man was released after his arrest on Tuesday pending further inquiries the ICAC said in a statement 
12942 The anti-graft body was discussing the case with the Thai government especially the suspect 's status it said 
12943 It is not clear if the fugitive had diplomatic status in Hong Kong and officials from the Thai Consulate were not available for comment 
12944 The arrest came after the ICAC received a complaint that the man had demanded a bribe of HK$ 100,000 US$ 12,940 to issue a Thai passport the ICAC said 
12945 At the time of his arrest ICAC officers seized HK$ 100,000 it added

12947 Thai poll shows military wants PM Banharn out 
12948 BANGKOK 1996-08-29 
12949 Thailand 's powerful military thinks the government is dishonest and Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa 's resignation might solve the nation 's political and economic woes an opinion poll showed on Thursday 
12950 Nearly half the 1,617 military personnel surveyed in the Rajapat Institute poll suggested that Banharn resign while about 28 percent thought he should dissolve parliament and 24 percent thought a cabinet reshuffle could resolve the government 's problems 
12951 Banharn who leads a six-party 13-month-old coalition government faces a no-confidence debate in parliament next month 
12952 The prime minister who has already lost one coalition partner this month is expected to have a tough battle in the debate because of infighting in his own party and warnings of more pullouts by other coalition partners 
12953 The poll conducted earlier this month after Banharn 's coalition completed one year in office showed the military would prefer General Chatichai Choonhavan a former prime minister who was ousted in a military coup in February 1991 as prime minister 
12954 Defence Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh head of coalition member the New Aspiration Party was the second choice for prime minister the poll showed 
12955 Banharn came in last on the list of proposed leaders with less than one percent of the votes 
12956 Nearly two-thirds of the people surveyed thought the government was dishonest and insincere and 65 percent blamed the government 's poor performance for the country 's economic slowdown 
12957 The opinion of the military in Thailand which has seen 17 coups or attempted coups since the country switched to parliamentary democracy from absolute monarchy in 1932 always carries weight in the political scene despite officials vows to distance the military from politics 
12958 Hamas cleric jailed in Israel hospitalised briefly 
12959 JERUSALEM 1996-08-29 
12960 Israeli prison officials took jailed Islamic militant Hamas founder Sheikh Ahmed Yassin to hospital briefly on Thursday for medical tests officials said 
12961 This evening Sheikh Yassin completed medical checks and returned to Ramle prisons authority medical centre said a spokesman for Israel 's internal security ministry 
12962 A prison official said Yassin had a mild case of pneumonia 
12963 The 60-year-old Moslem cleric jailed by Israel since 1989 is serving a life sentence for ordering attacks by Hamas guerrillas against Israeli targets 
12964 The ailing Yassin is the spiritual leader of the fundamentalist Hamas group which has killed scores of Israelis in suicide attacks aimed at wrecking Israel-PLO peace deals 
12965 Palestinian President Yasser Arafat has demanded that Israel release Yassin who is confined to a wheelchair on humanitarian grounds 
12966 Israel said last month after it recovered the body of a soldier abducted by Hamas seven years ago that it would consider freeing Yassin

12971 Accompanied by his wife and grandson Peres arrived in Morocco on August 25 
12972 Peres is expected to fly home on Friday officials said 
12973 Scandal hits Clinton campaign at vital moment 
12974 Michael Conlon 
12975 CHICAGO 1996-08-29 
12976 President Bill Clinton 's triumphal appearance at the Democratic convention a vital moment in his bid for a second term was marred on Thursday by the resignation of a top adviser in a reported sex scandal 
12977 Clinton was at work on the nomination acceptance speech that will launch his 10-week re-election campaign when political strategist Dick Morris abruptly announced his resignation on Thursday 
12978 The tabloid Star magazine reported the married Morris had a lengthy affair with a $ 200-an-hour prostitute who he allowed to eavesdrop on telephone conversations with Clinton and with whom he shared White House speeches before they were made 
12979 Dick Morris is my friend and he is a superb political strategist Clinton said in a written statement 
12980 I am and always will be grateful for the great contributions he has made to my campaigns and for the invaluable work he has done for me over the last two years 
12981 Morris declined to address the allegations directly in his resignation statement but said he was quitting to avoid becoming a campaign issue 
12982 The surprise development captivated the thousands of reporters at the convention and clearly worried some Democrats who had planned a triumphal celebration of Clinton 's lead over Dole in the opinion polls 
12983 Senator Dianne Feinstein a California Democrat called it a big bump in the way of the Clinton campaign 
12984 It comes at the worst possible time on one of the biggest days for the president Feinstein said 
12985 Clinton was to deliver his acceptance speech at the final session of the Democratic Convention opening at 8 p.m. EDT midnight GMT 
12986 The 50-year-old president has been dogged for years by allegations of financial wrongdoing sexual misconduct and questionable judgment in selecting his advisers 
12987 Republicans hope to seize on the character issue to bolster Clinton 's challenger Bob Dole in the final weeks of the campaign 
12988 Speaking in Santa Barbara California Dole did not directly refer to the sexual scandal but said the departure of Morris who had advised Clinton to chart a more centrist political course would make Clinton drift back to the left 
12989 Morris has been trying to make President Clinton a Republican now maybe he 'll revert to the liberal Democrat that he really is Dole told reporters 
12990 Clinton will hit the road on Friday for a bus tour across several states in his fight to become the first Democratic incumbent re-elected to a second term since the days of Franklin D. Roosevelt 
12991 Aides said Clinton planned to spend most of Thursday in his hotel room several miles km from the convention hall working on his speech 
12992 It was apparently neglected on his long whistle-stop train trip to the convention during which he revelled in contact with friendly crowds across the country 's heartland 
12993 He was also hoarse and was giving his voice a rest 
12994 But first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton told ABC television He 's really fired up 
12995 He wants to outline to the American people what he thinks has been accomplished in the last four years and what he would like to see done in the next four years she said 
12996 He 's very excited about this convention 
12997 He 's excited about the campaign 
12998 But more than that he 's very resolute about what he wants to do 
12999 I do n't take anything for granted 
13000 I always expect elections to get close 
13001 I expect to have a great deal of up and down days between now and then she said of the November 5 election date 
13002 Clinton is leading Dole by as much as 15 points according to some polls 
13003 The campaign pits Dole a man of quick and withering wit and long-time public service but stilted speaking style against the glib and confident Clinton who has perfected a style that makes direct eye contact with his audience

13016 Researchers report progress in muscular dystrophy 
13017 PHILADELPHIA 1996-08-29 
13018 University of Pennsylvania researchers on Thursday said a new gene-therapy technique for treating muscular dystrophy disease had shown progress in laboratory animals 
13019 Word of the findings to be published in the Oct. 1 issue of the journal Human Gene Therapy came in advance of the annual Jerry Lewis Labour Day weekend telethon to raise money for muscular dystrophy research 
13020 Several hurdles must be overcome before the method is used in human trials 
13021 Nevertheless a treatment based on the new strategy .... may have the potential to benefit many patients the University of Pennsylvania Medical Centre said in a release 
13022 Muscular dystrophy is a fatal illness in which the body 's muscle tissue degenerates and is replaced by fat 
13023 Death strikes in early adulthood 
13024 Individuals with the disease have a non-working version of a gene responsible for producing a crucial muscle protein called dystrophin 
13025 In the study at the University 's Institute for Human Gene Therapy researchers altered a common-cold virus to carry a version of the working dystrophin gene 
13026 The virus which also was altered to minimise its susceptibility to the immune system was then injected into the muscle cells of mice bred to lack dystrophin genes 
13027 In the experiment between 30 to 40 percent of the muscle fibers in one group of mice produced dystrophin for two weeks before diminishing 
13028 Similar results had been obtained previously in test-tube cell cultures but not in live animals the university said 
13029 The university said methods are still needed to make enough of the altered virus to treat humans to further decrease the immune-system response to the virus and to deliver the virus to human muscle tissue

13058 Help-wanted ad index fell in July 
13059 NEW YORK 1996-08-29 
13060 The help-wanted advertising index fell in July the Conference Board said Thursday reflecting the uneven nature of the nation 's labour markets 
13061 The monthly index fell to 83.0 in July against a reading of 85.0 in June the private business research group said 
13062 In July the volume of help-wanted advertising fell in five of the nine U.S. regions 
13063 The labour market has been expanding throughout 1996 but in a very uneven pattern Conference Board economist Ken Goldstein said 
13064 Recent want-ad figures indicate that conservative hiring plans are keeping job growth below the rate of overall economic activity 
13065 With 2.5 percent gross domestic product growth expected for 1996 new job growth should slowly lower the unemployment rate over the rest of the year 
13066 With the unemployment rate staying close to about 5.5 percent over the last two years there is a good chance the rate will slowly drop to about 5.0 percent by the end of the year Goldstein said 
13067 The July index matched the reading for July 1995 
13068 The greatest declines in the volume of help-wanted advertising were in the New England Mountain and West South Central regions 
13069 The greatest increase was in the East North Central region 
13070 Police seek suspects in Atlantic City jewel heist 
13071 ATLANTIC CITY N.J. 1996-08-29 
13072 Atlantic City police said Thursday they were seeking two men and two women in connection with a $ 690,000 theft of jewelry and cash from a guest of the Showboat Hotel and Casino 
13073 Capt 
13074 Richard Andrews said police were seeking a man shown on a hotel videotape carrying a suitcase resembling the victim 's 
13075 We want to talk to him Andrews said of the man 
13076 A second man and two women also were being sought 
13077 The thefts occurred Sunday when the victim New York jewelry wholesaler Jerry Schein left three suitcases in a closet at Somerset Jewellers in the hotel while he checked out 
13078 While he was gone two women in their mid-twenties and an older man entered the jewelry store and tried to distract store owner Charles McGilley 
13079 When Schein returned two of the suitcases were missing 
13080 They contained $ 650,000 in jewelry and $ 40,000 in cash Andrews said 
13081 He said the man on the videotape did not match the description given by the jewelry store owner 
13082 O.J. Simpson hints at more supporting evidence 
13083 Jackie Frank 
13084 WASHINGTON 1996-08-29 
13085 O.J. Simpson said on Thursday he was financially broken by his defence against murder charges but he was hopeful new evidence to support him would be available for a civil trial next month 
13086 The former football star was found not guilty by a criminal trial jury last October of the murders of his former wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman in June 1994 
13087 He now faces a civil suit brought by families of the victims who hold him responsible for the deaths 
13088 He told reporters a court order not to talk about his case kept him from detailing how he has fulfilled his pledge to find the killers 
13089 But he added without elaborating hopefully we will see some things come out in this next trial 
13090 The judge in the civil trial has imposed a sweeping gag order that prohibits lawyers witnesses and parties to the case from discussing it with the media or elsewhere in public 
13091 I would love to speak about everything said Simpson who vowed after his acquittal to find the killers and offered a substantial reward 
13092 His lawyers have said his defence in the civil trial that starts Sept 
13093 17 will be that he did not kill the victims 
13094 Simpson said at the hotel news conference his plans include eventually writing another book 
13095 He added that he has had job offers but more have come from abroad than at home 
13096 I 'm broke 
13097 I am not crying the blues 
13098 I can get along just fine he said 
13099 Whatever you want to send me I need 
13100 He again accused the news media of erroneous reporting on his case but did not signal any plans for lawsuits as he did on Wednesday in an address at a jam-packed Washington church 
13101 Contrary to news reports Simpson said he has received support from both blacks and whites 
13102 He again dismissed charges that he had distanced himself from the black community during his successful football and commercial career only to seek their support after he faced murder charges 
13103 A crowd of 2,000 paid $ 10 a head to hear the former star running back for the Buffalo Bills professional football club and a Football Hall of Fame member on Wednesday night 
13104 The crowd in the church was wildly supportive showering Simpson with gifts and praise 
13105 But outside dozens of protesters from the D.C. Coalition Against Domestic Violence called for the church to support victims of violence instead 
13106 Clinton adviser Morris announces resignation 
13107 CHICAGO 1996-08-29 
13108 President Bill Clinton 's top political strategist Dick Morris resigned on Thursday saying he did not want to become an issue in Clinton 's re-election campaign 
13109 In a written statement distributed by the Clinton campaign Morris avoided comment on published allegations that he had engaged in a year-long affair with a $ 200-an-hour prostitute 
13110 The statement from Morris said that he had submitted his resignation on Wednesday night 
13111 While I served I sought to avoid the limelight because I did not want to become the message 
13112 Now I resign so I will not become the issue he said 
13113 The announcement followed a report in the weekly supermarket tabloid Star magazine reprinted in Thursday 's editions of the New York Post that the married adviser had hired a 37-year-old prostitute on a weekly basis while visiting Washington to advise Clinton on his re-election campaign 
13114 I will not subject my wife family or friends to the sadistic vitriol of yellow journalism 
13115 I will not dignify such journalism with a reply or an answer 
13116 I never will his statement said 
13117 It was distributed to reporters at the press centre of Clinton 's Democratic convention headquarters just hours before the president was to address the delegates accepting the party 's nomination for a second four-year term in the White House 
13118 U.S. surgeon investigated for discarding foot 
13119 CHARLESTON S.C. 1996-08-29 
13120 Health officials said on Thursday they were investigating the discovery of an amputated foot on a beach near Charleston to determine whether a local surgeon had improperly disposed of infectious waste 
13121 The foot which washed up on Sullivan 's Island beach this month was amputated three years ago from a child whose legs were deformed 
13122 The foot had to be removed so the infant could be fitted with a prosthesis 
13123 An orthopedic surgeon was given permission by the child 's parents and the hospital to keep the foot for research and educational purposes 
13124 Health officials said the surgeon told authorities he stored the foot in his freezer at home but the freezer recently broke down and the contents spoiled 
13125 The surgeon who apologised for the incident said he decided to put the foot in a crab trap to remove the flesh 
13126 The foot later washed up on the beach

13130 When four would-be robbers armed and masked showed up to rob a Checker 's restaurant in the Fort Lauderdale suburb of Pembroke Pines on Tuesday they had no idea the shrub near the drive-through window was toting a shotgun

13132 They were quite surprised he told the Miami Herald

13134 Green and black face paint completed his disguise 
13135 He was staking out the restaurant after a series of robberies at local fast-food places 
13136 Pembroke Pines police said five people were arrested as a result of the 90-minute stakeout including the four robbers and a restaurant employee who was allegedly prepared to let them in a back door

13157 EU barley sale worth $ 145 T for Saudi sources 
13158 PARIS 1996-08-29 
13159 A European Union sale of 234,324 tonnes of German intervention barley is worth some $ 145 per tonne fob Germany and is mostly destined for Saudi Arabia European grain sources said on Thursday 
13160 The EU 's cereals management committee sold 234,324 tonnes of German intervention barley at a minimum price of 105.07 Ecus per tonne 
13161 Saudi Arabia provisionally bought 800,000 tonnes of optional-origin barley at an August 21 tender at prices between $ 160 and $ 162 including cost insurance and freight traders said last week 
13162 But European grain traders and officials said the Saudis might reduce the purchase to 600,000 tonnes 
13163 Traders have said a substantial part of the deal was likely to come from the European Union which enjoys a supply and freight advantage over other producers 
13164 But subtracting freight costs the equivalent fob price of the deal is around $ 142 well below the $ 149 per tonne floor price which the EU put on its barley as news of the deal emerged last week 
13165 Last Thursday the EU sold 34,277 tonnes of German intervention barley at a minimum price of 109.36 Ecus per tonne which was seen as worth $ 149 per tonne fob

13171 A cutback plan could slim their numbers to 1,700 from 4,200 
13172 Several hundred workers also marched in the western town of Indre where 500 or 1,600 jobs are at risk

13200 Salang tunnel reopened linking Kabul with north 
13201 SALANG TUNNEL Afghanistan 1996-08-29 
13202 The Salang tunnel linking Kabul with northern Afghanistan was formally reopened to traffic on Thursday under an agreement between the government and an opposition militia witnesses said 
13203 They said dozens of trucks began moving through the tunnel from both directions after the road reopened 
13204 The Salang tunnel the main supply route for Soviet troops when they were occupying Afghanistan in the 1980s had been closed since 1994 when northern militia leader General Abdul Rashid Dostum rebelled against the Kabul government 
13205 Witnesses said wrecked tanks and vehicles littered both sides of the heavily-mined road 
13206 Mines had been removed from the road itself but experts of the Halo Trust mine clearance agency said it would take a week to clear the roadsides 
13207 Afghan Deputy Prime Minister Qotbuddin Hilal officiated at the reopening ceremony which was delayed by several hours while the two sides argued about a mutual release of prisoners 
13208 Two Indians to die for killing 23 bus passengers 
13209 NEW DELHI 1996-08-29 
13210 India 's Supreme Court on Thursday sentenced two men to death after finding them guilty of killing 23 bus passengers including children 
13211 It said the two after robbing the passengers burnt them alive by sprinkling the bus with petrol and setting it on fire in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh in 1993 
13212 We have no doubt that this is one of the rarest of the rare cases not merely due to the number of innocent human beings roasted alive by the appellants but the inhuman manner in which they plotted the scheme and executed it Justice K.T. Thomas said in the verdict by a panel of three judges 
13213 Elephant tramples woman to death in Nepal 
13214 KATHMANDU 1996-08-29 
13215 A rampaging elephant dragged a sleeping 72-year-old woman from her bed and trampled her to death in the third such killing in two months Nepal police said on Thursday 
13216 The elephant crashed into Hari Maya Poudels house in Madhumalla village earlier this week while she was asleep they said 
13217 The beast dragged the woman 30 feet nine metres away from her bed and trampled her to death a police official told Reuters in the Himalayan kingdoms capital Kathmandu 
13218 In the past two months elephants have killed three people in remote areas of east and central Nepal 
13219 Elephants are protected under Nepali law which provides for jail sentences of up to 15 years for convicted elephant killers

13237 SoCal Edison sees 2 power lines back today 
13238 NEW YORK 1996-08-29 
13239 Southern California Edison Co said it expected two 220 kilovolt KV power lines in southern California to resume service later today after being shut late Wednesday because of a wildfire raging north of Los Angeles 
13240 They are expected to be placed in service later today said company spokesman Steve Conroy adding repair crews have been removing smoke and other fire-related residues which had settled on the two lines 
13241 The shutdown of the 220 KV lines reduced by 500 megawatts MW the amount of power which the area received from SoCal Edison 's 1,200 MW Sierra hydroelectric facility he said 
13242 Conroy noted two 500 KV and another 220 KV line running from the Sierra plant to Los Angeles remained in operation and continued to carry some of the production from Sierra to the region 
13243 On Monday the two 500 KV transmission cables were taken out of service also for cleaning for about a day 
13244 Containment of the fire has been difficult because of the hot arid windy weather in the region Conroy said 
13245 The fires keep moving back because of the winds he said forcing the utility to shut those transmission lines for a second time this week 
13246 Local authorities charged a teenager for starting the blaze 
13247 In four days the fire destroyed 20,000 acres of forest land

13257 Sierra Semiconductor jumps on exit plan 
13258 Martin Wolk 
13259 SEATTLE 1996-08-29 
13260 Sierra Semiconductor Corp jumped 23 percent Thursday on the expectation the company would emerge as a smaller but more profitable operation after its planned exit from the computer modem business 
13261 The San Jose Calif. company was up 2-1/8 at 11-3/8 after its announcement Wednesday that it planned to pull out of the highly competitive modem-chip business and focus instead on the fast-growing market for computer networking equipment 
13262 Certainly the company will be a much smaller company now but it will be a more profitable business said analyst Elias Moosa of Roberston Stephens & Co 
13263 But analysts noted that Sierra still has much painful work ahead of it including cutting as many as 150 jobs from its workforce which currently has 500 people and building up the business of its PMC-Sierra unit which makes routing devices and chipsets for high-speed computer networks 
13264 The company has announced plans to take a charge against earnings of $ 50 million to $ 80 million to write down the value of assets and inventories and cover severance payments 
13265 Scott Randall of Soundview Financial Group said the company likely would have difficulty selling its modem-chip business 
13266 Once you announce your intention to exit a business it becomes a complete buyer 's market he said 
13267 And he said that while the company is focusing on the fastest-growing part of its business the market for networking chips has begun to attract the attention of much-larger players such as International Business Machines Corp 
13268 As the market develops the question is are they able to make that transition to be a much larger company ? 
13269 Randall said 
13270 Other analysts were more bullish even though the company is expected to shrink to slightly more than half its current size in sales 
13271 It 's a positive strategic move said Miles Kan of Hambrecht & Quist 
13272 The modem business is a low-margin commodity business he said 
13273 The company 's PMC-Sierra unit generated $ 33 million of the company 's $ 117 million in sales in the first half of the year compared with $ 45 million in sales of modem chips Kan said 
13274 But the PMC unit is far more profitable he said 
13275 Sierra 's stock has fallen from a high of nearly $ 25 this year as the computer chip sector has been battered by falling prices and concern about slowing demand 
13276 Seattle bureau 206-386-4848

13316 Oasis singer heads for U.S. after illness 
13317 LONDON 1996-08-29

13320 I hate you f... ing lot yet you 're always asking me too many things 
13321 I 'm not a supermodel you know he said 
13322 On Monday just 15 minutes before his flight was due to depart Liam decided not to travel with the rest of the group which includes his brother Noel 
13323 Liam caught a taxi back to London saying he had problems at home 
13324 He was believed to be suffering from laryngitis and said he had to go house-hunting with actress girlfriend Patsy Kensit

13328 LONDON 1996-08-29

13330 Shares in Slough which earlier announced a 14 percent rise in first-half pretax profit to 37.4 million stg climbed nearly six percent or 14p to 250 pence at 1009 GMT while British Land added 12-1 2p to 468p Land Securities rose 5-1 2p to 691p and Hammerson was 8p higher at 390 
13331 Traders said positive comment from investment banks Merrill Lynch and SBC Warburg also fueled the gains 
13332 One dealer said positive stances from Merrill Lynch and SBC Warburg were the key factors behind the gains 
13333 A spokesman for Merrill Lynch said the bank was preparing to issue a note on the sector 
13334 We have been very positive on property he said adding On a technical basis it is our most favoured sector 
13335 SBC Warburg issued an update on the property sector on Thursday saying that most of the predictions it made at the start of the year were being realised 
13336 In the property market it is a case of so far so good a member of SBC Warburg 's property team said 
13337 SBC Warburg said it is maintaining its forecast for five percent growth in rental incomes during 1996 but it has shaved its forecast for capital growth to five percent from six 
13338 The spokesman said SBC Warburg has also put an add recommendation on Slough Estates shares but added that this is a general move not because of the results 
13339 Slough 's chairman Sir Nigel Mobbs added to the bullish mood in the sector saying in a statement that with the prospect of a period of steady economic growth and low inflation ahead there is good reason to believe that the property sector should continue its improvement

13341 Canada 's international travel account gap shrinks 
13342 OTTAWA 1996-08-29 
13343 Higher spending by foreign visitors and less Canadian tourist spending abroad cut the deficit in Canada 's international travel account by 26.5 percent in the second quarter Statistics Canada said on Thursday 
13344 The deficit fell to a seasonally adjusted C$ 715 million in the second quarter from C$ 973 million in the first as foreigners spent a record C$ 3.00 billion seasonally adjusted while Canadians reduced their spending abroad by 5.1 percent to C$ 3.72 billion

13353 Iran says five spy networks destroyed 41 held 
13354 TEHRAN 1996-08-29 
13355 Iranian security forces have broken up five espionage rings in northwestern Iran and arrested 41 people on charges of spying for unnamed countries a daily newspaper said on Thursday 
13356 Jomhuri Eslami quoted the West Azerbaijan province security chief as saying those held confessed to gathering confidential information photographing strategic sites doing propaganda against state officials and spreading pan-Turkism 
13357 It was not clear if they were the same five spy rings allegedly led by Turkish diplomats that Iran said in April it had broken up in the same area which borders Turkey 
13358 The April arrests were announced shortly after a row in which Tehran asked Ankara to withdraw four Turkish diplomats accused of spying and Turkey expelled four Iranian diplomats for their alleged links to killings of Iranian exiles 
13359 Ties between the two neighbours strained also over a military accord between Turkey and Israel which drew strong Iranian objections have improved since Islamist Necmettin Erbakan took over as Turkish prime minister in June 
13360 The daily Iran on Thursday quoted Intelligence Minister Ali Fallahiyan as saying agents arrested 137 people for allegedly spying for Iraq the United States and other unnamed countries in the Iranian year which ended on March 19 
13361 Mideast Gulf oil outlook India holds the key 
13362 DUBAI 1996-08-29 
13363 India will continue to hold the key to the middle distillates product market in the Middle East Gulf in the short term traders in the region said on Thursday 
13364 They said premiums on high quality jet kerosene have widened to around $ 1 and are likely to remain strong in the near term 
13365 On the jet kerosene side we must be cautious about quality 
13366 Some are commanding a very good premium of 95 cents to one dollar 
13367 It 's been 99 cents to Korea 
13368 This will stay at this sort of price premium for a while one said 
13369 But for normal jet the weakened demand is quite noticeable the premium is around 45-50 cents 
13370 The differential is not normally as wide as this he added 
13371 Another put the premium for jet kerosene at between 65 and 75 cents 
13372 One trader said despite the fact that some kerosene was in storage at Dubai ports demand looked to exceed supply in the near term 
13373 Jet kerosene was assessed at $ 27.40 $ 27.70 a barrel fob Gulf on Thursday up from $ 27.22 last week 
13374 Dealers expected premiums to stick around current levels for the next two or three weeks before they get a boost in the second half of September from demand for October cargoes 
13375 Gas oil assessed at $ 24.00 $ 24.20 a barrel fob Gulf was little changed on Thursday from last week 's $ 24.10 $ 24.24 
13376 On gas oil in the near term demand and supply are balanced to a bit short there are some enquiries into east Africa and short covering in India said one trader 
13377 The Indians have awarded three cargoes but the question is whether they will come out for more he added 
13378 India has acquired 120,000 tonnes of diesel in three cargoes bound for the west coast in its October tender 
13379 Traders said the award could be India 's lowest in recent years 
13380 After IOC 's very small purchase of 120,000 tonnes I 'm still suspicious that they will buy more in the second half of October another said 
13381 But traders see the market remaining tight in the short-term with some surplus arising closer to October 
13382 I see an overhang of gas oil further out one said 
13383 Gas oil will remain tight in the short term up to mid-September with the premium of around $ 1 for 0.5 percent sulphur material 
13384 In the second half of September and October we see the premium coming off to 70-75 cents 
13385 Traders said there was not much demand for one percent sulphur material gas oil with the premium at 40 to 45 cents

13450 Baker made secret trip to Syria in March 1995 
13451 WASHINGTON 1996-08-29 
13452 Former Secretary of State James Baker made a secret trip to Syria in March 1995 in an unsuccessful bid to break an impasse in negotiations between Syria and Israel the Washington Post reported on Thursday 
13453 The paper said Baker declined to discuss the trip but authorised an associate to confirm it took place and give an account of it 
13454 News of the secret trip came after Baker trashed the Clinton administration at the Republican National Convention two weeks ago for its efforts to nudge Syria into peace with Israel 
13455 Baker made the March 1995 trip on the explicit understanding that it remain a secret but after his speech at the GOP convention Israel 's outgoing ambassador Itamar Rabinovich told a reporter about it the Post said 
13456 Baker was secretary of state in the Republican administration of President George Bush

13462 Beachcomber finds piece that could be TWA part 
13463 ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS N.J. 1996-08-28 
13464 A foot-long piece of debris bearing markings from a commercial aircraft was found on the New Jersey shore and forwarded to TWA crash investigators in Long Island officials said on Wednesday 
13465 A person walking on the shore at Island Beach State Park found the debris and alerted police who forwarded it to Long Island New York where the National Transportation Safety Board and the FBI are conducting an investigation 
13466 The TWA jet exploded in a deadly fireball last month killing 230 people crashing in the Atlantic Ocean at least 80 miles from where the debris was found Wednesday 
13467 Several other items have been reported found along the New Jersey shore most of it such personal items as wallets shoes and jewelry 
13468 Investigators said they still do not have enough evidence to determine whether a bomb a missile or mechanical failure caused the crash 
13469 FEATURE Rich new detail on U.S. Civil War unearthed 
13470 Leila Corcoran 
13471 WASHINGTON 1996-08-29 
13472 A freed black man writes to his still-enslaved wife a mother pleads with Abraham Lincoln on behalf of her son and a maimed soldier poses for an official photograph in newly reopened records that bring the U.S. Civil War back to life 
13473 Working in the basement of the National Archives members of the Civil War Conservation Corps are organising the military records of volunteers who fought for the North so that they can be preserved on microfilm 
13474 The faded documents have been stowed away in the Archives since it opened in 1935 and have rarely seen the light of day 
13475 Each soldier 's file is a gold mine of information enlistment papers muster rolls medical records discharge certificates letters and photographs 
13476 Since the project began almost two years ago corps volunteers have focused on African American troops preparing records in time for the unveiling in Washington this year of a special memorial to black soldiers who fought in the war 
13477 More than 185,000 black soldiers fought and 37,000 died 
13478 In one letter a black soldier heading South wrote his wife though great is the present national difficulties yet I look forward to a brighter day when I shall have the oportunity of seeing you in the full enjoyment of freedom 
13479 I would like to no sic if you are still in slavery if you are it will not be long before we shall have crushed the system that now oppreses you for in the course of three months you shall have your liberty 
13480 Great is the outpouring of the coloured people that is now rallying with the heart of lions against the very curse that has separated you and me 
13481 In another letter dated January 1865 a well-to-do Washington matron wrote to Lincoln to plead for her son who faced a dishonourable discharge from the Army 
13482 James is a prisoner for a thoughtless act of folly while those who have done nothing for the cause are free she wrote 
13483 Lincoln 's notation on the letter read If his colonel will say in writing on this sheet he is willing to receive this man back to the regiment I will pardon and send him 
13484 The soldier was subsequently pardoned 
13485 While the letters speak to the anguish of separation a photograph of a black amputee speaks to the terrible physical cost of the war 
13486 In a picture required for his military discharge Pvt 
13487 Lewis Martin with haunted eyes posed bare-chested to reveal his missing arm and leg blown off during a battle at Petersburg Virginia in July 1864 
13488 The work on black troops has provided new insight into the rhythms of plantation talk and culture said John Simon professor of history at Southern Illinois University at Carbondale and editor of Gen 
13489 Ulysses Grant 's papers 
13490 These writings are not only poetic but a linguistic treasure trove 
13491 This is the first generation of African Americans that really can express itself without fear and punishment Simon said 
13492 I think there 's probably a whole lot of material that would expand our understanding of the sociology of the war said Edward Smith director of American Studies at American University in Washington 
13493 The war between the North and South raged for nearly four years claimed the lives of half a million Americans and forever seared the nation 's consciousness 
13494 Southern records have already been preserved 
13495 They were put on microfilm about 30 years ago through a grant from the United Daughters of the Confederacy 
13496 The Civil War Conservation Corps is mostly retirees joined by students during the school year 
13497 Director Budge Weidman who has shepherded the project from the beginning predicts it will take up to a decade to complete 
13498 The work was inspired by a National Park Service plan to put computer databases at Civil War battlefields across the country so that Americans might research their ancestors 
13499 The records also provide insight into medical thinking of the day 
13500 One soldier was discharged because of mental incapacity and inebetude sic of the brain alleged by the Patient to be connected with a fall on the head but believed to arise from long continued and excessive masturbation 
13501 Clinton arrives in Chicago on day of re-nomination

13505 New bomb attacks on Corsica despite crackdown vow 
13506 Sylvie Florence 
13507 AJACCIO Corsica 1996-08-29 
13508 Separatist guerrillas planted two bombs overnight at government offices on the French Mediterranean island of Corsica despite fresh warnings of a crackdown by Paris police said on Thursday 
13509 In the latest in a wave of attacks a two kg four lb bomb seriously damaged two floors of Agriculture Ministry offices located just 50 metres yards from a police station in the centre of the island capital Ajaccio 
13510 No one was hurt 
13511 A second device packed with five kg 10 lbs of explosive was defused before it could go off police said 
13512 The new attacks followed by a day a warning of a new get-tough policy by Paris toward the separatists who seek greater autonomy 
13513 Interior Minister Jean-Louis Debre under fire for staging secret talks with one of the largest of several rival underground nationalist groups told the daily La Corse in a statement he had given firm orders to police to round up those responsible for the bombings and bring them to justice 
13514 Judges on the island had accused Paris of taking a lax stance on guerrilla violence while conducting secret but widely-reported talks with separatists which have now failed 
13515 The latest bombing close on the heels of the new orders brought charges that police were powerless 
13516 No searches no arrests no police reinforcements visible on the island despite the ministry 's promises the daily France-Soir lamented 
13517 On the island as at the Place Beauvau the Interior Ministry 's Paris address people are well aware who is who and who is doing what 
13518 It is time to end this nightly farce said the pro-government daily Le Figaro in an editorial 
13519 No one immediately claimed responsibility for Thursday 's incidents which brought to 23 the number of guerrilla attacks on the resort island since mid-August when separatist guerrillas ended a shaky seven-month truce 
13520 Corsica has been racked by low-level separatist-inspired violence principally directed against government targets for two decades 
13521 The daily Le Monde reported on Wednesday some separatist movements were considering taking their attacks to the French mainland on the principle that 300 grammes of explosives on the continent have more impact than 300 kilos in Corsica 
13522 The newspaper said separatists may take advantage of social unrest widely expected on the mainland in coming weeks over government austerity plans to stoke a popular backlash against the government 
13523 Sweden 's OM to open London forest products bourse 
13524 STOCKHOLM 1996-08-29 
13525 Swedish options and derivatives exchange OM Gruppen AB said on Thursday it would open an electronic bourse for forest industry products in London in the first half of 1997 
13526 Together with subsidiaries OMLX the London Securities & Derivatives Exchange and OM Stockholm OM Gruppen will open an international electronic bourse for forest products in the first half of 1997 OM Gruppen said in a statement 
13527 The first commodity to be traded on the PULPEX bourse will be pulp but OM said trade would be extended to include products such as timber recycled paper and other paper qualities 
13528 Through the establishment of PULPEX London will have a commodities bourse for forest products which complements existing bourses for oil metals and softs coffee sugar and cocoa OM said 
13529 PULPEX was the result of a three-year project run in cooperation between OM and representatives of the forest industry the company said 
13530 Huge swings in the price of pulp over the past few years have made pulp producers profitability unpredictable and made investing in new production capacity a risky business 
13531 Without the ability to hedge prices changes in the world market price for pulp has had an immediate impact on players profitability OM said 
13532 It said global production of pulp amounted to around 200 million tonnes per year of which around 20 percent or 40 million tonnes was sold on the spot market 
13533 At current prices the value of this production was around $ 25 billion 
13534 PULPEX will be both a marketplace and a clearing house OM said adding that the British Securities and Investments Board had been informed of OM 's plans 
13535 PULPEX 's clearing operation will be covered by the parent company guarantee issued by OM Gruppen to its wholly-owned bourses and clearing organisations

13585 The Norwegian news agency NTB quoted another official on the island as saying no survivors had been found 
13586 The Vnukovo Airlines Tupolev 154 flight from Moscow carrying 129 passengers and a crew of 12 crashed in bad weather 10 km six miles east of Longyearbyen the island 's only airstrip officials said 
13587 First rescuers arrived shortly after 1 p.m. 1100 GMT and reported soon afterwards that most of the three-engine jet 's wreckage was scattered around the top of the small Opera mountain while the rest had slid down the mountainside

13592 Galeforce winds and heavy rains batter Belgium 
13593 BRUSSELS 1996-08-29 
13594 Torrential rains and galeforce winds battered Belgium on Thursday causing widespread damage as some areas had more rainfall in 24 hours than they normally get in a month the meteorological office said 
13595 Cellars were flooded trees uprooted and roofs damaged but there were no reports of any injuries an interior affairs ministry spokesman said 
13596 Some trains were delayed as fallen trees blocked lines 
13597 Brussels received 5.6 cm 2.24 inches of water in the past 24 hours compared to an average 7.4 cm 2.96 inches per month but in several communes in the south of the country up to 8 cm 3.2 inches fell the Royal Meteorological Institute RMT said 
13598 The RMT spokesman said that near the eastern city of Turnhout a group of boy scouts camping in a low-lying meadow had to be evacuated as water flooded their tents 
13599 The rain also severely hindered Belgian investigators excavations in the southern village of Jumet where they are looking for bodies in one of the houses of the main character in a paedophile sex-and-murder scandal 
13600 But the coastal towns got off lightly as the flooding that had been expected due to a combination of spring tides and high winds failed to materialise 
13601 Repsol shares up 65 pesetas on H1 results

13603 Shares in Spanish oil and chemicals group Repsol were up 65 pesetas to 4,150 after the company announced net first half profits fell 1.1 percent to 61.45 billion pesetas on the previous year 
13604 This was close to the market 's forecast of net profits of 61.94 billion 
13605 Shares in Repsol shot up 100 pesetas to 4,175 shortly after the figures having traded down 10 pesetas before the figures were released 
13606 It 's madness said an analyst at a Madrid brokerage adding that the market had overreacted to the news 
13607 People were waiting for the results to come out before buying 
13608 The rise has been very quick and very crazy 
13609 He predicted a correction perhaps as early as this session
