15044 Twilight zone for Wall Street as political race heats up 
15045 Pierre Belec 
15046 NEW YORK 1996-08-30 
15047 For Wall Street this is the season to be cautious as the presidential contest puts the stock market in the twilight zone 
15048 President Clinton Bob Dole and Ross Perot are hitting the road now that the partying is over and people who have billions of dollars invested in stocks were bracing for political promises that could have an impact on their wealth 
15049 Analysts believe that the candidates will add to the market 's list of uncertainties which already includes the question of whether the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to cool economic growth 
15050 They say the politicians will need to promote legislation that helps the economy without scaring the socks off financial markets 
15051 The worst thing that could happen for financial markets is that if Clinton and Dole start to trade shots in the middle of the ring with one-upmanship said Hugh Johnson chief investment officer at First Albany Corp. That 's when Wall Street will need to worry 
15052 He said that the bond market would be the first to react if the bidding intensifies and stocks would quickly drop as interest rates rise 
15053 I do n't think it would imply the collapse of the stock market unless the rise in rates touches off a dynamic within the market which would include selling by portfolio managers redemptions by individuals of mutual funds that would in turn pressure the portfolio managers to sell even more stock 
15054 This week the market weighed Dole 's proposal to lower federal income taxes by 15 percent across the board a package that carries a price tag of $ 548 billion 
15055 Clinton proposes an $ 8.4 billion re-election agenda that would spare most home-sellers from capital gains taxes and give employers tax incentives to hire people off the welfare rolls 
15056 Clinton claims Dole 's plan would increase the deficit while the White House said some corporate taxes would be raised to offset the cost of the president 's plan 
15057 The experts said there are some unusual risks for the market from this year 's political season because the rush to promise tax cuts to win votes could upset Wall Street 's expectations that Washington will balance the budget 
15058 The stock market will have to edit the promises and then do a probability study on those edited promises said John Geraghty at the consulting firm North American Equity Services 
15059 During the past four presidential elections the candidate that has favoured tax cuts has won 
15060 Ronald Reagan 's tax cut won him a second four-year term in the White House in 1984 while Democrat Walter Mondale who promised higher taxes lost 
15061 George Bush became president in 1988 on his no-new-tax campaign and Clinton won in 1992 with a promise to fatten workers paychecks 
15062 The trick they said will be for the candidates to continue to convince Wall Street that the Treasury 's 30-year bond the most closely-watched interest rate will fall to between 4 percent and 5 percent by the end of the decade 
15063 Johnson said that long-term interest rates have already been spooked by the election 
15064 The long-term bond jumped this week to 7.13 percent after starting the year at 5.95 percent 
15065 The surge of buying in stocks during the last two years has come amid an environment of low interest rates which has boosted corporate profits 
15066 But the market stalled this summer after the Dow Jones industrial average set a record high of 5,778.00 points on May 22 
15067 The market does n't seem to be able to make new highs and it has been back and forth in a fairly horizontal mode which looks like a holding pattern said Geraghty 
15068 He said the market reflects the political uncertainty now that Dole has sharply narrowed the gap with Clinton in the polls 
15069 Geraghty said that the one thing that could completely turn the election around are new findings in the Whitewater scandal that would damage the Clintons 
15070 Stocks are on a delicate edge because if something happens that looks like it could upset the presidency it could throw the political and to some extent the economic process into chaos Geraghty said 
15071 Right now Wall Street is pondering the candidates 
15072 We have an election where there are so many unknown variables that most people will probably want to hold fire and even take the chance that they will have to pay higher prices for stocks after the November election than take the risk that a shock to the system will hurt the stock market Geraghty said 
15073 On Friday the Dow Jones index closed down 31.44 points at 5,616.21 
15074 For the week it was down 106.53 points 
15075 The Nasdaq composite index closed 3.53 points lower Friday at 1,141.50 
15076 For the week it was down 1.55 points 
15077 The Standard & Poor 's index of 500 stocks was off 5.41 points at 651.99 down 15.03 points for the week 
15078 The American Stock Exchange index was down 1.66 points at 559.68 and was off 1.26 for the week 
15079 Brisk economic reports rattle markets anew 
15080 Glenn Somerville 
15081 WASHINGTON 1996-08-30 
15082 Factory orders rose in July and manufacturing surged in the Midwest in August reports said Friday sparking worries about inflation that battered financial markets for a second straight day 
15083 The Commerce Department said orders for manufactured goods climbed 1.8 percent in July to a seasonally adjusted $ 317.6 billion nearly twice the increase that had been expected 
15084 Shipments of everything from new cars to food items rose as did order backlogs in a sign that the strength in the industrial sector would continue in coming months 
15085 A separate report from Chicago area purchasing managers underlined the strength in manufacturing as the group 's barometer of manufacturing in the region jumped to 60 in August from 51.2 in July 
15086 A reading above 50 indicates growth in manufacturing 
15087 While production and orders rose at Midwest area businesses the prices they paid for goods used in manufacturing remained well in check 
15088 Analysts said the reports implied the economy was not slowing down in the third quarter after a burst of growth in the spring and that the lull in late June and July was more temporary than Federal Reserve policy-makers had wanted 
15089 It appears that August is showing an economy again reversing course and is not moving onto a significantly slower track at this point said economist Lynn Reaser of Barnett Banks Inc. in Jacksonville Fla 
15090 The reports fanned worries on Wall Street that the Fed the nation 's central bank would raise rates next month in a bid to ward off inflation driving stock and bond prices sharply lower for a second day running 
15091 The 30-year Treasury fell almost a point raising its yield which moves in the opposite direction from the price to 7.12 percent from 7.04 percent late Thursday 
15092 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.44 points to 5,616.21 after a 64.73-point decline Thursday 
15093 A third report from the Commerce Department on July personal income and spending pointed to a potential slowdown in consumer spending that some analysts said may help moderate growth in the second half 
15094 It showed spending rose only 0.2 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $ 5.15 trillion after dropping a revised 0.4 percent in June 
15095 Incomes from wages salaries and all other sources gained 0.1 percent to a rate of $ 6.47 trillion after a 0.9 percent jump in June 
15096 July 's slight gain in incomes was the weakest in six months since January when they were flat 
15097 Economist Joel Naroff of First Union bank in Philadelphia said consumer spending which fuels two-thirds of the nation 's economy may be much slower in the third quarter than in the first half which should slow economic growth 
15098 The FOMC Federal Open Market Committee has been forecasting a slowing in economic activity and moderating household demand will have a large impact on overall economic growth Naroff said in a written comment 
15099 The policy-making FOMC is to meet on Sept 
15100 24 to plot interest-rate strategy 
15101 It already has adopted a bias toward raising rates to keep a lid on wage and price rises and help sustain the 5-1 2-year-old economic expansion 
15102 In an interview on the cable television network CNBC Friday Federal Reserve Governor Lawrence Lindsey said there still were mixed signals about the economy 's direction 
15103 I think that on balance it is looking a little bit on the strong side Lindsey said 
15104 He added that with expansion as solid as it is and with unemployment so low the greater risks are clearly that we might see some overheating 
15105 While July consumer spending rose only slightly there were ample indications that consumers remained confident 
15106 The University of Michigan 's August index of consumer sentiment made available on Friday to paying subscribers rose to 95.3 from 94.7 in July 
15107 Reaser said strong consumer confidence coupled with relatively lean inventories were providing manufacturers with a reason to gear up production 
15108 The economy is not going to be expanding at the 4.8 percent annual rate that we had in the second quarter but it is likely to keep expanding in the 3 percent range she said above the 2 percent to 2-1/4 percent that the Fed considers to be non-inflationary 
15109 New orders to factories were strong for durable goods like new cars and for nondurables like paper and food products 
15110 Orders for durable goods meant to last three years or more rose a revised 1.7 percent in July after falling 0.2 percent in June 
15111 Orders for nondurables jumped 1.8 percent following a 1.2 percent decrease in June 
15112 Mexican avocados not expected in U.S 
15113 Maggie McNeil 
15114 WASHINGTON 1996-08-30 
15115 U.S. Agriculture Department officials said Friday that Mexican avocados which are restricted from entering the continental United States will not likely be entering U.S. markets any time soon even if the controversial ban were lifted today 
15116 The opportunity to import Mexican avocados probably wo n't become possible for another year said Paul Drazek senior trade advisor to Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman 
15117 We could lift the ban tomorrow but that would not mean anything immediately said Drazek 
15118 We probably would not see avacados come in until next season next November 
15119 The Agriculture Department proposed more than a year ago to significantly ease an 82-year ban on Mexican avocados 
15120 Under the administration 's proposal the borders to the Mexican produce would be opened into 19 Northern and Northeastern states from November through February 
15121 The plan has raised a storm of protest from U.S. avocado growers who are largely concentrated in California 
15122 California growers have charged that removing the restrictions even on a limited basis would endanger the $ 1 billion U.S. industry if potentially harmful Mexican insects were brought into the country along with the avocados 
15123 Mexican officials contend that there is no scientific basis for the ban and that it is illegal under international trading rules of the World Trade Organisation 
15124 Proponents of the plan discount the worries of the U.S. growers and say the plan has enough safeguards built into it to eliminate any significant threat to American producers 
15125 Under the proposal only imports of export-quality avocados growing in approved orchards in Michoacan Mexico the country 's main avocado area would be allowed 
15126 Mexican growers and distributors would have to abide by strict rules established by the Mexican and U.S. agriculture agencies 
15127 The California Avocado Commission which has spearheaded the opposition to lifting the ban said new data the group submitted to the Agriculture Department last spring shows the department underestimated the pest problem in Mexico and have urged that the agency reopen its study of the issue 
15128 The administration is still studying the new data and officials have said that if experts think the information is significant the agency could reopen its investigation 
15129 But U.S. avocado industry sources said that while they may have delayed the plan for a while they ultimately do not expect the administration to change its position 
15130 From a common-sense view the department should reconsider this plan but due to politics they will probably go ahead with this said Tom Bellamore of the California avocado group 
15131 Administration officials said they want to get the issue resolved as quickly as possible but said there is no timetable they are working under 
15132 It 's a very complicated issue said the Agriculture Department 's Drazek 
15133 We 'll get it resolved as quickly as we can based on the best available science 
15134 U.S. Cardinal Bernardin says has terminal cancer 
15135 CHICAGO 1996-08-30 
15136 Chicago Cardinal Joseph Bernardin head of the second-largest U.S. Roman Catholic archdiocese said on Friday his doctors had diagnosed him as having liver cancer and he had a year or less to live 
15137 Bernardin 68 underwent extensive surgery for pancreatic cancer in June 1995 followed by months of chemotherapy which he said made him more aware of his own vulnerabilities and the need to minister to the sick 
15138 On Wednesday examinations indicated that the cancer has returned this time in the liver 
15139 I am told that it is terminal and that my life expectancy is one year or less a composed Bernardin told a news conference 
15140 In 14 years as Chicago 's archbishop he built a prayerful saintly image and was deeply involved in world church issues and publicly committed to rooting out abuses by clergy 
15141 I have been assured that I still have some quality time left he said saying he would undergo a new form of chemotherapy but his doctors have told him there was only a slim chance of a cure and the liver cancer was inoperable 
15142 It 's not going to be easy to say goodbye to everybody 
15143 Death does have some sad dimensions to it but I am a man of faith he said 
15144 Death is a natural phenomenom 
15145 He said he would serve until the end as cardinal 
15146 Pancreatic cancer is among the most deadly forms of the disease although Bernardin 's case was caught early 
15147 Surgeons removed a cancerous kidney parts of his pancreas and stomach small intestine bile duct and surrounding tissues 
15148 He made a rapid recovery and resumed most of his duties but then developed a deteriorating condition in his spine that caused him great pain and shortened his height by several inches 
15149 He was scheduled to undergo back surgery next month but that was cancelled when the cancer was discovered in his liver in order to avoid delaying the start of chemotherapy 
15150 The spare soft-spoken son of an Italian stonecutter took over the Chicago archdiocese the nation 's second-largest after Los Angeles with 2.3 million parishioners in 1982 
15151 Ironically Bernardin who developed a progressive much-praised programme to deal with pedophilia involving priests became the highest-ranking church official ever accused of sexual improprieties when a former seminary student leveled charges in 1993 that he had been sexually abused by Bernardin during the 1970s 
15152 Bernardin steadfastly denied the charges and the former student later recanted his tale of abuse 
15153 Bernardin prayed with him before he died from AIDS last year 
15154 Bernardin who became archbishop of Cincinnati in 1972 played an increasingly prominent role in the U.S. church as a moderate voice of compromise among liberals and conservatives in the ranks of the bishops 
15155 This month he announced that he would oversee a series of conferences to find common ground among American Catholics 
15156 Previously he was instrumental in drafting church policy on war peace and nuclear arms and for seven years he headed the bishops anti-abortion policy committee espousing a policy describing human life as a seamless garment 
15157 Boatmen 's deal could spark more mergers 
15158 Brad Dorfman 
15159 CHICAGO 1996-08-30 
15160 The $ 9.5 billion proposed acquisition of Boatmen 's Bancshares Inc. by NationsBank Corp. could spark a flurry of other mergers involving Missouri banks which until last year were protected from outside buyers by state regulations 
15161 NationsBank just strolled into the Midwest and bagged the biggest banking trophy in the landscape said Michael Ancell banking industry analyst at Edward D. Jones & Co 
15162 Whoever wants a big market position in the Midwest has to come in and grab Mercantile or Commerce 
15163 St. Louis-based Mercantile Bancorp Inc. a bank holding company with $ 18.04 billion in assets was seen by many analysts as the most attractive Missouri franchise in size after Boatmen 's 
15164 Kansas City Mo.-based Commerce Bancshares Inc. with $ 9.32 billion in assets also could help a regional bank establish a strong presence in the lower Midwest analysts added 
15165 It focuses more attention on Mercantile Commerce and Roosevelt said James Weber analyst at A.G. Edwards & Sons 
15166 Roosevelt Financial Group Inc is a $ 9.33 billion asset-St 
15167 Louis based thrift 
15168 Now the most coveted bank out there is Mercantile Weber said 
15169 Mercantile and Commerce did not return phone calls seeking comment 
15170 Among those seen as having an interest in buying in Missouri are Minneapolis-based First Bank System Inc. and Norwest Corp. Ohio-based KeyCorp and Banc One Corp. and First Chicago NBD Corp. in Illinois 
15171 Representatives of First Bank Norwest Banc One and First Chicago said the banks do not comment on rumors of possible mergers or acquisitions 
15172 KeyCorp contacted by phone would not comment 
15173 With a presence in nine states and $ 41 billion in assets 
15174 Boatmen 's was the prize in Missouri where barriers to outside acquirers were brought down last year by a federal banking statute 
15175 Boatmen 's was the plum of Missouri and was the plum of the central Midwest Weber said 
15176 Talk that the Missouri banks were seeking inflated prices from buyers was seen as a reason a deal has not occurred sooner 
15177 But NationsBank 's bid representing a premium of 40 percent for Boatmen 's stock was large enough to get the deal done 
15178 I think Boatmen 's was shopping itself and everybody knew if you wanted to be the winning buyer here you had to make the bid nobody would beat Ancell said 
15179 But some analysts cautioned that other targets should not expect as large a premium 
15180 They also questioned whether NationsBank can recoup shareholder value with such a large bid for Boatmen 's 
15181 I think initially some stocks will trade up on sympathy but the wild premium NationsBank put on this deal here I do n't see a lot of other deals being done at this premium said Michael Durante analyst at McDonald & Co

15186 The view of the U.S. government on Farrakhan 's not accepting any gifts from Libya is well-known 
15187 Davies also noted We 've talked about the passport restriction for travel to Libya but he did not elaborate 
15188 The U.S. Treasury Department on Wednesday denied Farrakhan 's application to receive the $ 250,000 award or a $ 1 billion donation Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi had pledged to Farrakhan 's Nation of Islam group after they met last January 
15189 Farrakhan organised last October 's Million Man March that brought thousands of black men to Washington for a peaceful rally 
15190 The Treasury Department said Libya was on the U.S. list of states that sponsor international terrorism and noted that Tripoli has refused to hand over two Libyan suspects in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie Scotland 
15191 That refusal led to the imposition of U.N. sanctions on Libya

15210 Titanic recovery mission is scrapped 
15211 NEW YORK 1996-08-30 
15212 Equipment problems and mechanical failure forced a recovery expedition to give up efforts to retrieve a giant slab of the RMS Titanic from the ocean floor a spokeswoman said on Friday 
15213 A 20-ton piece of the Titanic 's steel hull which had been attached by cables to a recovery ship off the coast of Newfoundland Canada fell back to the bottom of the sea said Erin Purcell of Boston-based Reagan Communications that represents two of the ships used in the expedition 
15214 The piece of hull lifted from the ocean floor by means of several diesel-filled bags had been stuck about 200 feet about 70 metres below the water 's surface before it fell she said 
15215 It fell as recovery crews were trying to haul the piece into more shallow water and several of the bags burst and cables snapped she said 
15216 The steel-hulled Titanic thought to be unsinkable struck an iceberg on April 14 1912 and sank killing 1,523 of the 2,200 passengers and crew on board 
15217 The wreck was located in 1985 
15218 Passengers who had paid $ 1,500 and up to accompany the recovery expedition on two cruise ships had returned back to port on Thursday Purcell said 
15219 Bonn appeals for Middle East peace 
15220 BONN 1996-08-30 
15221 The German government urged Israelis and Palestinians on Friday to avoid any course of action that might jeopardise the peace process in the Middle East 
15222 Israel announced this week the expansion of Jewish West Bank settlements surrounding Jerusalem and the demolition of an Arab community centre in East Jerusalem 
15223 City officials there said the centre was being erected illegally 
15224 But Palestinian President Yasser Arafat said the moves by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu 's government were tantamount to war 
15225 Tension has been rising in the region since 
15226 We believe that the Israeli settlement policy in the occupied areas is an obstacle to the establishment of peace German Foreign Ministry spokesman Martin Erdmann said 
15227 All concerned must avoid taking any course of action that could pose an obstacle to the peace process and which could make a peaceful solution difficult he said as news came of a renewed breakdown in Arab-Israeli peace talks in Jerusalem 
15228 Erdmann told reporters Bonn supported European Union efforts to persuade Israel to stop further Jewish settlement on the West Bank 
15229 The foreign ministry later announced Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy would visit Bonn for talks with his German counterpart Klaus Kinkel next month 
15230 The ministry said Levy and Kinkel would discuss the Middle East process and German-Israeli relations at their meeting on September 9 
15231 Levy 's visit would be the first by an Israeli cabinet minister since Netanyahu 's conservative government took power in une this year the ministry said 
15232 Before Levy 's arrival in Bonn German Defence Minister Volker Ruehe will visit Israel from September 2 to 4 the defence ministry said 
15233 Ruehe planned to meet his Israeli counterpart Yitzhak Mordechai and Israeli President Ezer Weizman the ministry said 
15234 He was also expected to meet Prime Minister Netanyahu and opposition leader Shimon Peres for talks 
15235 France expels African Air France unions protest 
15236 PARIS 1996-08-30 
15237 France on Friday expelled another African man seized in a police raid on a Paris church as about 100 Air France workers denounced charters of shame used to fly illegal immigrants home 
15238 A Guinean man detained in a round-up in the Saint-Bernard church a week ago was deported on a scheduled Air France flight to Conakry after his appeals failed a spokesman for Air France 's pro-Socialist CFDT union said 
15239 He was apparently the eighth African deported from among 210 people evicted from the church after a 50-day occupation aimed at securing residence permits unions said 
15240 Most of the others have been released after a brief stay in detention 
15241 About 100 people from the CFDT and the Communist-led CGT unions marched outside Air France headquarters at Charles de Gaulle airport north of Paris against the use of civilian jets and staff in deporting illegal immigrants 
15242 We must obtain a formal commitment from Air France chairman Christian Blanc that no plane no personnel be used to transform our air companies into charters of shame CFDT spokesman Francois Cabrera said 
15243 He said civilians should not be police accomplices 
15244 Twenty-three out of 25 charters flying illegal immigrants home since Prime Minister Alain Juppe 's government took office in May 1995 have been civilian jets 
15245 The other two were military jets 
15246 Separately Juppe confirmed the conservative government was preparing to submit a draft bill to parliament to tighten laws on illegal workers as part of a crackdown on immigration 
15247 Legislation is insufficient in several areas notably in those concerning illegal work Juppe told reporters

15286 Canadian bonds open softer spreads to U.S. shrink 
15287 TORONTO 1996-08-30 
15288 Canadian bonds opened softer on Friday pulled lower by a sinking U.S. market but outperformed U.S. bonds on positive Canadian economic data analysts said 
15289 I think this morning 's Canadian numbers were very supportive of narrower spreads particularly the current account number said Jim Webber director of fixed-income research with TD Securities Inc 
15290 Canada 's 8.0 percent bond due 2023 fell C$ 0.45 to C$ 101.15 to yield 7.894 percent 
15291 The U.S. 30-year benchmark fell 30/32 to yield 7.12 percent 
15292 The spread between benchmark bonds narrowed 77 basis points from 81 basis points at the close of trading on Wednesday 
15293 Statistics Canada on Friday reported Canada 's current account moved to a higher-than-expected C$ 1.15 billion second quarter surplus from a C$ 1.62 billion deficit in the first quarter 
15294 It was the first surplus since the fourth quarter of 1984 
15295 The agency also reported Canada 's real gross domestic product rose a weaker-than-expected 0.3 percent in the second quarter or 1.3 percent at an annualized rate 
15296 While the data provided support for Canadian bonds both Canadian and U.S. markets weakened after the release of strong U.S. economic data including a report showing the Chicago Purchasing Managers August index rose to 60 from 51.2 in July 
15297 The purchasing managers number is extremely extremely strong said Webber 
15298 In other news the Toronto Bond Traders Association said it is recommending that dealings in the Canadian bond market end early at 1400 EDT 1800 GMT on Friday 
15299 The Canadian market typically closes early on holiday weekends and Canadian financial markets will be closed on Monday for Labour Day 
15300 In other prices the 7.0 percent of 2006 fell C$ 0.28 to C$ 96.89 to yield 7.437 percent 
15301 The U.S. 10-year benchmark fell 21/32 to yield 6.95 percent 
15302 The spread between the two bonds narrowed to 49 basis points from 54 basis points at the close of trading on Thursday 
15303 The three-month cash bill traded at 4.04 percent against the U.S. three-month bill at 5.26 percent

15334 Syria slams Israel on settlements 
15335 DAMASCUS 1996-08-30 
15336 Syria on Friday condemned Israel 's settlement policy and said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was preparing for war with Arabs 
15337 Practices of the Israeli government especially its settlement activities came to confirm that dealing with this government inflicts the biggest harm on the Arab cause state-run Damascus Radio said in a commentary 
15338 When this government insists on stabbing the peace process and tearing it apart this means that it is preparing for war the radio said 
15339 Palestinian President Yasser Arafat described this week the decision to expand settlements in the West Bank as a declaration of war 
15340 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza observed a strike on Thursday to protest against the Israeli move 
15341 The radio urged Arabs to unify their ranks to thwart the policies of the right-wing Israeli government 
15342 Israel could not confront a united Arab stand or usurp their rights because the Arab rights could be regained when they achieve unity and solidarity Damascus radio said 
15343 It welcomed the international criticism of Israel 's settlement policies but called for practical steps to force the Israeli government to abandon this policy 
15344 It is important to translate the criticism into pressuring action to prevent Israel from undermining the big international efforts aimed at making the peace process achieve success the radio said 
15345 Syria and Arabs have been dismayed by Netanyahu 's refusal to trade the occupied Arab lands for peace his support for the expansion of settlements and his insistance on Jerusalem as a unifed capital for Israel 
15346 Syria has held sporadic peace talks with Israel since 1991 without achieving a breakthrough 
15347 Egypt police detain 26 suspected Moslem militants 
15348 CAIRO 1996-08-30 
15349 Police have detained 26 suspected members of Egypt 's largest militant group al-Gama'a al-Islamiya Islamic Group government newspapers reported on Friday 
15350 They said police arrested the militants in the eastern Sharqiyah province after capturing their leader Rami al-Saadani in a satellite city outside Cairo 
15351 Al-Akhbar newspapers said the men had been plotting against strategic institutions and prominent individuals but gave no other details 
15352 The newspapers said the men were being interrogated 
15353 State security officials were not immediately available for comment 
15354 More than 960 people have been killed in the armed struggle the Gama'a launched in 1992 to topple President Hosni Mubarak 's government and establish a purist Islamic state in its place 
15355 Israel blocks Palestinian pilgrims progress 
15356 Sami Aboudi 
15357 AL-RAM West Bank 1996-08-30 
15358 Kamil Jamil did n't have a prayer 
15359 An Israeli roadblock stopped the 38-year-old Palestinian from answering Yasser Arafat 's call to worship at Jerusalem 's al-Aqsa mosque on Friday 
15360 Go home 
15361 There are no prayers today an Israeli soldier yelled at Jamil in Hebrew 
15362 Palestinian President Arafat attacking Israel 's decision to expand Jewish settlements and its policy on Jerusalem went before the Palestinian legislature on Wednesday to urge the two million Arabs in the West Bank and Gaza to go to the holy city 
15363 Pilgrims stood little chance of making progress 
15364 Palestinians have been banned by Israel from travelling from the West Bank to Jerusalem since suicide bombings by Moslem militants killed 59 people in the Jewish state in February and March 
15365 And Israeli checkpoints have circled Jerusalem since 1993 a concrete and constant reminder of Israel 's hold on a city it considers its eternal capital 
15366 The PLO wants Arab East Jerusalem as the capital of a future Palestinian state 
15367 Only a few Palestinians trickled to the roadblocks 
15368 They were immediately turned back 
15369 I am heeding Abu Ammar 's Arafat 's call to pray at al-Aqsa and I came 
15370 It is our duty towards al-Aqsa to come and pray Jamil said 
15371 A tourist from Jordan was also told by Israeli soldiers at the al-Ram checkpoint that he could not enter Jerusalem 
15372 We have a peace treaty with them and we let them go wherever they want when they come to Jordan said the tourist Khaled Hijazi 37 
15373 I feel terrible 
15374 I am entitled to see Jerusalem he said 
15375 Some Palestinians took to back roads only to run into waiting Israeli security forces 
15376 The Israelis have no right to prevent us from going to pray 
15377 What kind of peace is this that prevents us from reaching our holy places ? 
15378 asked Mustafa Hoshiyeh a 27-year-old West Bank labourer turned around by a police patrol on a back road 
15379 Abu Ammar Arafat is right 
15380 We have signed a peace treaty with the Israelis but on the ground we see that nothing has changed said 20-year-old Ali Ahmed from Qalandia refugee camp

15414 Consumer spending incomes edge up in July 
15415 Glenn Somerville 
15416 WASHINGTON 1996-08-30 
15417 Consumer spending barely edged up in July the Commerce Department said Friday as income growth slowed abruptly to the weakest pace in six months 
15418 Spending rose 0.2 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $ 5.15 trillion after dropping a revised 0.4 percent in June 
15419 Incomes from wages salaries and all other sources gained 0.1 percent to a rate of $ 6.47 trillion after a 0.9 percent jump in June 
15420 Department officials said July 's slight gain in incomes was the weakest for any month since January when they were flat 
15421 Wages and salaries came under pressure in July as a shorter average workweek and lower hourly earnings cut into paychecks 
15422 The department said wages and salaries decreased by $ 6.9 billion in July after climbing $ 45 billion in June 
15423 In July average weekly hours and average hourly earnings declined more than offsetting the effect of an increase in employment Commerce said 
15424 But more money went into savings accounts as savings held at 5.3 cents out of each dollar earned in both June and July 
15425 That was the highest savings rate since October last year when 5.5 cents out of each dollar earned was being saved 
15426 The generally lackluster report on spending and incomes in July had been expected 
15427 At the same time the department said in a separate report that new orders received by U.S. factories climbed strongly in July with widespread gains across most major categories 
15428 Orders increased 1.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted $ 317.6 billion significantly stronger than the 1 percent rise forecast by Wall Street economists 
15429 That followed a revised 0.7 percent decline in June orders 
15430 Commerce said previously that spending at retail stores was up only 0.1 percent in July partly because of softer sales of new cars and light trucks 
15431 In addition the Labour Department 's July employment report had foreshadowed the muted income growth 
15432 It showed average hourly earnings fell in July by 0.2 percent to $ 11.00 and the average workweek shortened to 34.3 hours from 34.7 in June 
15433 Gains in personal income which includes wages and salaries as well as income from sources such as dividends interest and businesses are essential for funding consumer purchases which fuel two-thirds of national economic activity 
15434 Spending on all types of durable goods which includes cars fell to an annual rate of $ 626.3 billion in July from $ 633.6 billion in June 
15435 But spending on nondurable products increased moderately to a rate of $ 1.55 trillion from $ 1.54 trillion in June while spending for services was up to $ 2.97 trillion in July from $ 2.96 trillion 
15436 Payrolls of manufacturing companies rose in July by $ 2.3 billion to an annual rate of $ 678 billion 
15437 World Markets Overnight Summary Aug 30 
15438 NEW YORK 1996-08-29 
15439 WORLD MARKETS ROUND-UP

15448 STOCKS SINK AS BOND RATES JUMP ON STRONG DATA 
15449 Blue-chip stocks sank to their biggest loss since mid-July Thursday as fresh signs of a surprisingly strong economy boosted long-term bond interest rates above 7 percent 
15450 The dollar rose slightly against the German mark but edged lower against the Japanese yen 
15451 The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 64.73 points at 5,647.65 its largest drop since July 15 when it closed with a loss of 161 points 
15452 In the broader market declining issues beat advances 1,627 to 743 on moderate volume of 321 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange 
15453 In the bond market the 30-year Treasury bond fell 23/32 of a point or $ 7.1875 on a $ 1,000 bond raising its yield to 7.04 percent the highest since July 31 from 6.98 percent at Wednesday 's close 
15454 Seven percent creates psychological problems and a legitimate competitor for money from equities said Ralph Bloch chief technical analyst at Raymond James 
15455 We could carry another 100 points lower in the Dow he said 
15456 I 'm telling clients things are dicey going into next Friday Sept 
15457 6 so let 's be careful 
15458 Wall Street on Sept 
15459 6 faces the key monthly employment report which has been known to cause dramatic swings in stock prices 
15460 We had two very strong economic reports said David Shulman Salomon Bros 
15461 chief equity strategist 
15462 There are more worries in bond land 
15463 Fears of a Fed tightening next month have resurfaced for the first time since the end of July 
15464 The Commerce Department reported that the nation 's gross domestic product expanded at a 4.8 percent annual rate in the three months from April through June instead of the 4.2 percent estimated a month ago 
15465 In another report sales of new homes jumped unexpectedly in July to the briskest rate in five months driving prices up in a strong housing market 
15466 Sales shot up 7.9 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 783,000 units the strongest since February when new homes were selling at a rate of 784,000 a year 
15467 Analysts said the stock market was also worried about the impact on President Clinton 's re-election bid of his top political strategist resigning 
15468 Dick Morris who is credited with resurrecting Clinton 's political fortunes over the past 18 months by masterminding his turn to the political centre quit after a supermarket tabloid reported he engaged in a yearlong affair with a prostitute with whom he allegedly shared confidential campaign documents 
15469 Analysts said Wall Street had grown accustomed to a moderate Republican in the form of Democratic President Clinton 
15470 Morris departure raised fears that Clinton would veer more to the left in a second term 
15471 The dollar closed at 1.4772 marks up from 1.4767 late Wednesday 
15472 The dollar slipped to 108.40 yen from 108.45 
15473 Oil markets rose sharply on a combination of low stocks two hurricanes and allegations of illicit trading by Iraq 
15474 September heating oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed 1.63 cents higher at 63.67 cents a gallon September unleaded gasoline finished 1.39 cents up at 63.72 cents a gallon and October crude rose 44 cents to $ 22.15 a barrel 
15475 December cotton closed 0.95 cent higher at 77.06 cents per pound on the New York Cotton Exchange despite some easing of concern about the twin hurricane threat to key U.S. growing areas with forecasts indicating both storms may remain offshore 
15476 Overseas London 's FTSE 100 index had earlier climbed to 3,8921.1 just below its record of 3,922.1 before edging down through the afternoon session to finish the day at 3,885.0 a fall of 33.7 points 
15477 In Tokyo the key 225-share Nikkei average shed 156.65 points or 0.76 percent to end at 20,553.16 
15478 Pirelli cables look to tap Chinese growth 
15479 David Jones 
15480 MILAN 1996-08-30 
15481 Italian tyre and cables giant Pirelli on Friday announced its long-awaited move into China with a cables joint venture set to capitalise on the rapidly-growing Chinese telecommunications market 
15482 Pirelli is linking with Hong Kong-based group CITIC Pacific in a venture to be called the Wuxi Tong Ling Company Ltd which will operate in partnership with a local industrial company at its existing factory in Wuxi Jiangsu province Shanghai 
15483 The partners will invest around $ 30 million in the existing copper cable plant at Wuxi to update technology and include optic fibre production with annual turnover expected to reach $ 60 million within the next few years 
15484 The move marks a further move by Pirelli 's cables division to expand in the fast-growing Far Eastern developing markets with the group already present in Indonesia India and Malaysia 
15485 This is really positive news for Pirelli and I expect that it will produce one of the best half-year results in late September compared to other industrial Italian companies said analyst Paula Buratti at Indosuez 
15486 She emphasised that the move was positive because Pirelli will have management control of the Chinese venture and it also showed another example of Pirelli exporting its technical know-how to developing markets 
15487 Pirelli shares reacted favourable even though talks had been underway for some time and news about a venture had been widely expected 
15488 The shares rose 0.2 percent to 2,555 lire by 1350 GMT in an easier Milan stock market 
15489 This will be Pirelli 's first industrial involvement in a Chinese market where demand for telecommunication networks is expected to grow to 80-100 million new lines between 1996 and 2000 doubling demand for optical cables 
15490 China 's second largest telecoms operator Unicom already has a mandate from the central government to establish 15 million new phone lines by the year 2000 which will necessitate new trunk line systems and local distribution networks 
15491 The starting of this production base in China has for our group an undoubted strategic value representing an important enhancement of our presence in Asia said Pirelli SpA chairman and chief executive officer Marco Tonchetti Provera 
15492 Pirelli Cables has global sales of over $ 3.5 billion and has become a large supplier of optic cables and systems to major telecoms carriers in the U.S. Europe and the Far East 
15493 CITIC Pacific is a major Hong Kong-listed company focusing on infrastruture trading distribution and property with 28 percent of its 1995 profits coming from telecoms 
15494 It has investments in several industrial joint ventures in China 
15495 Dutch bond futures revival delayed EOE 
15496 AMSTERDAM 1996-08-30 
15497 A broad attempt to spur activity in Dutch bond futures has been delayed to give participants a chance to become familiar with the trading system the European Options Exchange EOE said on Friday 
15498 Market-making in the rarely-traded FTO contract was expected to begin today but an EOE spokesman said the 10 banks and brokers involved in the initiative needed time to get accustomed to changes in the electronic trading system 
15499 It 's not ready yet 
15500 We found it wise to take some time between the commitment to start and the actual start EOE spokesman Lex van Drooge told Reuters 
15501 He said no date had been fixed yet for the start of price making in the 10-year contract but the EOE had agreed to speak again to the participants in one to two weeks 
15502 Investors in Dutch bonds currently use German bond futures to hedge their portfolios because the FTO contract is so illiquid 
15503 A limited attempt to reinvigorate the contract two years ago failed 
15504 Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000 Fax +31 20 504 5040 
15505 OSCE defends record over Chechnya peace mission 
15506 BONN 1996-08-30 
15507 The head of an international mediating mission defended its record on Friday in the face of criticism by pro-Moscow leaders in breakway Chechnya and insisted it was doing its best to bring peace to the region 
15508 Flavio Cotti the chairman of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe OSCE told German radio the Vienna-based body viewed the conflict in Chechnya as an internal Russian problem 
15509 The OSCE is completely involved 
15510 But one must not forget that the OSCE only has limited powers there said Cotti who is also the Swiss foreign minister 
15511 Our mission in Chechnya has done all it can within the given limitations 
15512 Pro-Moscow leaders in Chechnya have criticised Tim Guldimann the Swiss diplomat who heads the OSCE Chechnya mission saying he was biased toward Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev president of the self-declared separatist government 
15513 Russian peacemaker Alexander Lebed and Chechen separatist military leader Aslan Maskhadov started a new round of peace talks on Friday just outside the rebel region 
15514 Cotti said Chechnya must remain part of Russia but the solution to the conflict would be to accord the region maximum autonomy within Russia 's borders 
15515 There is no doubt that Chechnya according to OSCE principles belongs to a state called Russia he said pointing out that Russia was an OSCE member and it was not the organisation 's policy to challenge members sovereignty 
15516 He added that the OSCE was the only international body which has been allowed into the Chechnya to monitor the human rights situation there but that its means were restricted by the fact that the conflict was a internal issue 
15517 We have a small concept the details of which have yet to be worked out 
15518 Chechnya must be accorded the maximum autonomy possible within the framework of Russian integrity said Cotti 
15519 Dutch say no reason to reopen El Al carqo enquiry 
15520 THE HAGUE 1996-08-30 
15521 The Dutch transport minister Annemarie Jorritsma told the country second chamber that there is no further need to investigate the 1992 crash of an El Al freighter which left 43 dead in an Amsterdam suburb 
15522 She said that a request from her ministry for the aircraft 's waybill documentation and further information about the contents of its hold had been complied with by El Al 's head office in Tel Aviv 
15523 The Dutch transport ministry had come in for pressure from a cross-section of Dutch members of parliaments in May this year some of whom believed the aircraft had been carrying unlisted dangerous goods 
15524 Others said they thought the aircraft was loaded with too much airfreight 
15525 Jorritsma said the latest evidence from El Al in no way supported the allegations and added there is no justification for a further investigation into the incident 
15526 Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542 8982 Fax +44 171 542 5017 
15527 Armenians Azeris hold peace talks in Germany 
15528 BONN 1996-08-30 
15529 Representatives from Armenia and Azerbaijan held talks earlier this week in Germany on bringing a lasting peace to the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region a diplomatic source close to the talks said on Friday 
15530 The source who spoke on condition of anonymity said Azerbaijani presidential adviser Vafa Gulizade and his Armenian counterpart Zhirayr Liparityan met to discuss the disputed enclave on Wednesday and had now flown home 
15531 An uneasy ceasefire has prevailed in Nagorno-Karabakh which represents around 20 percent of Azeri territory since May 1994 after ethnic Armenians drove Azeris out of the region 
15532 The conflict which began in 1988 claimed over 10,000 lives 
15533 The main subject of the talks was the search for a peaceful solution for Nagorno-Karabakh the source said 
15534 He declined to reveal any more details about the content of the talks or their exact location in Germany 
15535 Azerbaijan has said it is prepared to grant autonomy to Nagorno-Karabakh if Armenian forces pull out but will not accept Armenia 's demands for the independence of the enclave 
15536 Russia 's Interfax news agency reported on Tuesday the officials had departed for negotiations in Germany adding that face-to-face talks between the two sides first took place last December in Amsterdam 
15537 Interfax said the discussions were being held in parallel with peace talks mediated by the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe OSCE and the broad-based Minsk Group of countries led by Russia and Finland 
15538 Sombre mood on Arctic island after plane crash 
15539 Rolf Soderlind 
15540 LONGYEAR Norway 1996-08-30 
15541 The windblown chilly streets of this tiny Arctic town are all but deserted and flags are flying at half-mast beneath a brooding clouded sky 
15542 Longyear is a town in mourning a close-knit community that has been shattered 
15543 Disaster struck on Thursday when a Russian airliner bringing coal miners to work crashed as it came in to land at the airport killing all 141 people on board 
15544 It 's a sight I will never forget 
15545 I will remember it for the rest of my life said Stig Onarheim 
15546 He was one of a handful of rescuers who raced to the scene of the crash in a helicopter on Thursday hoping in vain to find survivors 
15547 The plane smashed into a snow-capped mountain on the Arctic island of Spitzbergen on Thursday just east of Longyear 
15548 Imagine a big plane with a lot of luggage and people on board 
15549 Think of all that mixed together with twisted wrecked parts on the slope Onarheim 29 told Reuters 
15550 Police and local officials have sealed off the crash site protecting it from intrusive reporters and from the polar bears that roam freely across the icy expanses 
15551 The dead were all Russians and Ukrainians coming to work in the mining towns of Barentsburg and Pyramiden 
15552 Longyear is a Norwegian settlement of just over 1,000 people but it also feels the loss keenly 
15553 I have trouble finding the words to express my grief 
15554 It 's a tragedy for everyone 
15555 We know many of the people who live in Barentsburg some of them could have been on the plane said Johan Sletten 52 
15556 Sletten a caretaker who has lived on the island for 30 years said the Norwegian and Russian communities visit frequently competing at soccer in the summer and with snow-scooter races in the winter 
15557 Teenage shop assistant Heidi Groenstein was blunter 
15558 I 'm glad it was not a Norwegian plane she said 
15559 Just think of it a mining village where so many workers die 
15560 They must be having a tough time of it now 
15561 Barentsburg just a few hours ride by snow-scooter or 15 minutes by helicopter from Longyear has asked to be left alone with its grief and told reporters to stay away 
15562 Around 100 Russian and Ukrainian miners were waiting in Longyear to fly home on the plane that crashed 
15563 They were given shelter in the town 's church overnight and ate a sombre breakfast before getting on a bus for the airport 
15564 Another plane had been sent from Moscow to pick them up 
15565 At this time of year the only colour in Longyear comes from the brightly-painted wooden houses 
15566 Everything else is muddy the waters of the fjord leaden 
15567 Winter is in the air 
15568 Barentsburg is an even grimmer place a run-down testament to the hardships of the new Russia 
15569 Spitzbergen lies some 500 miles 800 km off the northern tip of Norway and endures one of the most extreme climates on the planet 
15570 Inhabited by fewer than 3,000 people in total it sees the sun for 24 hours a day during summer and is plunged into round-the-clock darkness in the winter months 
15571 The terrain is mountainous the only roads are dirt tracks 
15572 Norway rules the island group under the terms of a 1920s international treaty which gave many other nations the right to establish setttlements and exploit the coal that is still mined there 
15573 Only Russia has chosen to do so 
15574 Ericsson says wins 1.2 bln SKR China order 
15575 STOCKHOLM 1996-08-30 
15576 Swedish telecoms group LM Ericsson AB said on Friday it won an order worth 1.2 billion crowns for a fixed public telecoms network in the Guangdong province of China 
15577 Ericsson said in a statement the order was from the Guangdong Post and Telecommunications Administration GPTA 
15578 The order included AXE switching equipment ISDN equipment Intelligent Network IN products broad-band multi-media communication network products services and training Ericsson spokesman Per Zetterquist told Reuters 
15579 Deliveries are due to be completed by 1999 the company said 
15580 Stockholm newsroom +46-8-700 1017 
15581 HK has infrastructure in place for post-97 Tsang 
15582 AUCKLAND 1996-08-30 
15583 Hong Kong Financial Secretary Donald Tsang said on Friday that the territory had the infrastructural hardware to make a success of its future under Chinese sovereignty from mid-1997 
15584 We have the largest and most efficient port on the South China coast ; we have the best transport and telecommunications infrastructure in the world ; and we are investing in this hardware on an enormous scale Tsang said in a speech to Auckland during a visit to New Zealand 
15585 Hong Kong also had the necessary constitutional infrastructure in place with the promise of autonomy in running its affairs after the handover from Britain to China 
15586 What this means in practice is that Hong Kong will go on raising its own taxes issuing its own currency setting its own expenditure priorities and managing its own enormous financial reserves Tsang said 
15587 He acknowledged that many Hong Kong people had decided to seek their future elsewhere and others were sure to follow in the next nine months 
15588 But for the great majority of us Hong Kong is our home and Hong Kong 's future is our future

15626 Bootleg brew kills 35 in China police nab suspects 
15627 BEIJING 1996-08-30 
15628 Police in southwest China have arrested 30 people suspected of making and selling homemade alcohol that killed 35 people and poisoned 157 the Xinhua news agency said on Friday 
15629 A group of farmers in Huize county in the southwestern province of Yunnan were arrested for blending alcohol with methanol and selling the toxic liquor to local residents the agency said 
15630 Between late June and July a total of 192 people were poisoned by the toxic liquor and 35 of them died and six were left severely handicapped it said 
15631 Local authorities launched an investigation after they received reports of several similar deaths in the area it said 
15632 Post-mortem examinations showed they were all caused by methanol poisoning 
15633 Police had confiscated the remainder of the poisonous liquor Xinhua said 
15634 It gave no further details 
15635 Singapore hangs Thai drug trafficker 
15636 SINGAPORE 1996-08-30 
15637 Singapore hanged a Thai farmer at Changi Prison on Friday for drug trafficking the Central Narcotics Bureau CNB said 
15638 Jeerasak Densakul 24 was arrested in 1995 when he was found with 11 slabs of cannabis weighing 2.2 kg 4.8 pounds the CNB said 
15639 Singapore has a mandatory death sentence for anyone over 18 years of age found guilty of trafficking in more than 15 grams half an ounce of heroin 30 grams an ounce of morphine or 500 grams 18 oz of cannabis or marijuana 
15640 Of the nearly 270 people hanged for various crimes in Singapore since 1975 almost half have been for drug-related charges 
15641 Arafat goes to Nablus ahead of cabinet meeting 
15642 NABLUS West Bank 1996-08-30 
15643 Palestinian President Yasser Arafat arrived in the West Bank self-rule enclave of Nablus from Ramallah on Friday witnesses said 
15644 His aides said Arafat would hold the weekly meeting of the Palestinian self-rule Authority 's cabinet in Nablus on Saturday 
15645 In Jerusalem Israeli security forces were bracing for thousands of Palestinians expected to answer Arafat 's call earlier this week to come to the city holy to Moslems Arabs and Jews to pray in protest against Israel 's settlement policy in the West Bank and delay in peace negotiations 
15646 Palestinians want Arab East Jerusalem as the capital of a future independent state 
15647 Israel which captured and annexed East Jerusalem in 1967 says it will never cede any part of the city 
15648 Arafat who made an interim peace deal with Israel in 1993 that set up self-rule says he will only visit Jerusalem once Israeli occupation has ended 
15649 U.N. Council concerned about Israeli bulldozers 
15650 UNITED NATIONS 1996-08-29 
15651 Security Council members expressed concern on Thursday that Israel 's bulldozing of a Palestinian day-care centre for the disabled might further injure the Middle East peace process 
15652 Responding to a letter from the the Palestinian U.N. observer mission Security Council President Tono Eitel of Germany said that members asked him to convey their views to Israel 's charge d'affaires David Peleg 
15653 The members expressed their concern about the maintenance of the peace process and they urged that no action be taken that would have a negative impact on the negotiations Eitel said after an informal council session 
15654 They asked me to call in the Israeli charge d'affaires and discuss the matter with him he added 
15655 The Palestinian letter from Marwan Jilani said the destruction of the Jerusalem centre was an effort by Israel to alter the character demographic composition and status of the Holy City of Jerusalem and violated agreements between Israel and the Palestinian Liberation Organisation 
15656 This most recent measure represents a revival of old malicious plans to confiscate the land and build units for Israeli settlers within the walls of the Old City 
15657 We expect the international community to take a clear and firm position based on international law and in accordance with U.N. resolutions against all such Israeli violations and illegal practices he said 
15658 On Tuesday Israeli crews hoisted a bulldozer over the walls of Jerusalem 's old city and demolished the centre saying it was being restored without a building permit 
15659 Canada had recently donated $ 30 million to the centre called the Burj al-Laqlaq Society 
15660 SOCCER REAL SCRAPE 1-1 DRAW IN SCRAPPY OPENING MATCH 
15661 LA CORUNA Spain 1996-08-31 
15662 A late goal by newly-signed defender Roberto Carlos saved the blushes of Real Madrid coach Fabio Capello and his multi-billion peseta line-up in the opening game of the Spanish championship on Saturday 
15663 The Brazilian 's 79th-minute effort was enough to earn Real a point from a scrappy 1-1 draw at fellow title contenders Deportivo Coruna 
15664 Deportivo started strongly taking the lead midway through the first half when former Auxerre playmaker Corentine Martins headed home a corner after a flick-on by Brazilian-born Spanish international midfielder Donato 
15665 Real looked to be in deep trouble shortly after the break when Luis Milla was sent off for committing two bookable offences in as many minutes 
15666 But Deportivo were unable to capitalise on their numerical advantage and were themselves reduced to ten men when Armando Alvarez was sent off 15 minutes from time 
15667 Shortly afterwards Roberto Carlos found space in the home defence and equalised for Real with a shot that was deflected past despairing Deportivo keeper Jacques Songo'o 
15668 In a frantic final five minutes there were chances at both ends and Donato who had earlier been booked was sent off for protesting about the incursion of Real players at a free kick 
15669 Before the match Deportivo chairman Augusto Lendoiro said he would ignore a FIFA decision banning Brazilian midfielder Mauro Silva from playing in the match for failing to join his national side 's tour of Europe 
15670 In the event coach John Toshack decided not to use Silva who had claimed he did not join the Brazil squad because he had lost his passport

15680 SOCCER IRISH ERASE PAINFUL MEMORIES WITH 5-0 WIN 
15681 ESCHEN Liechtenstein 1996-08-31 
15682 The Republic of Ireland 's new-look side dispelled painful memories of their last visit to Liechtenstein by beating the Alpine part-timers 5-0 in a World Cup qualifier on Saturday 
15683 The Irish under new manager Mick McCarthy took a 4-0 lead within 20 minutes through captain Andy Townsend 20-year-old Norwich striker Keith O'Neill Sunderland forward Niall Quinn and teenager Ian Harte 
15684 Quinn added his second and Ireland 's fifth just after the hour to complete the rout and give the Irish their biggest-ever away win 
15685 The result helped erase memories of Ireland 's visit to the Eschen stadium 14 months ago when Jack Charlton 's side were held to a frustrating 0-0 draw which ultimately cost them a place in the European championship finals

15830 CRICKET PAKISTAN WIN TOSS PUT ENGLAND IN TO BAT 
15831 BIRMINGHAM England 1996-08-31 
15832 Pakistan won the toss and put England in to bat in the second limited overs cricket international at Edgbaston on Saturday 
15833 Surrey all-rounder Adam Hollioake was making his England debut replacing Lancashire batsman Graham Lloyd with seamer Peter Martin again being omitted from the 13 
15834 Pakistan kept the side who lost to England by five wickets at Old Trafford on Thursday in the first of the three one-day matches

15838 BASEBALL GONZALEZ HOMERS TWICE AS RANGERS BEAT INDIANS 
15839 ARLINGTON Texas 1996-08-31 
15840 Juan Gonzalez homered twice and Ivan Rodriguez added a two-run shot as the Texas Rangers defeated the Cleveland Indians 5-3 in a matchup of division leaders Friday 
15841 Rodriguez 's 18th homer off Chad Ogea 7-5 in the first gave Texas a 2-0 lead 
15842 One out later Gonzalez smacked his 40th homer extending his hitting streak to 20 games 
15843 Gonzalez who hit in 21 straight games earlier this season joined Mickey Rivers as the only players in Texas history with two 20-game streaks in the same year 
15844 Gonzalez hit his second homer in the third for his fifth multi-homer game of the season 
15845 Gonzalez has three 40-homer seasons and his 121 RBI broke Ruben Sierra 's team record of 119 set in 1989 
15846 The Indians had their four-game winning streak stopped 
15847 It 's not something I 'm going to try to explain said Texas manager Johnny Oates about his team winning seven of the 10 meetings from Cleveland this season 
15848 We 've got two more regular season games against them and we might get lucky enough or unlucky enough to play them in the post-season 
15849 Roger Pavlik 15-7 gave up three runs and seven hits in 6 1/3 innings and became the fourth 15-game winner in the American League 
15850 Jeff Russell pitched two perfect innings for his third save 
15851 Brian Giles and Jim Thome homered for Cleveland 
15852 Cleveland 's lead over the White Sox in the American League Central dropped to nine games 
15853 Texas 's lead over Seattle in the West increased to six 
15854 At California Tino Martinez 's two-run homer keyed a three-run first and Andy Pettitte became the league 's first 19-game winner as the New York Yankees beat the Angels 6-2 
15855 New York snapped a season-high five-game losing streak and also got homers from Mariano Duncan Darryl Strawberry and Jim Leyritz 
15856 Pettite 19-7 allowed two runs and eight hits over eight innings with a walk and seven strikeouts 
15857 He improved to 12-2 following Yankees losses 
15858 Mariano Rivera pitched a scoreless ninth striking out two 
15859 Ex-Yankee Randy Velarde hit his 11th homer his most at any professional level 
15860 In Seattle Pete Incaviglia 's grand slam with one out in the sixth snapped a tie and lifted the Baltimore Orioles past the Seattle Mariners 5-2 
15861 It was Incaviglia 's sixth grand slam and 200th homer of his career 
15862 Baltimore 's Eddie Murray cracked his 20th homer of the season and 499th of his career 
15863 Jay Buhner hit his 38th homer and Edgar Martinez his 23rd for Seattle 
15864 The Orioles remained tied with the White Sox for the American League wild card with the Mariners a game back 
15865 In Toronto Kevin Tapani 12-8 allowed two runs and six hits over 7 1/3 innings and Frank Thomas hit his 29th homer and drove in three runs as the Chicago White Sox cruised to an 11-2 victory over the Blue Jays 
15866 Thomas Harold Baines and Robin Ventura each collected three hits 
15867 Baines homered and scored three runs 
15868 Danny Tartabull added two hits and three RBI as all Chicago starters got at least one hit 
15869 In Oakland Dave Telgheder scattered seven hits over eight innings and Mark McGwire hit his major-league leading 45th homer and drove in three runs as the Athetlics blanked the Boston Red Sox 7-0 
15870 Telgheder 2-5 snapped a personal three-game losing streak 
15871 Buddy Groom pitched a perfect ninth inning 
15872 McGwire singled home a run to spark a three-run sixth and capped the scoring with a two-run homer in the seventh 
15873 The loss was Boston 's seventh in its last 29 games 
15874 In Detroit Todd Van Poppel pitched a five-hitter for his first career shutout and Tony Clark homered to cap a four-run first inning as the Tigers blanked the Kansas City Royals 4-0 
15875 Van Poppel 3-6 walked two and struck out two in defeating the Royals for the second time this week 
15876 He threw 108 pitches as he lowered his ERA from 8.08 to 7.24 
15877 Kansas City has scored only one run in two games 
15878 In Milwaukee Marc Newfield homered off Jose Parra 5-4 leading off the bottom of the 12th as the Brewers rallied for a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins 
15879 Milwaukee has won 10 of its last 15 
15880 Bob Wickman 6-1 pitched 2 2/3 hitless innings for the win his second for the Brewers 
15881 Matt Lawton hit a three-run homer off closer Mike Fetters with one out in the ninth to give Minnesota a 4-2 lead 
15882 But Milwaukee tied it up in the bottom of the ninth on pinch-hitter Dave Nilsson 's two-run double 
15883 CRICKET ESSEX AND KENT MADE TO SWEAT IN TITLE RACE 
15884 LONDON 1996-08-31 
15885 Essex and Kent both face tense finishes on Monday as they attempt to keep pace with title hopefuls Derbyshire and Surrey convincing three-day victors on Saturday in the English county championship run-in 
15886 Essex need another 148 with five wickets in hand to beat Yorkshire after a maiden first-class century from Richard Kettleborough transformed a match which his side had seemed certain to lose 
15887 Kent will also need to keep their nerve against struggling Nottinghamshire who will enter the final day 137 ahead with four wickets left in a relatively low-scoring match at Tunbridge Wells 
15888 Derbyshire nine-wicket winners over Worcestershire and Surrey who thrashed Warwickshire by an innings and 164 runs can instead take the day off along with rivals Leicestershire who beat Somerset inside two days 
15889 Warwickshire captain Tim Munton is tipping Surrey to emerge on top impressed by the positive influence of Australian coach Dave Gilbert but Derbyshire 's Australian captain Dean Jones is conceding nothing as his side chase their first title for 60 years 
15890 We took three absolutely brilliant catches in this match and our catching all season has been pretty impressive 
15891 Our catching will win or lose us the championship he said

15949 RUGBY UNION LYNAGH SEALS VICTORY OVER DWYER AND LEICESTER 
15950 LONDON 1996-08-31 
15951 Former Wallaby captain Michael Lynagh began his career in English club rugby in impeccable fashion on Saturday to frustrate his old coach Bob Dwyer on his league coaching debut with Leicester 
15952 Lynagh kicked five penalties and a conversion from his six attempts at goal to steer his multi-national Saracens side to a 25-23 home win and offer millionaire backer Nigel Wray an early return on his big investment in the north London club 
15953 French centre Philippe Sella also enjoyed a good game alongside Lynagh although the home team scored only one try through England scrum-half Kyran Bracken 
15954 The new French connection at Harlequins also made a good start Laurent Cabannes and Laurent Benezech scoring a try apiece in their side 's 75-19 victory over Gloucester 
15955 Former England captain Will Carling handed the kicking duties finished with 20 points 
15956 With the first day of the league season briefly shifting the spotlight away from the discord between the clubs and the Rugby Football Union there were also emphatic victories for champions Bath 56-13 winners over Orrell and Northampton and narrow successes for Wasps and Bristol

16172 SOCCER CANADA BEAT PANAMA 3-1 IN WORLD CUP QUALIFIER 
16173 EDMONTON 1996-08-31 
16174 Canada beat Panama 3-1 halftime 2-0 in their CONCACAF semifinal phase qualifying match for the 1998 World Cup on Friday

16179 RUGBY UNION SPRINGBOKS FINALLY BREAK ALL BLACK SPELL 
16180 Andy Colquhoun 
16181 JOHANNESBURG 1996-08-31 
16182 South Africa managed to avoid a fifth successive defeat in 1996 at the hands of the All Blacks with an emphatic 32-22 victory in front of an ecstatic Ellis Park crowd on Saturday 
16183 They scored three tries in recording their highest total against New Zealand salvaging some pride in a season in which the world champions have lost five out of eight tests 
16184 It also ended a run of nine successive victories this year for New Zealand but arrived too late to prevent a 2-1 series defeat and an historic first All Black series triumph on South African soil 
16185 Springbok scrum-half Joost van der Westhuizen was his side 's inspiration scoring their opening try and making the third for flanker Andre Venter from a quickly taken penalty to give his side a 29-8 lead after 54 minutes 
16186 Fullback Andre Joubert scored the other scorching in from 40 metres at the start of the second half to add to his three long-range penalties 
16187 The All Blacks salvaged some pride by scoring two tries from centre Walter Little and scrum-half Justin Marshall in the final five minutes to close a gap which at one point stood at 24 points 
16188 But they generally endured an off-day highlighted by recalled fly-half Andrew Mehrtens who missed five out of eight kicks at goal 
16189 Recalled fly-half Henry Honiball kicked the Springboks into a 6-0 lead after 10 minutes only to see Andrew Mehrtens launch a penalty from eight metres inside his own half to narrow the gap 
16190 Mehrtens missed three further penalties and a conversion in the first 40 minutes which could have put his side ahead but it was the Springboks who looked the more dangerous 
16191 Their promise was realised when Joubert made a 40-metre break in the 25th minute and although winger Pieter Hendriks appeared to knock on Joubert 's reverse pass Welsh referee Derek Bevan allowed Van der Westhuizen to pick up and score under the posts 
16192 Honiball converted and Joubert kicked a penalty before All Black hooker Sean Fitzpatrick scored a try from close range on the stroke of half-time to narrow the lead to 16-8 and hint at a comeback 
16193 Instead Joubert kicked another long penalty and then raced around the outside of the defence to score the Springboks second try 
16194 A quick penalty from Van der Westhuizen five metres from the All Black line set up the third try for Venter five minutes later and when Joubert kicked his third penalty the Springboks held an unassailable 32-8 lead going into the last quarter 
16195 When the All Blacks did break through it was too late 
16196 Centre Walter Little followed up Mehrtens kick to score under the posts and scrum-half Justin Marshall forced himself over from a ruck close to the line in injury-time to give them some consolation 
16197 South Africa 15 Andre Joubert 14 Justin Swart 13 Japie Mulder Joel Stransky 48 mins 12 Danie van Schalkwyk 11 Pieter Hendriks ; 10 Henry Honiball 9 Joost van der Westhuizen ; 8 Gary Teichmann captain 7 Andre Venter Wayne Fyvie 75 6 Ruben Kruge 5 Mark Andrews Fritz van Heerden 39 4 Kobus Wiese 3 Marius Hurter 2 James Dalton 1 Dawie Theron Garry Pagel 66 
16198 New Zealand 15 Christian Cullen Alama Ieremia 70 14 Jeff Wilson 13 Walter Little 12 Frank Bunce 11 Glen Osborne ; 10 Andrew Mehrtens 9 Justin Marshall ; 8 Zinzan Brooke 7 Josh Kronfeld 6 Michael Jones Glenn Taylor 53 5 Robin Brooke 4 Ian Jones 3 Olo Brown 2 Sean Fitzpatrick captain 1 Craig Dowd

16210 SOCCER MAURITANIA DISSOLVES NATIONAL TEAM AFTER CUP EXIT 
16211 NOUAKCHOTT 1996-08-31 
16212 Mauritania 's soccer federation dissolved the national team and suspended this season 's domestic championship on Saturday in the wake of the country 's failure to qualify for the African Nations Cup 
16213 Since Mauritania has been eliminated on all fronts and the next commitments are not for another two years we have reason to take a break federation president Mohamed Lemine Cheiguer said 
16214 The North Africans were held to a goalless draw by Benin on Friday after losing the first leg of their qualifying tie 4-1

16264 SOCCER INCE EXPOSED BY GASCOIGNE 'S LATEST PRANK 
16265 CHISINAU Moldova 1996-08-31 
16266 England 's irrepressible midfielder Paul Gascoigne was up to his old tricks on Saturday pulling down his team mate Paul Ince 's trousers in front of an astonished crowd in Moldova 
16267 Ince was clambering over a wall at the Republican stadium in Chisinau as Glenn Hoddle 's England players tried to escape heavy rain during an under-21 clash 
16268 Gascoigne whose compulsive practical joking has landed him in trouble in the past tugged down the Inter Milan player 's trousers in front of a group of press photographers 
16269 Hoddle coaching the side for the first time declined to comment on the incident 
16270 England face Moldova in a World Cup qualifier in the same stadium on Sunday

16321 SQUASH HILL BRANDS WORLD CHAMPION JANSHER A CHEAT 
16322 HONG KONG 1996-08-31 
16323 Controversial Australian Anthony Hill called Jansher Khan a cheat during his acrimonious defeat by the world number one in the Hong Kong Open semifinals on Saturday 
16324 The match boiled over when Hill made to walk off court after what he claimed was a game-winning point in the third 
16325 When the referee called Jansher 's return good and the decision was accepted by the player Hill shrieked at the Pakistani You cheat 
16326 He was standing right there and knew the shot was down so I called him a cheat said Hill whose squash career has been blighted by fines and suspensions for unacceptable behaviour 
16327 He knew it was down and accepted what I called him because of that 
16328 Hill won the game on the next point and said later that Jansher was generally honest on court but played by the referee 's decision 
16329 The Australian had upset Jansher 's rhythm with his mixture of gamesmanship and fluent stroke-making but eventually succumbed 15-7 17-15 14-15 15-8 
16330 I changed my strategy against him today and had him rattled he added 
16331 He is not as fit as he used to be be but was too good for me in the end 
16332 I shook him a bit but he will come out next time and be a better player for it that 's Jansher 
16333 Jansher said that he was disturbed to be called a cheat 
16334 What he did was bad for squash bad for the crowd and bad for the sponsors 
16335 We are trying to build up squash like tennis and players should not say things like that 
16336 I think the Professional Squash Association should look into this matter and deal with it properly 
16337 I am not calling for him to be banned but they have to take some action 
16338 Jansher bidding for an eighth Hong Kong Open title plays second-seeded Australian Rodney Eyles in the final 
16339 Eyles played his best squash of the tournament to beat fourth-seeded Peter Nicol of Scotland 15-10 8-15 15-10 15-4 
16340 Eyles who defeated Jansher in the semifinals of the Portuguese Open in 1993 said that he would like to win for the good of the game 
16341 I have nothing against Jansher but it will be great if I could beat him said Eyles 
16342 My biggest problem against Jansher is concentration 
16343 I want to beat him so badly that I just cannot get it together
