16345 HONG KONG 1996-08-31 
16346 Semifinal results in the Hong Kong Open on Saturday prefix number denotes seeding 1 Jansher Khan Pakistan beat Anthony Hill Australia 15-7 17-15 14-15 15-8 2 Rodney Eyles Australia beat 4 Peter Nicol Scotland 15-10 8-15 15-10 15-4 
16347 GOLF PARNEVIK TAKES ONE-SHOT LEAD AT GREATER MILWAUKEE OPEN 
16348 MILWAUKEE Wisconsin 1996-08-31 
16349 Jesper Parnevik of Sweden fired a course record-tying eight-under-par 63 Saturday to take a one-shot lead into the final round of the $ 1.2 million Greater Milwaukee Open 
16350 Parnevik who is seeking his first PGA Tour victory moved to 19-under 194 for the tournament 
16351 Parnevik tied the 18-hole record set by Loren Roberts in 1994 at the Brown Deer Park Golf Course and also equalled Saturday by Greg Kraft 
16352 Nolan Henke who led by two strokes entering the third round carded a four-under 67 and was one stroke back at 18-under 195 
16353 He is striving for his fourth career PGA Tour victory and first since the 1993 BellSouth Classic 
16354 Tiger Woods who made the cut in his first tournament as a professional shot a two-over-par 73 and was four under for the tournament 
16355 The 20-year-old Woods who turned professional Tuesday after winning an unprecedented third successive U.S. Amateur Championship struggled on the front nine bogeying the first and seventh holes and double-bogeying the par-four 359-yard ninth hole 
16356 After bogeying the 10th hole to move to four-over for the round he rallied for birdies on 15 and 18 
16357 After Parnevik started off his round by parring the first hole and bogeying the second the Swede birdied six of the next seven holes 
16358 Parnevik continued to storm through the course birdying three holes on the back nine including two from 12 feet out on the 15th and 17th holes 
16359 I ca n't remember when I 've putted this well said Parnevik 
16360 I was disappointed when a 12-footer did n't go in 
16361 My game feels very good 
16362 I 've been fading my driver but today whenever I set up for a fade it went straight 
16363 Whenever everyone 's making birdies you never want to be even par 
16364 Henke had a bogey-free round and birdied four holes including a 45-footer on the par-three 215-yard seventh hole and one from 12 feet out on the 12th hole 
16365 I did n't hit it very well today said Henke 
16366 Jasper blew right by me 
16367 Once he did I knew I had to make birdies just to keep up 
16368 I made some really good pars 
16369 I basically picked up where I left off yesterday afternoon 
16370 Right now I ca n't put my finger on what 's wrong 
16371 Bob Estes shot a 67 for sole possession of third place at 15-under 
16372 Steve Stricker who tied for second at last week 's World Series of Golf and Stuart Appleby were both five shots off the lead at 14 under 
16373 Duffy Waldorf who also tied for second at the World Series of Golf carded a 70 to lead a group of six golfers at 13 under including Kraft 
16374 The top four on the PGA Tour money list all skipped the tournament 
16375 TENNIS SPAIN U.S. TEAMS OPEN ON ROAD FOR 1997 FED CUP 
16376 Richard Finn 
16377 NEW YORK 1996-08-31 
16378 This year 's Fed Cup finalists defending champion Spain and the United States will hit the road to open the 1997 women 's international team competition based on the draw conducted Saturday at the U.S. Open 
16379 Spain travels to Belgium while the U.S. team heads to the Netherlands for first-round matches March 1-2 
16380 The other two first-round ties will pit hosts Germany against the Czech Republic and visiting France against Japan 
16381 The semifinals are July 19-20 and the final September 27- 28 
16382 Life on the road this year did not slow the Americans who will try to avenge their 3-2 defeat in the final last year when they host Spain on September 28-29 in Atlantic City 
16383 Last year we stood on the court after we had lost and we put out hands together and made it our committment to bring back the Cup U.S. captain Billie Jean King said at the draw 
16384 That is our sole goal 
16385 The United States edged Austria in Salzburg 3-2 in the opening round in April and then blanked Japan 5-0 in Nagoya last month in the semifinals 
16386 The victory against Japan marked the Fed Cup debut of Monica Seles who became a naturalised U.S. citizen in 1994 
16387 Seles easily won both her singles matches and King is counting on the co-world number one to lead the team again 
16388 I told Monica we need her if we want to win King said 
16389 Seles 's sore left shoulder and a wrist injury to Fed Cup veteran Mary Joe Fernandez have forced King to take a wait and see attitude regarding her squad for the best-of-five match 
16390 Fernandez was forced to withdraw from the U.S. Open 
16391 We will wait until the last minute so we check with everybody and their injuries said King 
16392 What we like would be Seles Olympic champion Lindsay Davenport and Mary Joe Fernandez 
16393 If she can get that threesome together King will feel good about her chances against the Spain 's formidable duo of Arantxa Sanchez Vicario and Conchita Martinez 
16394 To be a great coach you have to have the right horses and I got the right horses said King

16501 BASEBALL KEVIN BROWN LOWERS ERA AS MARLINS BEAT REDS 
16502 CINCINNATI 1996-08-31 
16503 Major league ERA leader Kevin Brown threw an eight-hitter and Devon White 's RBI double snapped a fifth-inning tie as the Florida Marlins beat the Cincinnati Reds 3-1 for their seventh straight win Friday 
16504 Brown 14-10 tied Todd Stottlemyre of the Cardinals for the National League lead with his fifth complete game and lowered his major league-leading earned run average from 1.96 to 1.92 
16505 He struck out eight and did not walk a batter 
16506 Brown threw 119 pitches and won for the third time in as many starts against the Reds this season 
16507 Bolesy Florida manager John Boles told me yesterday You have to go nine tomorrow Brown said 
16508 In the early innings I was struggling I was just trying to make it from pitch to pitch 
16509 I gave up a lot of hits in the early innings and I was n't thinking about the seventh eighth or ninth 
16510 I was n't satisfied with any of my pitches and I did a better job of moving the ball around in the later innings 
16511 He has a devastating sinker observed Reds manager Ray Knight 
16512 The guys say it moved more than everyone in the league 
16513 I remember Nolan Ryan saying in 91 or 92 that he was the best young pitcher coming around in a long time and he saw Tom Seaver and Jerry Koosman when they were starting 
16514 In Philadelphia Delino DeShields 's triple in the top of the 12th off Jeff Parrett 2-3 scored Chad Curtis and lifted the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-6 victory over the Phillies 
16515 Los Angeles won for the seventh time in eight games 
16516 Darren Dreifort 1-1 picked up the win after allowing a hit and a walk over 2 1/3 scoreless innings 
16517 Todd Worrell worked the 12th to earn his league-leading 37th save 
16518 The Phillies have dropped five of their last six overall and nine of 11 at home 
16519 Billy Ashley belted a three-run homer for Los Angeles 
16520 In Chicago the Braves and Cubs split a doubleheader 
16521 In the first game Ryne Sandberg snapped an eighth-inning tie with an infield single and Kevin Foster 6-2 outdueled Atlanta 's Tom Glavine 13-8 for his third straight win 3-2 
16522 Foster a .333 hitter helped his own cause in the second with a two-run single 
16523 The Braves took the second game when Chipper Jones singled home the tying run in the top of the ninth and Andruw Jones took advantage of a poor throw to score the go-ahead run on a sacrifice fly for a 6-5 victory 
16524 Cubs shortstop Jose Hernandez committed three of Chicago 's four errors 
16525 Mike Mordecai singled doubled and homered for Atlanta which has won 14 of its last 19 games and has the best record in the majors 84-50 
16526 In Montreal Scott Sanders allowed one hit over eight innings and Wally Joyner hit a two-run single in a four-run third as the San Diego Padres blanked the Expos 6-0 for their sixth straight win 
16527 Sanders 8-4 struck out 10 and walked three to win his fourth straight 
16528 He allowed a leadoff double to David Segui in the second and won for the seventh time in eight decisions 
16529 The right-hander retired 14 batters in a row from the second inning through the seventh 
16530 Mike Oquist allowed one Montreal hit in the ninth 
16531 Montreal lost for the ninth time in 14 games 
16532 In New York Marvin Benard 's two-run homer snapped a tie and Shawn Estes came one out away from his first complete game as the San Francisco Giants beat the Mets 6-4 
16533 Benard hitting .467 14-for-30 against the Mets this season hit his first pitch from Pete Harnisch 8-10 in the seventh over the right-field fence to put the Giants up 4-2 
16534 Estes 3-4 was lifted for closer Rod Beck after yielding a single with two out in the ninth 
16535 Beck allowed a two-run double to Alvaro Espinoza who collected a career-high four RBI but struck out Brent Mayne for his 31st save 
16536 The loss was the Mets eighth straight their longest slide since September 1993 and dropped them to 0-4 under new manager Bobby Valentine 
16537 In St Louis Tom Pagnozzi had three hits and three RBI and Alan Benes scattered six hits over six-plus innings as the Cardinals beat the Colorado Rockies 7-4 
16538 Benes 12-8 allowed three runs walked three and struck out three for the win 
16539 St Louis defeated Colorado for just the second time in 12 meetings dating back to last season 
16540 Ray Lankford went 4-for-5 with a pair of doubles for the Cardinals who won for just the third time in 11 games 
16541 Eric Anthony hit a pair of solo homers for the Rockies 
16542 In Pittsburgh Sean Berry tied a career high with six RBI and Donne Wall fired a seven-hitter for his first major-league shutout as the Houston Astros routed the Pirates 10-0 
16543 It was the third time Berry had six RBI in one game 
16544 Wall 9-4 struck out four and walked none to post his second complete game of the season and third straight win 
16545 TENNIS EDBERG REFUSES TO QO QUIETLY 
16546 Richard Finn 
16547 NEW YORK 1996-08-30 
16548 Refusing to go quietly in the night Stefan Edberg extended his stay at his 14th and last U.S. Open when Bernd Karbacher trailing and hurting quit in the fourth set of their second-round match Friday 
16549 The 30-year-old Edberg a former two-time Open champion had wrestled control of the match away from Karbacher when the German hampered by a left hamstring injury decided he could n't continue under the stadium lights at the National Tennis Centre 
16550 A win is a win 
16551 I 'll take it Edberg who has announced that this will be his last Grand Slam event said of the 3-6 6-3 6-3 1-0 victory 
16552 Ironically Karbacher two years ago ended Ivan Lendl 's Grand Slam career here when the former champion had to retire in the middle of their first-round match 
16553 After seeing the trainer come out early in the third set Edberg was not surprised by Karbacher 's decision not to go on 
16554 I knew he had problems with something Edberg said 
16555 I really was n't surprised 
16556 Edberg had his own problems early in the match as the Swede battled to acclimate himself to the nighttime conditions while Karbacher was ripping passing shots and blasting serves past him 
16557 I did n't really feel good to begin with I had problems finding the timing on the ball seeing the ball said Edberg who upset Wimbledon champion and fifth-seeded Richard Krajicek in the first round 
16558 This was one of these matches where I did n't play up to my standard 
16559 I had to fight hard 
16560 Edberg 's tenacity paid off in the second set 
16561 Edberg lost his own serve twice but he rallied for three breaks of his own the last to wrap up the set 
16562 That 's where the match sort of changed said Edberg 
16563 I think once I got that second set I felt a lot better about my game 
16564 Edberg is starting to feel pretty good about postponing his swan song a lot longer 
16565 It does n't look all that bad Edberg said of his path through the draw starting next with a match against Krajicek 's Dutch countryman Paul Haarhuis 
16566 However the 1991 and 1992 champion is not ready to start making plans to be in next week 's final 
16567 I 'm always being realistic said Edberg 
16568 Like I said many times I think it 's a very little chance but nothing is impossible 
16569 If I play great tennis that could take me a long way 
16570 A lot of things can happen like tonight

16574 SOCCER AUSTRIA DOMINATE SCOTLAND IN WORLD CUP QUALIFIER 
16575 Steve Pagani 
16576 VIENNA 1996-08-31 
16577 Austria dominated their World Cup group four qualifier against Scotland on Saturday with wave after wave of attacks but were unable to penetrate the visitors defence and had to settle for a goalless draw 
16578 Scotland who thrashed Belarus 5-1 in their opening group four match were unable to repeat their performance 
16579 Austria 's best chance came in the 63rd minute with Stephan Marasek of SC Freiburg taking advantage of a scramble in the Scottish penalty area but his shot narrowly passing the left-hand post 
16580 They also went close a minute before the interval when a promising attack saw the ball fall to Markus Schopp but he hit his shot wide 
16581 Everton 's Duncan Ferguson went close for Scotland in the 65th minute when he forced Austrian goalkeeper Michael Konsel to a diving save 
16582 Two Scotland players were shown yellow cards captain Gary McAllister for bringing down Andreas Heraf and Ferguson for arguing against the referee 's decision 
16583 The result is acceptable Scottish coach Craig Brown told reporters 
16584 We 'd hoped not to lose and we tried not to play for a draw but the Austrian defence was simply too good 
16585 SK Rapid 's Dietmar Kuehbauer who gave an impressive performance said the team started off well but let the game slip after the first 30 minutes 
16586 Somehow it seemed there were less than 11 players on the pitch 
16587 We have lost two points 
16588 The Scots are not really a great team and we should have won he said 
16589 Austrian coach Herbert Prohaska said his team had displayed great fighting spirit but sometimes lacked ideas

16596 SOCCER FRANCE LAUNCH 1998 WORLD CUP BUILD-UP WITH 2-0 WIN 
16597 PARIS 1996-08-31 
16598 Euro 96 absentee Nicolas Ouedec and Youri Djorkaeff scored the goals as 1998 World Cup hosts France beat Mexico 2-0 in a friendly international on Saturday 
16599 The victory extended to 29 matches France 's unbeaten run under coach Aime Jacquet their Euro 96 semifinal elimination having come in a penalty shoot-out but was marred by the sending-off of Chelsea central defender Franck Leboeuf 
16600 Leboeuf was dismissed two minutes from time for a second bookable offence fouling Mexican substitute Ricardo Pelaez who minutes earlier had also been shown the yellow card for pushing the Chelsea defender in the back 
16601 Both goals came early in the second half after France had surprised the Mexicans with three half-time substitutions 
16602 After a sterile first half France injected more sting in midfield with the introduction of Juventus 's Zinedine Zidane 
16603 This allowed Djorkaeff to play further up and his cross from the right fell for Ouedec who has joined Espanyol of Barcelona from Nantes since missing the European championship finals through injury to score after a mistake by midfielder Joaquin del Olmo 
16604 Within four minutes Ouedec was returning the compliment for Djorkaeff playing a one-two with the Internazionale Milan forward down the middle to set him up for a cross shot past diving goalkeeper Osvaldo Sanchez 
16605 Jacquet beginning the 22-month countdown to France 's hosting of the World Cup finals said We have an identity as a team which we are going to work on

16614 SOCCER BELGIUM SCRAPE PAST TURKEY DESPITE CROWD TROUBLE 
16615 Bert Lauwers 
16616 BRUSSELS 1996-08-31 
16617 Belgium kicked off their 1998 World Cup campaign with a hard-fought 2-1 victory over 10-man Turkey in a tense match marred by Turkish crowd trouble shortly after the break 
16618 Turkish fans upset at their team 's 2-0 first-half deficit ripped apart dozens of plastic seats and threw them over the fence 
16619 Riot police took 10 minutes to restore order 
16620 The police were given an unexpected hand by second-half substitute Sergen Yalcin who rekindled Turkish hopes in the 61st with a splendid half-volley which stunned Belgian goalkeeper Filip De Wilde 
16621 But Yalcin who had come on just four minutes earlier turned from hero to villain barely two minutes after his strike when he was sent off after spitting at an opponent and arguing with English referee David Elleray 
16622 Marc Degryse had opened the scoring for Belgium after 13 minutes whacking a low 10-metre drive into the net after an incisive pass by defender Dirk Medved from the edge of the penalty area 
16623 Brazilian-born Luis Oliveira then gleefully slipped the ball past goalkeeper Rustu Recber from the right of the area to make it 2-0 seven minutes before the interval Turkey 's best first-half effort proving to be a vicious 30-metre shot by Ogun Temizkanoglu which De Wilde tipped over 
16624 The visitors seeking to restore some pride after failing to score a single goal in Euro 96 in June repeatedly ripped through the left side of the home defence but De Wilde was able to block several sharply-angled efforts 
16625 With only the group seven winners qualifying automatically for the 1998 finals in France Belgium could not afford a slip-up at home and they frantically chased a decisive third goal 
16626 But they were almost upset 12 minutes from time when De Wilde fumbled a hard Arif Erdem shot and Orhan Cikirikci almost pounced on the loose ball 
16627 Belgium 's best second-half effort came three minutes later when Degryse put the ball over the bar from close range with Recber beaten 
16628 Teams 
16629 Belgium 1 Filip De Wilde 2 Bertrand Crasson 3 Dirk Medved 4 Pascal Renier 16 Geoffrey Claeys 6 Gunther Schepens 15 Nico Van Kerckhoven 81st 10 Enzo Scifo 7 Gert Verheyen 14 Frederic Peiremans 62nd 9 Marc Degryse 8 Luc Nilis 11- Luis Oliveira 18 Gilles De Bilde 88th

16631 Belgian coach Wilfried Van Moer said he had not expected Turkey to be so strong and fast 
16632 We started panicking a bit after the Turkish goal 
16633 we suffered said Van Moer who succeeded Paul Van Himst as coach in April 
16634 It was Belgium 's first victory under Van Moer after two draws in friendlies against Russia and Italy

16658 BOXING KNOCK-OUT SPECIALIST MILLER DEFENDS TITLE 
16659 DUBLIN 1996-08-31 
16660 A powerful right hook followed by a straight left gave defending champion Nate Miller a seventh round knock-out win over fellow American James Heath in their WBA cruiserweight title bout on Saturday 
16661 Miller who went into the contest with a record of 24 knock-out wins in 32 fights took charge from the opening bell and had his opponent on the canvas inside 90 seconds when he landed a deft left-hook to the head 
16662 Heath did score with two brusing lefts to Miller 's head in the third round but failed to put his opponent under any real pressure 
16663 Miller raised the pace of the contest at the start of the fifth round and once he started to get his right-left combinations working for him the fight was never likely to go the distance

16687 SOCCER KLINSMANN TO RETIRE AFTER 1998 WORLD CUP

16691 Klinsmann said he believed Germany could win in France with the same nucleus of players which won the European championship in England this summer 
16692 I think it can be done he said especially as experience is becoming more and more valuable in sport 
16693 I think we can do it with the same body of players 
16694 That 's what we 're all aiming for 
16695 Coach Berti Vogts has called up a virtually identical squad for next week 's friendly against Poland Germany 's first match since Euro 96

16710 Paper says Thatcher 's office consulted astrologer 
16711 LONDON 1996-09-01 
16712 A British newspaper said Margaret Thatcher was so shaken by an IRA attempt on her life when she was prime minister in 1984 that an astrologer was asked to warn her against future threats 
16713 The Sunday Telegraph quoted Majorie Orr as saying she did a horoscope chart for Thatcher a Libran after she narrowly escaped death in the Irish guerrilla bombing of a hotel during the Conservative Party conference more than a decade ago 
16714 Orr said Thatcher 's press secretary Bernard Ingram asked her to telephone if she saw any threatening indications in the future 
16715 Bernard Ingham told me that if I ever heard anything that indicated danger I was to let him know Orr said 
16716 Orr said she never had to telephone 
16717 She added that the horoscope was purely for security purposes and she was never consulted about political moves 
16718 Ingram was quoted as telling the newspaper he thought astrology was a load of rubbish and that he could not recall asking Orr to keep a watch on Thatcher 's stars 
16719 Thatcher dubbed the Iron Lady for her driven forceful personality was never known to have an interest in the occult and in fact has a university degree in chemistry 
16720 Former U.S. president Ronald Reagan 's wife Nancy admitted in her biography My Turn that she regularly consulted an astrologer to help her plan her husband 's schedule 
16721 Reuters historical calendar September 7 
16722 LONDON 1996-08-31 
16723 Following are some of the major events to have occurred on September 7 in history 
16724 1533 Queen Elizabeth I born 
16725 Daughter of Henry VIII and his second wife Anne Boleyn she was queen of England 1558-1603 
16726 One of the great monarchs who presided over a period of English assertion in Europe in politics and the arts 
16727 1706 French troops under Duke of Orleans besieging Turin were defeated by the Austrians under Prince Eugene the French army was destroyed and they ceased trying to capture northern Italy 
16728 1714 The Treaty of Baden was signed between the Holy Roman Emperor Charles VI and France ending War of Spanish Succession 
16729 Charles ceded Alsace and Strasbourg to France and got back Breisach Kehl and Freiburg 
16730 1812 Russian army under General Kutuzov was defeated at heavy cost by Napoleon at the battle of Borodino 70 miles west of Moscow 
16731 Napoleon entered Moscow a week later 
16732 1822 Brazil proclaimed independence from Portugal and Pedro I became first Emperor of Brazil in December 1822 
16733 1836 Scottish politician Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman born 
16734 As Liberal prime minister 1905-1908 he granted self-government to the Transvaal 
16735 He also got the House of Lords to pass his Trades Disputes Act which gave labour unions more freedom to strike 
16736 1860 Giuseppe Garibaldi leading his Red Shirts seized Naples in the Italian war of liberation against the Austrians 
16737 1901 In China the Boxer Rising which attempted to drive out all foreigners officially ended with the signing of the Peking Protocol 
16738 This imposed an indemnity to be paid to the great powers for Boxer crimes 
16739 1909 Elia Kazan born as Elia Kazanjoglus 
16740 A U.S. stage and screen director he is best known for Viva Zapata and On the Waterfront 
16741 1913 Sir Anthony Quayle born 
16742 British actor of stage and screen in films from 1948 
16743 Best known for appearances in Ice Cold in Alex Lawrence of Arabia and as Cardinal Wolsey in Anne of a Thousand Days 
16744 1914 James Alfred Van Allen born 
16745 U.S. physicist who discovered the two zones of radiation encircling the earth to which he gave his name 
16746 1930 Belgian King Baudouin I born 
16747 He succeeded to the throne in 1951 on the abdication of his father Leopold III 
16748 1940 In World War Two the German airforce under Hermann Goering began its Blitz bombing campaign on London 
16749 Over 300 people were killed on this day alone 
16750 1969 Scottish motor racing driver Jackie Stewart won the Italian Grand Prix to secure his first world championship 
16751 Four years later after winning his third world crown he announced his retirement 
16752 1986 Bishop Desmond Tutu was enthroned as Archbishop of Cape Town South Africa 
16753 He was the first black head of South Africa 's Anglicans 
16754 1990 The United States won Saudi and Kuwaiti pledges to help pay for forces in the Gulf 
16755 Iraq ordered many restaurants to close indefinitely to save food in face of a blockade 
16756 1990 British historian Alan John Percivale A.J.P. Taylor died 
16757 He won acclaim for the insights that he gave into the events which shaped modern Europe and was one of Europe 's leading authorities on the great conflicts of the 20th century 
16758 1993 Six former Soviet republics Russia Belarus Kazakhstan Uzbekistan Armenia and Tajikistan signed framework agreement to keep the Russian rouble as their common currency 
16759 1994 The Stars and Stripes flag was lowered for the last time over U.S. army headquarters in Berlin formally ending the American presence in the once-divided city after nearly half a century 
16760 Escaped British paedophile recaptured 
16761 LONDON 1996-08-31 
16762 A convicted British paedophile was arrested on Saturday two days after escaping from custody during a supervised day trip to a zoo police said 
16763 Trevor Holland a 52 year-old with who has been convicted twice of gross indecency with children was captured after being spotted in Worthing a town on England 's southern coast 
16764 A member of the public recognised Holland in a newsagent shop as he was reading the headlines about himself a police spokesman said 
16765 Police launched a nationwide search on Thursday after he disappeared during an unsupervised trip to the toilet while visiting a popular zoo and theme park south of London 
16766 Holland was moved to a more secure centre earlier this year after a similar incident 
16767 His escape at the zoo caused outrage in Britain 
16768 A child sex scandal in Belgium in which two eight-year-old girls were murdered and two other sexually abused girls were rescued has focused new attention on the problem 
16769 Scottish Labour Party narrowly backs referendum 
16770 STIRLING Scotland 1996-08-31 
16771 British Labour Party leader Tony Blair won a narrow victory on Saturday when the party 's Scottish executive voted 21-18 in favour of his plans for a referendum on a separate parliament for Scotland 
16772 Blair once pledged to set up a Scottish parliament if the Labour won the next general election which must be held by May 1997 
16773 But many activists were dismayed when he abruptly decided earlier this year to hold a two-question referendum on the issue asking Scots if they wanted a separate parliament and if it should have tax-raising powers 
16774 Many party members argued that a general election win would demonstrate popular support for a separate parliament and others said a single question referendum would suffice 
16775 Prime Minister John Major says the 300-year-old union of the Scottish and English parliaments will be a main plank in his Conservative Party 's election platform 
16776 Conservatives have only 10 of the 72 Scottish seats in parliament and consistently run third in opinion polls in Scotland behind Labour and the independence-seeking Scottish National Party 
16777 Britain condemns Iraq involvement in Arbil attack 
16778 LONDON 1996-08-31 
16779 Britain on Saturday condemned Iraqi involvement in an attack on the Kurdish city of Arbil and said it was in close touch with its allies 
16780 We condemn Iraqi involvement 
16781 In no way can Iraqi involvement be seen as helpful said a Foreign Office spokesman 
16782 U.N. officials said that a Kurdish rebel faction backed up by Iraqi tanks heavy artillery and helicopters had taken control of half of the city after heavy fighting 
16783 Arbil lies within the so-called safe haven set up at the end of the 1991 Gulf War on the suggestion of British Prime Minister John Major to protect Iraqi Kurds from attack by the Iraqi military 
16784 The area is patrolled by U.S. French and British planes 
16785 We are in close touch with all our allies said the Foreign Office spokesman 
16786 He declined to give any further information 
16787 Seven Iraqis charged with hijack 
16788 LONDON 1996-08-31 
16789 Seven Iraqi men appeared in court on Saturday charged with air piracy following the hijacking to Britain of a Sudanese airliner with 199 people aboard 
16790 The seven including a carpenter and a businessmen and whose ages ranged from 25 to 38 years old were ordered to be held in jail until another hearing next week 
16791 No pleas were entered at the preliminary hearing 
16792 They were accused of taking over Flight 150 which was flying from Khartoum Sudan to Amman Jordan 
16793 All the hostages were freed on Tuesday after the plane landed at Stansted airport north of London 
16794 The men have claimed political asylum in Britain saying they were persecuted while in Iraq 
16795 Their court appearance means they will face trial and possible imprisonment in Britain before their applications for asylum are considered 
16796 Under English law the maximum sentence for hijack is life imprisonment but there has been widespread speculation that the seven will receive lesser sentences 
16797 After a search of the aircraft following the hijack police found only knives and fake explosives 
16798 Opposition group says Iraqis advance in north Iraq 
16799 LONDON 1996-08-31 
16800 An Iraqi opposition group in exile said on Saturday it had received reports that Iraqi forces were shelling and advancing on the Kurdish town of Arbil in northern Iraq 
16801 A London-based spokesman of the Iraqi National Congress said Iraqi artillery was shelling the city and Iraqi tanks had advanced to within 10 km six miles of Arbil the administrative centre of the Kurdish rebel-controlled region of northern Iraq 
16802 At 4.50 a.m. Iraq time 0050 GMT Iraqi forces began an artillery attack on the outskirts of Arbil the spokesman who asked not to be identified told Reuters in a telephone call 
16803 There was no independent confirmation of the report which the spokesman said came from the organisation 's members in Arbil 
16804 He said damage and casualties in the city were heavy and Kurdish forces were defending the city 
16805 President Bill Clinton on Friday ordered the U.S. military to ready itself for any possible action as Washington turned up the heat in an escalating crisis over Iraqi troop movements in northern Iraq 
16806 On Thursday Iraq accused Iran of aggression and said it reserved the right to retaliate for Tehran 's alleged deployment of troops into northern Iraq where fighting broke out between the two main Iraqi Kurdish rebel groups two weeks ago 
16807 Two die in Algeria restaurant blast radio 
16808 LONDON 1996-08-31 
16809 Two people were killed when a hand grenade exploded in a restaurant near Algiers late on Friday Algerian radio reported on Saturday 
16810 The report monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation BBC quoted security services as saying six other people were injured in the blast in the town of Staouelli 
16811 An estimated 50,000 people had been killed in political violence in Algeria since 1992 when army-backed authorities cancelled a general election that Islamic fundamentalists had been expected to win

16827 S. African Afrikaners still seek own territory 
16828 CAPE TOWN 1996-08-31 
16829 South African right-wing Afrikaners on Saturday revived their campaign for a form of self-rule identifying a sparsely-populated area in Northern Cape province as the best place for a home of their own 
16830 Constand Viljoen leader of the Freedom Front party told a news conference in Pretoria self-determination for Afrikaners could begin at local government level 
16831 Certain powers can be delegated from the provincial level towards the sub-regions he said 
16832 We think that the Afrikaner model within this new multi- ethnic society of South Africa will have to develop experimentally with world thinking in this regard 
16833 Viljoen broke with other right-wing whites in 1994 by taking part in the country 's first all-race elections in April of that year saying the only way to attain self-determination was by cooperating with President Nelson Mandela 's majority African National Congress 
16834 Some right-wingers demanded sovereignty in their own territory in the run-up to the elections saying the alternative was war 
16835 Their threats came to nothing 
16836 Viljoen has hailed clauses in South Africa 's new constitution as making possible a form of self-rule for the Afrikaners descendants of the country 's Dutch German and French settlers 
16837 According to state television Viljoen told the news conference the self-rule model should be introduced in parts of the Northern Cape provinces where a majority of people whites and mixed-race Coloureds speak Afrikaans 
16838 Rwandan refugee group calls for calm over census 
16839 NAIROBI 1996-08-31 
16840 A Rwandan refugee lobby group called on Saturday for calm in refugee camps in eastern Zaire during a census from Sunday to be conducted by aid workers 
16841 The Rally for the Return of Refugees and Democracy in Rwanda RDR urged the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees to avoid any policing approach and to calm refugees by explaining the aims of the operation 
16842 The RDR appeals to all refugees to prepare themselves calmly for the demands of the census agents because it will be in their ultimate interest the group said in a statement 
16843 It said refugees feared census takers would use indelible ink to mark them so they could be detected by Rwandan government troops and mistreated if they were forced back into Rwanda 
16844 U.N. officials said more than 1,000 aid workers will take part in the census from Sunday until Tuesday of the estimated 727,000 refugees in camps around the eastern Zairean border town of Goma 
16845 Only about 100 refugees a week are returning voluntarily to Rwanda in contrast to the 600 babies born in the camps weekly 
16846 Zairean Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo said at the end of a visit to Rwanda last week that the Zairean and Rwandan governments agreed on an organised massive and unconditional repatriation of the 1.1 million Rwandan refugees in Zaire 
16847 He said the repatriation would be carried out swiftly and would be enormous starting with the closure of refugee camps 
16848 RDR said it feared forced expulsions would start in days 
16849 Zairean troops expelled 15,000 refugees in August last year 
16850 Many of the 1.1 million Rwandan Hutu refugees in Zaire and nearly 600,000 in Tanzania refuse to go home saying they fear reprisals for the 1994 genocide in Rwanda of up to a million people by Hutus 
16851 NATO monitors Moslem move towards tense village 
16852 MAHALA Bosnia 1996-08-31 
16853 NATO said it was closely monitoring the movement of about 75 Moslem men towards the village of Mahala in Bosnia 's Serb republic on Saturday two days after a violent confrontation with Serbs 
16854 I have to report this morning that we have in fact received reports 
16855 that up to 75 Moslem men are believed to be approaching Mahala NATO spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Max Marriner said in Sarajevo 
16856 Marriner said that NATO troops had set up a checkpoint on the road between Tuzla and Mahala to establish the identities and intentions of the men headed towards the village 
16857 Mahala is a Moslem village on Bosnian Serb republic territory 
16858 Moslems were driven from the village during the 43- month Bosnian war and most of their houses were destroyed 
16859 Some Moslems began returning to rebuild their properties earlier in the week 
16860 Fights and shooting broke out between the Moslems and Serb police on Thursday and NATO troops finally brought restored order 
16861 A Reuters reporter who entered Mahala on Saturday morning found it tranquil but NATO troops and U.N. police were seen on the ground and NATO helicopters flew overhead 
16862 Chechens exuberant but cautious on peace deal 
16863 Liutauras Stremaitis 
16864 URUS-MARTAN Russia 1996-08-31 
16865 Crowds of pro-independence Chechens greeted a newly-signed peace deal by singing dancing and firing guns in the air on Saturday but the celebrations held a trace of uncertainty 
16866 More than a thousand women children and men gathered in a field to the north of the town of Urus-Martan on Saturday to wait for a column of rebels to withdraw from the capital Grozny about 25 km 12 miles away 
16867 The men fired weapons into the air as groups of women danced 
16868 Adults in the crowd carried posters of former Chechen leader Dzhokhar Dudayev who declared independence in 1991 and children carrying photographs of him called Troops out ! 
16869 Russian military officials have expressed fears that the rebels and their supporters will see the deal signed by Russian peace envoy Alexander Lebed in the early hours of Saturday as a military victory for the separatists 
16870 It involves the withdrawal of Russian troops sent to Chechnya in December 1994 to crush the separatists and a postponement of the issue at the heart of the conflict the status of the mainly-Moslem North Caucasus region 
16871 But the people in the crowd on Saturday who had turned out in support of the rebels did not seem sure that the war was over 
16872 We hope for the best that it really has ended so we can live in peace 
16873 It 's our only dream said a 30-year-old woman Mubatik Dagayeva 
16874 Aiza Dudayeva with her 10-year-old son beside her shared the guarded optimism 
16875 We really want the war to end we hope and believe that our sons and brothers will win said Dudayeva adding that she was from Urus-Martan 
16876 Urus-Martan is a traditionally anti-separatist pocket in Chechnya and Moscow-backed leader Doku Zavgayev who has been sidelined in the peace deal has warned that it and places like it could become centres of civil war if Russian troops leave 
16877 But on Saturday the people gathered just outside the town seemed to be united in favour of the separatists 
16878 Two columns of rebels appeared in jeeps and cars firing their guns in the air as the crowd rushed towards them 
16879 Mouldi Mamatuyev in his late 20 's dressed in black and carrying a machine gun was welcomed by his mother and sister 
16880 Two sons have come back said his mother Nurbika Mamatuyeva 
16881 It 's the end 
16882 We believe in God 
16883 Mamatuyev joked that his sister Lisa was a rebel too and she responded by grabbing hold of his gun and shouting the Chechen war cry Allahu Akhbar God is Greatest and Freedom for Chechnya ! 
16884 The fighter sitting next to a man dressed in green and carrying a grenade-launcher said that the strict Islamic law adopted by the rebels during the conflict was now needed to impose peace 
16885 The war has ended if everything works out if there is law there will be power 
16886 Only Sheriat Islamic law can end the war 
16887 Polish group to bid for Ruch newsstand chain paper 
16888 WARSAW 1996-08-31 
16889 A Polish consortium including the Bank Rozwoju Exportu SA BRE plans to rival France 's Hachette in bidding for Polish state-owned press distribution chain Ruch SA Zycie Warszawy daily said on Saturday 
16890 Zycie Warszawy said its own publisher mineral water firm Multico and a group headed by Polish businessman Zygmunt Solorz were forming a consortium which would offer about $ 120 million with finance provided by BRE 
16891 The consortium wanted 40 percent of Ruch 's shares the state would get 20 percent of Ruch and 40 percent would be offered on the Warsaw stock exchange 
16892 This division would guarantee a dispersal of capital preventing anyone from taking total control over Ruch and dictating market conditions the paper quoted one of the initiators of the move as saying without giving a name 
16893 A consortium of press distributor Hachette and Polish publishers group UWP are seeking more than than 50 percent of Ruch and French President Jacques Chirac is likely to support its case when he visits Poland in September the daily said 
16894 News-stand chain Ruch which controls about 65 percent of Poland 's press distribution market had a net profit of 16.2 million zlotys on sales of 2.7 billion zlotys in 1995 
16895 It has about 17,000 news-stands and was the country 's sole press distributor before the 1989 fall of communism 
16896 Zycie Warszawy said the new open consortium which also included several listed Polish firms would on Monday inform Privatisation Minister Wieslaw Kaczmarek of its plans 
16897 It aims to invest $ 200 million in Ruch over five years more than the sum Ruch says it needs to upgrade its outlets 
16898 Initially Poland offered up to 75 percent of Ruch but in March Kaczmarek cancelled the tender and offered a minority stake with an option to increase the equity 
16899 Two consortia UWP-Hachette and a consortium of a Polish SPC group and Swiss firms placed initial bids 
16900 But after the change of tender conditions Swiss investors pulled out and SPC decided to bid jointly with UWP-Hachette 
16901 Kaczmarek said in May he was unhappy that only one investor ended up bidding for Ruch in which the government was initially offering up to 35 percent of shares with an option to extend the holding after investment promises are fulfilled 
16902 Anthony Barker +48 22 653 9700

16908 Attacks on servicemen aimed at seizing their guns have become frequent in Russia where the number of violent crimes committed with the use of fire arms is growing 
16909 Cuban novelist Jose Soler Puig dies at 79 
16910 HAVANA 1996-08-31 
16911 One of Cuba 's most acclaimed authors Jose Soler Puig died at the age of 79 the official newspaper Granma reported on Saturday 
16912 Puig 's first novel Bertillon 166 was published in 1960 a year after the Cuban revolution brought President Fidel Castro to power 
16913 The book which has been translated into 40 languages deals with a day in the life of Santiago de Cuba Puig 's native city under the pre-Castro government of Fulgencio Batista 
16914 The titles of his other novels translate as In the Year of January 1963 The Collapse 1964 Sleeping Bread 1975 The Decaying Mansion 1977 and A World of Things 1982 followed by The Knot Soul Alone and most recently A Woman 
16915 Granma called Sleeping Bread Puig 's greatest gift to the modern novel in our America 
16916 The author said in an interview shortly before his death that his own experiences had lent his books their strong sense of realism 
16917 I 'm a thief of ideas he said 
16918 The stories have been given to me by people 
16919 In the same interview published by Prensa Latina on Saturday Puig was asked if he feared death 
16920 Death is not a punishment death is the end of life 's punishment he said

16932 Radio Red quoted local police in the town of Tacambaro Michoacan 80 km 50 miles south of the state capital Morelia as saying 40 to 50 armed men attacked the convoy

16937 China said to fear dissidents more than criminals 
16938 MANILA 1996-08-31 
16939 The detention of veteran dissident Wang Donghai showed China 's determination to crush any vestige of dissent during the current profound transitions in the nation 's leadership a human rights activist said on Saturday 
16940 Xiao Qiang executive director of the New York-based group Human Rights in China said Wang 's arrest on Friday appeared to be part of the national Strike Hard campaign that has imprisoned thousands and sent hundreds to their death 
16941 Although supposedly aimed at criminals dozens of human rights activists have been detained in the campaign which is meant to strengthen the Communist Party 's grip on power as senior leader Deng Xiaoping nears death Xiao said in an interview 
16942 China is going through this power transition period 
16943 The authorities are apparently extremely afraid of any political and social discontent said Xiao in Manila to attend an Amnesty International conference on human rights in China 
16944 He said one of Wang 's apparent offences was to write a public letter in May suggesting that a free press and an independent judicial system were vital if the government really meant to stamp out rampant corruption 
16945 Xiao said crushing legitimate dissent was only making the problem worse and one day China would pay a high price 
16946 Those issues are not going to go away by repression 
16947 You only make things more hidden but potentially more explosive he said 
16948 Wang was arrested in the east China city of Hangzhou by security officers who told the dissident 's family he would be sent to a study class a euphemism for coercive ideological reform 
16949 Wang 45 was sentenced last month to one year 's re-education by labour but was released because of ill-health 
16950 Xiao said conditions in the labour camp were so brutal they drove another activist sentenced with Wang to attempt suicide 
16951 Police beat Wang and his colleague Chen Longde and encouraged other camp inmates to attack them as well Xiao said

16957 Jakarta served as the host to the series of negotiations which culminated in the initialling of the agreement last Friday

16959 Ramos said the peace agreement shall bring down the curtain on a long and storied era of strife in Philippine history 
16960 The war claimed more than 125,000 lives in the southern Mindanao island over a quarter of a century 
16961 Burma 's Suu Kyi says military rulers abuse law 
16962 Deborah Charles 
16963 RANGOON 1996-08-31 
16964 Burma 's democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi hit out at the government on Saturday for recent arrests and jailing of activists saying the military abused the law to try to crush the democracy movement 
16965 The main purpose of this press conference is to make it known to the world that the authorities are misusing the law all the time in order to try to crush the democracy movement Suu Kyi told reporters at her Rangoon home 
16966 Suu Kyi said at least 61 democracy supporters had been arrested since May and about 30 of them had been sentenced most to long prison terms 
16967 In May the government launched a sweeping crackdown on the democracy movement detaining over 260 members of Suu Kyi 's National League for Democracy NLD ahead of a party congress 
16968 Most were released but several dozen remain in custody 
16969 The Burmese government last week confirmed the recent sentencing of nine democracy activists who were arrested in the May crackdown including Suu Kyi 's assistant Win Htein 
16970 The military government which in May said it had detained the politicians to prevent anarchy said the activists were charged with attempting to destroy the peace and stability of the state 
16971 But Suu Kyi disagreed with the methods saying officials often arrested NLD supporters in the middle of the night then did not give them the opportunity to defend themselves in trials 
16972 When our people are tried they are tried in a very secretive way 
16973 Their families are not told she said 
16974 Suu Kyi who spearheads a campaign for sanctions on Burma 's government was under house arrest for six years without being tried before being released in July 1995 
16975 Several other leading members of the NLD have served prison terms 
16976 The NLD party won a landslide victory in a 1990 election but the State Law and Order Restoration Council SLORC which assumed power in 1988 after crushing pro-democracy demonstrations never recognised the poll 
16977 This lack of rule of law is an indication that the authorities are not interested in fair play she said 
16978 They are using a travesty of the law to try and crush our movements and to sentence our people to long terms in prison without proper trial 
16979 Suu Kyi said once the activists were sentenced they suffered inhuman conditions and lack of rights in prison 
16980 Almost all of the prisoners start suffering from various health problems after a couple of years in jail she said 
16981 Some of our people have been in prison for five to six years 
16982 Most political prisoners are held in Rangoon 's Insein Prison 
16983 Some who have been released have recounted torture methods like sleep and food deprivation and physical abuse 
16984 If there are any more instances of death in custody it will be further proof that a prison sentence for political prisoners is sometimes almost the same as a death sentence Suu Kyi said 
16985 Hla Than an elected member of parliament for the NLD died in early August after being at Insein for six years 
16986 His death came five weeks after James Leander Leo Nichols a close friend of Suu Kyi and Danish honorary consul died while serving a prison term at Insein 
16987 Suu Kyi said the government had increased its repression tactics on the democracy movement because it feared the growing popularity of the movement 
16988 But she said she and the NLD would not stop their efforts to bring democracy to Burma even if it meant more arrests of party members or even herself 
16989 We will carry on 
16990 Nobody is free from arrest in Burma

16992 BEIJING 1996-08-31

17000 N. Korea urges S. Korea to return war veteran 
17001 SEOUL 1996-08-31 
17002 North Korea demanded on Saturday that South Korea return a northern war veteran who has been in the South since the 1950-53 war Seoul 's unification ministry said 
17003 ...I request the immediate repatriation of Kim In-so to North Korea where his family is waiting North Korean Red Cross president Li Song-ho said in a telephone message to his southern couterpart Kang Young-hoon 
17004 Li said Kim had been critically ill with a cerebral haemorrhage 
17005 The message was distributed to the press by the South Korean unification ministry 
17006 Kim an unrepentant communist was captured during the Korean War and released after spending more than 30 years in a southern jail 
17007 He submitted a petition to the International Red Cross in 1993 asking for his repatriation

17011 Chinese police hold veteran dissident 
17012 BEIJING 1996-08-31 
17013 Chinese police have detained veteran dissident Wang Donghai the New York-based pressure group Human Rights in China said on Saturday 
17014 Police in Hangzhou capital of the eastern province of Zhejiang told Wang 's family that Wang would be sent to a study class a euphemism for coercive ideological reform the group said 
17015 Police gave no reason for detaining Wang on Friday and would not let his family meet him or say where he was being held the group said 
17016 Police also would not say why Wang was being sent to a study class a holdover from the chaotic 1966-76 Cultural Revolution or say when he would be released the group said 
17017 Wang 's family and Hangzhou police could not be reached for immediate comment 
17018 The group demanded Wang 's release and said his detention was a dangerous signal China was returning to its Cultural Revolution days 
17019 Last month Wang 45 a veteran dissident of the 1979 Democracy Wall movement was ordered to serve one year of re-education through labour but released because of poor health 
17020 Re-education through labour is an administrative punishment with a maximum of three years that can be imposed by police without recourse to prosecutors or the courts 
17021 Wang was jailed for two years for organising street protests after the military crushed pro-democracy demonstrations by students at Beijing 's Tiananmen Square on June 4 1989 with heavy loss of life 
17022 Chinese authorities appeared to be using administrative punishment more frequently to take dissidents out of circulation without having to go through a more complicated judicial process to impose criminal sentences Western diplomats have said

17026 Police detained Wang on Friday and would not let his family meet him or say where he was being held the group said 
17027 The pressure group said Wang would be sent to a study class often a euphemism in China for ideological reform 
17028 Wang 's family could not immediately be reached for comment 
17029 Last month Wang 45 a veteran dissident of the 1979 Democracy Wall movement was ordered to serve one year of re-education through labour but released because of poor health 
17030 Re-education through labour is an administrative punishment with a maximum of three years that can be imposed by police without recourse to prosecutors or the courts 
17031 Wang was jailed for two years for organising street protests after the military brutally crushed pro-democracy demonstrations by students at Beijing 's Tiananmen Square on June 4 1989 with heavy loss of life

17111 Automakers U.S. agency plan air bag safety ads 
17112 DETROIT 1996-08-31 
17113 Automakers suppliers insurers and the federal government 's auto safety agency Saturday launched a $ 10 million safety awareness campaign aimed at reducing the number of children killed accidentally by air bags in cars and trucks 
17114 Officials said they will work with law enforcement agencies pediatricians and media to warn parents about the dangers that air bags pose to children and adults not wearing seatbelts 
17115 Since 1993 24 children have been killed by the explosive force of automotive air bags which inflate at speeds up to 200 miles per hour 
17116 The first portion of the campaign involves pickup trucks equipped with billboards that were driving along some of the nation 's busiest interstate highways during the Labor Day weekend including Interstate 95 on the East Coast Interstates 80 and 90 in the Midwest and Interstate 5 in California 
17117 The boards read Air Bag Safety Everyone Buckled Kids in Back 
17118 Janet Dewey executive director of the industry-funded National Automobile Occupant Protection Campaign said most of the injuries to children occurred because they were not wearing seatbelts 
17119 A child 's chances of being killed in a car accident whether the vehicle was equipped with an air bag or not is reduced by 29 percent when they are in the rear seat she said 
17120 The auto industry was about three to six years away from introducing smart air bags with the ability to detect the size and position of an occupant and adjust inflation pressures accordingly 
17121 Current air bags were designed to halt the forward momentum of an average-sized unbelted adult male not a small child 
17122 Automakers petitioned the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to allow them to introduce air bags that inflate less aggressively to help reduce unwanted injuries 
17123 Even if changes are made to airbags today we 'd still have 20 million vehicles on the road with current technology Dewey said 
17124 The public has n't been getting the message 
17125 Two die as New Hampshire motel explodes and burns 
17126 ROCHESTER N.H. 1996-08-30 
17127 Adds deaths other details 
17128 An explosion leveled Rochester 's one-story Lilac Falls Motel killing two people fire officials said Friday 
17129 It was an explosion and then it got involved in fire 
17130 As far as I know it 's been to four alarms more trucks more people said Don Penney of the Rochester Fire Department said 
17131 Eyewitnesses told Boston television stations they saw a gasoline truck parked behind the Lilac Falls Motel and smelled gasoline shortly before the explosion 
17132 Fire department officials said they were investigating the cause of the blast and searching for any more casualties 
17133 Officials did not immediately identify the victims 
17134 Local hospital officials said a few firemen were treated for smoke inhalation but there were no other injuries 
17135 Car kills two trying to avoid Texas drag race 
17136 DALLAS 1996-08-31 
17137 An illegal drag race on a Dallas street turned deadly when another vehicle veered into the crowd killing two people and injuring a dozen more police said Saturday 
17138 Organisers tried to block off traffic while preparing the drag race late on Friday but an allegedly drunk driver was unable to slow down in time and ran into a group of spectators as he swerved to avoid one of the cars that was to take part in the race 
17139 A 26-year-old man and an 18-year-old woman were killed 
17140 The driver aged 51 was arrested and charged on two counts of intoxicated manslaughter 
17141 A police spokesman said the straight flat stretch of road was often used illegally as a drag strip by Dallas youths 
17142 U.S. warplanes ships in Gulf await Clinton order 
17143 Jim Adams 
17144 WASHINGTON 1996-08-31 
17145 More than 300 U.S. warplanes and 20 ships were available on Saturday in case President Bill Clinton ordered the use of U.S. force against Iraqi military action in northern Iraq U.S. defense officials said 
17146 They said 200 fighter planes including 79 on the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson were already in the Gulf ; the aircraft carrier Enterprise was in the eastern Mediterranean with 79 more and an air expeditionary force with up to 40 more was ready to fly from the United States if ordered 
17147 Yesterday the president ordered the Department of Defense to take prudent planning steps to have forces ready to deploy to the region should he direct us to do so Pentagon spokesman Doug Kennett said 
17148 We have taken those prudent planning steps 
17149 Clinton said on Saturday he had ordered U.S. forces in the Gulf to go on high alert and was reinforcing them in response to Iraqi attacks on Kurdish dissidents in northern Iraq 
17150 These developments cause me grave concern Clinton said at a campaign stop in Troy Tennessee 
17151 But he added It is premature at this time and I want to emphasize that highly premature to speculate on any response we might have 
17152 The U.S. defense officials said military flights to enforce no-fly zones in both northern and southern Iraq doubled over the weekend 
17153 Clinton said Iraqi military forces overran the city of Arbil which has been held since 1994 by Kurdish rebels who Baghdad says are backed by Iran 
17154 There were unconfirmed reports that Iran had sent troops into northern Iraq in response to Iraq 's attack 
17155 U.S. plans rely heavily on U.S. air attacks on Iraqi forces but there are also 23,000 U.S. troops in the region according to defense officials 
17156 In addition to the 158 F A-18 F-14 and other fighter planes on the aircraft carriers Vinson and Enterprise the Air Force air expeditionary force of 30 to 40 F-15 and F-16 fighter planes and fuel tankers is ready to fly from three U.S. bases in the United States they said 
17157 The expeditionary force would include nearly 1,000 Air Force personnel in ground and support crews they said 
17158 The 23,000 U.S. military people already in the Gulf consist of 15,000 sailors and Marines 6,000 U.S. servicemen based primarily in Saudi Arabia and 2,000 U.S. troops in the area for military exercises 
17159 Most of the Marines are on three ships in the Tarawa Amphibious Readiness Group 
17160 The Carl Vinson leads a battle group that includes seven other ships and there are nine other U.S. ships in the Gulf for a total of 20 
17161 Two missing Belgian teenagers found unharmed 
17162 BRUSSELS 1996-08-31 
17163 Two Belgian teenage girls missing since Thursday have been found unharmed police said on Saturday 
17164 The girls Rachel and Severine have been found 
17165 They are unharmed a police official in Liege said 
17166 He declined to say whether the girls had been kidnapped or whether they had gone away of their own accord 
17167 Late on Friday the two girls Rachel Legeard 18 and Severine Potty 19 were reported missing after failing to return home from a shopping trip to the eastern town of Liege on Thursday 
17168 Earlier police declined to comment on whether it suspected a link with the Marc Dutroux case the paedophile kidnap sex abuse and murder scandal which has rocked Belgium in the past two weeks 
17169 Algeria restaurant bomb kills seven newSpaper 
17170 PARIS 1996-08-31 
17171 A bomb explosion in a restaurant west of Algiers on Friday killed seven people an Algerian newspaper said on Saturday 
17172 Algerian security forces said in a statement that two people were killed and six were wounded when a home-made bomb ripped through a restaurant in the coastal town of Staoueli 
17173 But Le Matin newspaper quoting witnesses said the bomb killed seven people and wounded 20 
17174 Liberte newspaper said the bomb was hidden in a bag in front of the restaurant and that a booby-trapped car was defused near the restaurant shortly before the bomb went off 
17175 A week ago a home-made bomb exploded in a market in the western coastal town of Bou Haroun 65 km 40 miles from Algiers 
17176 Newspapers said it killed two women and five children 
17177 Algerian newspapers quoted the Human Rights National Observatory ONDH a government-appointed watchdog as saying earlier in August that about 1,400 civilians had been killed in bomb attacks blamed on Moslem guerrillas in the past two years 
17178 An estimated 50,000 people have died in Algeria 's violence pitting Moslem rebels against government forces since early 1992 when the authorities cancelled a general election in which radical Islamists had taken a commanding lead 
17179 Iran agents stormed German diplomat 's home Bonn 
17180 BONN 1996-08-31 
17181 Iranian security forces burst into the home of a German cultural attache in Tehran a month ago and seized his guests for questioning Bonn 's foreign ministry said on Saturday 
17182 A spokesman said he could substantially confirm a report in the news weekly Der Spiegel which said Iranian secret police burst in while attache Jens Gust was entertaining six Iranian writers and their wives 
17183 Gust was threatened with violence then locked into a room to be interrogated on suspicion of promoting activities hostile to the state while his guests were taken away the magazine said 
17184 The ministry spokesman said the German embassy immediately made a sharp protest to the Tehran government 
17185 The Iranian ambassador was also summoned to the ministry in Bonn to hear a sharp protest and disapproval of this glaring breach of the principles of international law he added 
17186 Iran subsequently said it regretted the incident which it said had been the result of a misunderstanding 
17187 All those detained appeared to have been freed the spokesman said 
17188 Relations between the two countries are currently under strain because of the testimony in a Berlin court of former Iranian president Abolhassan Banisadr 
17189 Banisadr an avowed opponent of the Tehran government who now lives in exile accused top Iranian leaders of personally ordering the assassination of three exiled Kurdish leaders in a Berlin restaurant in 1992 
17190 Iran has asked Germany to extradite Banisadr who is due is due back in Berlin next Thursday to continue his testimony 
17191 Banisadr who received political asylum in France after fleeing there in 1981 told Der Spiegel he did not plan to ask for a guarantee of safe conduct 
17192 If Germany were to extradite him he said it would lose face before the whole world 
17193 German prosecutors have already accused Iran 's intelligence minister Ali Fallahiyan of ordering the killing of the Kurdish leaders 
17194 Iran which denies the allegations urged German authorities to disregard Banisadr 's testimony and said it could hurt relations 
17195 Italy 's Dini meets Burundi negotiator Nyerere 
17196 ROME 1996-08-31 
17197 Italian Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini on Saturday met former Tanzanian president Julius Nyerere the international negotiator for Burundi the ministry said 
17198 Nyerere arrived in Rome this week on a private visit and held talks with the U.S. special envoy to Burundi Howard Wolpe and the Sant Egidio Community an Italian Roman Catholic organisation which has been monitoring Burundi closely 
17199 Nyerere informed Minister Dini of the latest developments in the Great Lakes region with particular respect to Burundi following the military coup d'etat on July 25 the ministry said in a statement 
17200 It gave no details of their talks 
17201 Nyerere was due to be presented with an Artisans for Peace prize by the Lay Volunteers International Organisation on Sunday 
17202 He leaves Rome on Monday 
17203 The U.N. Security Council on Friday condemned the coup by retired Tutsi major Pierre Buyoya and for the first time said in a resolution it intended to pressure Buyoya into unconditional negotiations with all parties and factions without exception 
17204 Buyoya on Saturday dismissed its threat of an arms embargo against Burundi and flatly ruled out talks with Hutu rebels 
17205 Some 150,000 people mostly civilians have died in Burundi since 1993 when the country 's first democratically elected Hutu president was killed in an attempted army coup 
17206 Nato declines comment on fighting in Iraq 
17207 BRUSSELS 1996-08-31 
17208 The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation 's spokesman on Saturday declined all comment on reports of armed conflict in northern Iraq 
17209 But a NATO official told Reuters We are watching the situation closely 
17210 Earlier on Saturday an Iraqi Kurd leader said both Iraqi troops and Kurdistan Democratic Party KDP forces were attacking the city of Arbil in northern Iraq

17213 More than 10 weapons including automatic Kalashnikov rifles were stolen from an arms store in Belgium police said on Saturday 
17214 A policeman in the southern Belgian town of Chatelet told Reuters that thieves used a car to ram the window of an arms store in neighbouring Chatelineaux last night 
17215 It was the second arms robbery this week 
17216 On Tuesday thieves stole about 40 forearms from a shooting range in southern Belgium including Kalashnikov Uzi and Fal automatic weapons 
17217 No trace of two missing teenagers in Belgium 
17218 BRUSSELS 1996-08-31 
17219 Belgian police said on Saturday they had found no trace of two teenage girls reported missing during a shopping trip three days ago 
17220 There is no trace so far the enquiry is continuing a Liege police official told Reuters 
17221 Late on Friday Liege police said in a statement that on Thursday Rachel Legeard 18 and Severine Potty 19 had gone shopping to the eastern town of Liege on Thursday where Legeard 's wallet had been stolen 
17222 After reporting the theft to the police they took a bus home and reportedly got off the bus before arriving in their home village of Nandrin 
17223 They have not been seen since

17225 Controversial IRA film screened at Venice festival 
17226 Vera Haller 
17227 VENICE Italy 1996-08-31 
17228 Dublin-born director Neil Jordan says he never lost more sleep over a film than over Michael Collins his controversial epic about the IRA which has its premiere on Saturday at the Venice Film Festival 
17229 The film starring Liam Neeson and Julia Roberts recounts the life of Michael Collins the Irish Republican Army 's Director of Intelligence who fought for Irish independence from 1919 to 1921 
17230 Although not due for release in Britain until early next year some politicians have already said they feared it would fan sectarian tensions in British-ruled Northern Ireland 
17231 Jordan defends his decision to make the film whose screenplay he wrote himself after years of research saying it was more about history than any political statement 
17232 The film spares neither the Irish nor the British in its depiction of the savagery of the time Jordan said in a statement released by Warner Bros 
17233 How often has independence been achieved without bloodshed ? 
17234 Very rarely 
17235 Jordan whose 1992 film The Crying Game also came under fire for what was perceived as a sympathetic portrayal of the IRA said Collins was more than just a revolutionary 
17236 He developed techniques of guerilla warfare later copied by independence movements around the world from Mao Tse-Tung in China to Yitzak Shamir in Israel Jordan said 
17237 Collins would never be a proponent of contemporary terrorism as practised today 
17238 He was a soldier and a statesman and over time a man of peace 
17239 Leeson the Northern Ireland-born actor who was nominated for an Oscar for best actor for his performance in Schindler 's List plays the lead role in Jordan 's film 
17240 Aidan Quinn portrays Harry Boland Collins best friend and rival for the love of Kitty Kiernan played by Roberts 
17241 Much of the film was shot on location in Dublin with Jordan using thousands of its citizens as unpaid extras 
17242 A set however was used for the fighting scenes 
17243 Noting that information about Collins was as mysterious as the existence he maintained Jordan said he made some historical assumptions in the film 
17244 I have made choices about certain events based on my own extensive research into his letters and reported speeches he said 
17245 I wanted to make this a story as accurate as possible without killing it dramatically and I think I have 
17246 It is a very true film 
17247 One of the assumptions is his interpretation of the murky circumstances surrounding the shooting death of Collins who had broken with his comrades when he sought a negotiated settlement with Britain in an ambush in 1922 
17248 I have never lost more sleep over the making of a film than I have over Michael Collins but I 'll never make a more important one Jordan said 
17249 In the life of one person you can tell the events that formed the north and south of Ireland as they are today 
17250 Dhaka stocks seen steady in absence of big players 
17251 DHAKA 1996-08-31 
17252 Shares on the Dhaka Stock Exchange DSE may remain steady as small investors are expected to target mainly blue chips while overseas investors will prefer to keep to the sidelines when the market reopens after Moslem Friday weekend brokers said 
17253 The market is expected to remain steady 
17254 There will be both buying and selling pressure said broker Shakil Rizvi 
17255 Broker Khurshid Alam said The market sentiment will remain strong 
17256 But the prices may move in a close range following a continued market uptrend 
17257 Brokers said blue chips like IDLC Bangladesh Lamps Chittagong Cement and Atlas Bangladesh were expected to rise 
17258 They said there was still demand for blue chips in engineering sector despite their persistent rise over the past several sessions 
17259 The DSE all share price index closed 2.73 points or 0.22 percent up at 1,196.35 on a turnover of 133.7 million taka on Thursday 
17260 Dhaka Newsroom 880-2-506363
